DajirN A man vexed, or disquieted by grief: (Ṣ:) or grieved, (A, Mṣb,) and distressed in mind, (A,) or vexed, or disquieted, (Mṣb,) and complaining: (A, Mṣb:) or disgusted, (mutabar-imN, A, Ḳ,) and vexed, or disquieted, (Ḳ,) by grief: (TA:) and mutaDaj-irN↓ signifies the same: (A:) and so, but in an intensive manner, DujarapN↓: (TA:) and DajuwrN↓ is also an epithet [in this last, intensive, sense,] applied to a man: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, DajirN, signifying straitened, or distressed, in mind, is from the same word in the sense here next following. (TA.)
A narrow place; (Aboo-Bekr, Ḳ;) as also DajorN↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: DujorapN Grief, and distress of mind, with complaint: (A:) or disgust (tabar-umN, A, Ḳ) and vexation, or disquietude, (Ḳ,) arising from grief. (TA.) [SM supposes Z to have said that it is syn. with mutaDaj-irN: but this is a mistake.]
Also A certain small bird: (AḤát, O, Ḳ:*) as though [so called because], by reason of its disquietude, not remaining in one place. (TA.)

entry.sense: DujarapN: see DajirN.
DajuwrN: see DajirN.
Also A she-camel that cries, or grumbles, (A, Ḳ,) much, (A,) on being milked, (A, Ḳ,) being distressed thereby. (A.)

It is said in a prov., applied to a niggard from whom property is obtained by degrees, notwithstanding his niggardliness, Uin-a AlD-ajuwra qado tuHolabu [Verily the she-camel that grumbles (or that grumbles much) on being milked is sometimes milked]. (AʼObeyd.)
muDojirN act. part. n. of 4: pl. maDaAjiru and maDaAjiyru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mutaDaj-irN: see DajirN.

1. DajaEa, aor. _a {yaDojaEu}, inf. n. DajoEN and DujuwEN, [He lay upon his side; or] he laid his side upon the ground; [and simply he lay; and he slept;] as also AiDoTajaEa↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) which is also expl. as syn. with naAma, [which has the second and third of the meanings mentioned above,] and with AisotaloqaI, [which has the third of those meanings,] (TA,) the T being substituted for the t of AiDotajaEa, (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb,) and AiD-ajaEa↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AiloTajaEa↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, in the CK [erroneously] AT-ajaEa,) the D in ADTjE being changed into l, which is the letter nearest in sound thereto, because the combination of two such letters as D and T is disliked, (Ṣ, L,) the same change occurring in AiloTiraAdN for AiDoTiraAdN, (Az, TA,) though this change is anomalous; (L;) and OaDojaEa↓ likewise signifies the same as DajaEa; (Mṣb;) [and] so does AnDjE↓, (Ḳ, TA,) as quasi-pass. of the trans. verb ADjE. (TA.)
[And accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán of the Hudhalees as signifying He declined from the way.]

DajaEa Aln-ajomu means ‡ [The star, or asterism, or the Pleiades,] inclined to setting; as also Dj-E↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. taDojyEN. (TA.) And DajaEati AlX-amosu is a dial. var. of Dj-Et↓, (TA,) which means ‡ The sun approached the setting; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) like Dar-aEat. (Ṣ, TA.)

DajaEa fiI Oamorihi ‡ He was, or became, weak in his affair; as also ADjE↓; and so DajiEa, like fariHa [in measure], on the authority of IḲṭṭ. (TA. [See also 2, and 5, and 6.]) And DujiEa fiI raOoyihi [not a mistranscription for DajiEa, as is shown by its part. n., q. v.,] ‡ He was, or became, weak in his judgment, or opinion. (TA.)
2: see above {1}, in two places.

Dj-E fiI AlOamori, (Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDojiyEN, (Ṣ,) ‡ He fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, in the affair; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ, TA;) and was, or became, weak therein. (Mgh.) [See also DajaEa fiI Oamorihi, and see 5, and 6.]
Hence, Alt-aDojiyEu fiI Aln-iy-api † The wavering, or vacillating, in intention, and not making it to take effect. (Mgh.)

3. DAjEhu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. muDaAjaEapN, He lay upon his side, or simply he lay, or slept, with him. (TA.) And DaAjaEahaA, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) He lay, or slept, with her, (Mṣb, TA,) namely, his girl, or young woman, (TA,) in, or on, one bed, (Mṣb,) or in one innermost garment. (TA.)
And hence, DAjEhu Alham-u ‡ Anxiety clave to him. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. OaDojaEotuhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDojaAEN, (TA,) I laid him upon his side; (Ṣ,* Mṣb;) I laid his side upon the ground. (Ḳ.)
And ‡ I lowered it, or depressed it, namely, a thing. (Ḳ, TA.)
ADjE Alr-umoHu AlT-aEona ‡ [app. The spear made the thrusting to be in a downward direction]. (TA.)
ADjE juwaAliqahu † He emptied his sack, it being full. (O, Ḳ.)
AlUiDojaAEu in relation to the vowel-sounds is ‡ like AlUimaAlapu and AlxafoDu. (Ḳ, TA. [See arts. myl and xfD.])
See also 1, in two places.

entry.sense: 5. tDj-E fiI AlOamori ‡ He held back in the affair, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and did not undertake it. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also 1, and 2, and 6.]
And tDj-E Als-aHaAbu ‡ The clouds continued raining (Oarab-a) in the place. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
6. tDAjE Eano Oamori kacaA wakacaA ‡ He feigned himself unmindful, or heedless, of such and such an affair. (Z, TA.) [See also 1, and 2, and 5.]
7: see 1, first sentence.
8. AiDoTajaEa, and its vars. AiD-ajaEa and AiloTajaEa: see 1, first sentence.

AlAiDoTijaAEu fiI Als-ujuwdi is ‡ The not drawing up the body from the ground in prostration [in prayer]; (Mgh, TA;) the contracting oneself, and making the breast to cleave to the ground, therein. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also its part. n., below.]

DajoEN [The species of glasswort, or kali, called] gaAsuwl, for [washing] clothes: n. un. with p {DajoEapN}: (Ḳ:) accord. to IDrd, the gum of a certain plant, or a certain plant [itself], with which clothes are washed: (O:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) and, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Ed-Deenawaree, (O,) i. e. AḤn, (TA,) a certain plant, (Ḳ,) resembling small cucumbers, (O, Ḳ, TA,) [or] in shape like asparagus, (TA,) but thicker (O, Ḳ, TA) in a great degree, (O, TA,) four-sided in the stalks, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and having in it an acidity (O, TA,) and a bitterness (maraArap O) or a taste between sweet and sour (mazaAzap TA): it is crushed (yuXodaxu O) or cut into slices (yXrH TA) and its juice is expressed into milk such as is termed raAYib [q. v.], which in consequence becomes pleasant, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and somewhat biting to the tongue; and its leaves are put into sour milk, like as is done with the leaves of the mustard: (O, TA:) it is good as an aphrodisiac. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
DijoEN † Inclination: (O, Ḳ:) so in the phrase DijoEu fulaAnK UilaI fulaAnK † [The inclination of such a one is towards such a one], (O,) or UilaI-a [towards me]. (Ḳ.)
DajoEapN A single act of lying, upon the side or otherwise, or of sleeping: (IAth, O,* TA:) a sleep. (Ḳ, TA.)
And ‡ Weakness in judgment; (O, Ḳ, TA;) as also DujoEapN↓. (Ḳ.) One says, fiI raOoyihi DajoEapN ‡ In his judgment is weakness. (O, TA.)
And ‡ Ease; repose; freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; as also DujoEapN↓. (TA.)
DujoEapN One whom people often lay upon his side [or throw down]. (Ḳ, TA.)
[And app., One who lays others on the side, or prostrates them; as is implied by what here follows.]
† A disease: (Ḳ, TA:) because it lays the man upon his bed. (TA.)
See also DajoEapN, in two places.
And see DujaEapN.
DijoEapN A mode, or manner, of lying upon the side [or in any posture], (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of sleeping. (TA.)
And † Sluggishness, laziness, or indolence. (Ḳ, TA.)

Also, for caAtu DijoEapK, † A bed. (JM. [See also maDojaEN.]) It is said in a trad. that the DijoEap of the Apostle of God was of skins, (IAth, JM, TA,) stuffed with fibres of the palm-tree: (IAth, TA:) meaning his bed. (JM.)
DajaEapN a gen. n. (O, Ḳ) in the sense of AiDoTijaAEN [i. e. The act of lying upon the side, or in any manner; and of sleeping]. (O.)

DujaEapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and, accord. to the Ḳ, DujoEapN↓, but this [as an epithet] has the meaning first assigned to it above, (TA,) and DujoEiy-apN↓ and DijoEiy-apN↓ and DujoEiI-N↓ and DijoEiI-N↓, (O, Ḳ,) the last two [in the CK, erroneously, DujoEaI and DijoEaI, but] like quEodiI-N and qiEodiI-N, (O,) and DaAjEN↓, (Ḳ,) [or this last is a simple part. n.,] ‡ A man who lies upon his side [or in any manner, or sleeps,] much, or often: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) sluggish, lazy, or indolent: (Ṣ and O in explanation of the first, and Ḳ in explanation of all:) or who keeps to the house or tent; seldom, or never, going forth; nor rising and speeding to do a generous deed: or impotent and stationary: (Ḳ, TA:) [or,] accord. to IB, DaAjiEN↓ and DujoEiI-N↓ and DijoEiI-N↓ signify one who is content with his poverty, and betakes himself to his house or tent. (TA.)
DujoEiI-N and DijoEiI-N: see each in two places in the next preceding paragraph.
DujoEiy-apN and DijoEiy-apN: see DujaEapN.
DajuwEN A water-skin (qirobapN) that makes the drawer of water to lean by reason of its heaviness. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
A wide dalow [or leathern bucket]; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) as also DaAjiEapN↓. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O.)
‡ A cloud (saHaAbapN) slow by reason of the abundance of its water. (IDrd, O, Ḳ, TA.)
A well (biYorN) hollowed in the sides, the water having eaten its interior. (AA, O, Ḳ.*)
A she-camel that pastures aside. (AʼObeyd, O, Ḳ.)
A wife contrarious to the husband. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ. [See also OaDojaEu.])
And ‡ A man weak in judgment; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) as also maDojuwEN↓. (Ḳ.)

DajiyEN [A bedfellow]. DajiyEuka means He who lies, or sleeps, with thee; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) i. q. muDaAjiEuka↓; (Ḳ;) which latter is likewise applied to a female; as also DajiyEapN:
and you say, huwa DajiyEuhaA meaning He is he who lies, or sleeps, with her in one innermost garment; and hiIa DajiyEatuhu She is she who so lies, or sleeps, with him. (TA.) And [hence] one says, biYosa AlD-ajiyEu AljuwEu ‡ [Very evil is the bedfellow, hunger]. (TA.)
DaAjiEN Lying upon his side [or in any manner; and sleeping; see its verb]; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also muDoTajiEN↓ (TA) and muDojiEN↓. (Mṣb.) See also DujaEapN, in two places.
‡ Stupid, foolish, or unsound in intellect: (IAạr, O, Ḳ, TA:) because of his impotence, and his cleaving to his place. (TA.)
dalowN DaAjiEapN A leathern bucket that is full, (IAạr, ISk, O, Ḳ,) so that it leans in rising from the well by reason of its heaviness. (ISk, O, Ḳ.) See also DajuwEN.
And DaAjiEN ‡ A star inclining to setting: pl. DawaAjiEu: (O, Ḳ, TA:) [or] AlD-awaAjiEu signifies [or signifies also] the fixed stars. (Ḥam p. 364.)
And ‡ Inclining as in the saying OaraAka DaAjiEFA UilaI fulaAnK ‡ [I see thee inclining towards such a one]. (O, TA.)
And † A place of bending of a valley: pl. DawaAjiEu. (O, Ḳ.)
Also, applied to a beast, † Worthless; in which is no good. (TA.) [But]
ganamN DaAjiEapN means Numerous sheep or goats; as also DaHoEaMCu↓. (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And UibilN DaAjiEapN and DawaAjiEu † Camels keeping to the plants called HamoD; remaining among them. (TA.)

DaAjiEapN as a subst. i. q. maSab-u waAdK; (AA, T, O, Ḳ, TA;) [app. meaning The place where the water flows into it, of a valley; for] Az adds, in the T, as though it were a raHabap, [see raHabapu AlwaAdiI in art. rHb,] then, afterwards, it takes a straight direction, and becomes a valley (waAdK): pl. DawaAjiEu. (TA.)

DawaAjiEu [which is like wise pl. of DaAjiEN] also signifies [Hills such as are called] hiDaAb [pl. of haDobapN]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and is said to have no sing. [in this sense]: occurring in a verse of En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee: (Ṣ:) but ISk says that, in this instance, it is the name of a certain place. (O.)
OaDojaEu Alv-anaAyaA ‡ Having the central incisors inclining; (O, Ḳ, TA;) applied to a man: (O:) pl. DujoEN. (TA.)
And OaDojaEu signifies also Contrarious to his wife. (O, Ḳ. [See also DajuwEN.])
For a meaning of its fem., DajoEaMCu, see DaAjiEN, last sentence but one.

maDojaEN A place in which, or on which, one lies upon his side [or in any manner, or sleeps]; (O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also muDoTajaEN↓: (O, Ḳ:) [a bed; and the like:] pl. maDaAjiEu: (Mṣb, TA:) which means sometimes places of sleep, or of passing the night: (Bḍ in iv. 38:) and beds; or other things spread upon the ground to lie upon. (Jel ibid., and Bḍ in xxxii. 16.)
[Hence] the pl. is used as meaning † Wives, or women: so in the saying, huwa Tay-ibu AlmaDaAjiEi i. e. † He has well-born wives or women; like kariymu AlmafaAriXi. (TA.)

And maDaAjiEu Algayovi means ‡ The places of falling of rain. (O, Ḳ, TA.) One says, baAtati Alr-iyaADu maDaAjiEa lilogayovi ‡ [The meadows were during the night places of the falling of rain]. (A, TA.)
muDojiEN: see DaAjiEN, first sentence.
maDojuwEN: see DajuwEN, last sentence. muDaAjiEN: see DajiyEN
muDoTajaEN: see maDojaEN.
It is also used as an inf. n. (Ḥar p. 664.)
muDoTajaEN: see DaAjiEN, first sentence.
[It is said that] Sal-aI muDoTajiEFA means ‡ He prayed lying upon his right side, [or app., inclining towards that side,] facing the Kibleh. (TA. [But see 8.])

1. Dajima, (MA, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDojamu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DajamN, (MA, Ḳ,*) It was, or became, distorted, or crooked; said of the mouth; (MA, Ḳ;) and in like manner one says of the side of the mouth; and of the lip; and of the chin; and of the neck: (Ḳ:) and likewise, ‡ of a well: and ‡ of a wound. (Ḳ, TA.) [See DajamN below.]
6. tDAjm [He was, or became, distorted, or crooked, in the mouth: (see its part. n., below:) and so, accord. to Golius, ADjm-↓ and ADjAm-↓.]

[And] ‡ i. q. Aixotalafa: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) so in the saying, taDaAjama AlOamoru bayonahumo ‡ [The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them]. (Ṣ, TA.) And hence the saying, AlOasomaMCu taDaAjamu [for tataDaAjamu] i. e. taxotalifu [meaning ‡ Names are dissimilar, diverse, or various]. (TA.)
9: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.
11: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.

DajamN inf. n. of Dajima [q. v.]: (MA, Ḳ:*) [as a simple subst.,] Distortion, or crookedness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [in an absolute sense; and particularly,] in the mouth; and in the side of the mouth; and in the lip; and in the chin; and in the neck: (Ḳ:) and in the nose; (Lth, TA;) its inclining towards one side (Lth, Ṣ, TA) of the face: (Ṣ, TA:) and in one of the shoulders: (Ṣ, TA:) and, accord. to the M, in the bill [for xT in the TA (an obvious mistranscription) I read xaTom] of the male ostrich: and sometimes in the mouth together with the nose: (TA:) and in like manner ‡ in a well: and ‡ in a wound. (Ḳ, TA.)
DujomapN A certain small creeping thing (duwayob-apN) of foul odour, (Ḳ, TA,) that stings, or bites. (TA.)

OaDojamu Having the quality termed DajamN, expl. above: (Ḳ:) [or, particularly,] having the nose inclining towards one side of the face: (Ṣ:) [fem. DajomaMCu: and pl. DujomN.] And [hence] qaliybN OaDojamu † A well having a crookedness in the wall that surrounds its interior: or that is not dug in a straight, or an even, direction: pl. qulubN DujomN. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj has applied the phrase qulubN DujomN to ‡ Wide wounds; as likened to the wells thus termed. (TA.)
And [the pl.] DujomN signifies also † Men who eat much. (IAạr, TA.)
mutaDaAjimN Distorted, or crooked, in the mouth, (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. DaHoDaHa, [inf. n. DaHoDaHapN, which see below,] said of the saraAb [or mirage], It was, or became, in a state of commotion; or moved to and fro; as also taDaHoDaHa↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And, (Ḳ, TA,) said of an affair, (TA,) It was, or became, manifest, evident, or apparent. (Ḳ,* TA.)
R. Q. 2: see the preceding paragraph (R.Q.1).

DiH-N The sun: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and (Ḳ) the light of the sun, (Lth, A, O, Ḳ,) when it has possession of the ground: (Lth, O, TA:) or the light of the sun upon the surface of the ground; sunshine; contr. of Zil-N: (AHeyth, T, O, TA:) accord. to AHeyth, originally wiDoHN, the w being rejected and a H added to the radical H; but correctly, it is originally DiHoIN, from DHyt AlXms [app. a mistranscription for DaHiytu lilX-amosi]: (TA; as from the T:) also land, or ground, that lies open and exposed (Ḳ, TA) to the sun: (TA:) and what is shone upon, or smitten, by the sun: (Ḳ, TA:) it has no pl. in any of these senses. (El-Fihree, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yaqoEudan-a OaHadukumo bayona AlD-iH-i waAlZ-il-i faUin-ahu maqoEadu AlX-ayoTaAni (Ṣ, A) ‡ [None of you shall sit between the sunshine and the shade, for it is the sitting-place of the devil]; meaning half of him in the sun and half of him in the shade. (TA.) And one says, jaMCa fulaAnN biAlD-iH-i waAlr-iyHi ‡ Such a one came with, or brought, that upon which the sun had risen, and that upon which the wind had blown; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) meaning, abundance, or much; (Ṣ, A;) or much property, or many cattle: (TA:) [F asserts that] one should not say bAlD-iyHi, (Ḳ,) i. e. biAlD-iyHi waAlr-iyHi: (TA:) this the vulgar say, but [J affirms that] it is nought: (Ṣ:) several, however, assert that AlD-iyH is correct: (MF:) [and the author of the Ḳ, who disallows it in this art., authorizes it in art. DyH, q. v.:] Kr, also, is related to have said that AlDiyHu signifies “the sun” and “its light;” and is said to signify “what is exposed to the sun:” and a poet says,
waAlX-amosu fiI All-uj-api caAti AlD-iyHi
[And the sun in the abyss of sunlight]: Aboo-Mis-hal, moreover, mentions, in his “Nawádir,” the saying, AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaI AlD-iyHi waAlr-iyHi [meaning † Such a one was employed as manager of much property]. (TA.) maAta Eani AlD-iH-i waAlr-iyHi, occurring in a trad., is rendered agreeably with the explanation of the saying in a trad. mentioned above, and means ‡ He died leaving much property. (TA.) And it is said of the Prophet, in a trad., yakuwnu fiI AlD-iH-i waAlr-iyHi He will be exposed to the heat of the sun and the blowing of the winds; meaning, accord. to Hr, † he will be attended by, or in the midst of, numerous horsemen and military forces. (TA.)

hom.sense: DaHoDaHN: see DaHoDaHapN:
and DaHoDaAHN.

entry.sense: DuHoDuHN: see what next follows.
DaHoDaHapN and DaHoDaHN↓ and DuHoDuHN↓ The running of the saraAb [or mirage, along the surface of the ground, like water: see R. Q. 1]. (Ḳ.)

And Many, or much; in the dial. of Hudheyl; (AA, O, Ḳ;) not known to others: (TA: [see also DaHolN:]) accord. to Aṣ, it is applied to sheep or goats, and to camels, as meaning many, or numerous: and also as meaning scattered, or dispersed, over the surface of the land, but, notwithstanding, few. (TA.)

1. DaHika, (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) and some say DiHikotu, with kesr to the D, (TA, as from the Ḳ, [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,]) to agree with the vowel of the H because the latter is a faucial letter, and this is a correct dial. var. of which similar instances are mentioned, and DaHaka also is said to be a well known dial. var. of DaHika, (TA,) aor. _a {yaDoHaku}, (Ṣ. O,) inf. n. DaHikN and DiHokN (Ṣ, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, KL) and DaHokN, (Ṣ, MA, O, Ḳ, KL,) the first of which is the superior form, (IDrd, O,) [the second and third being contractions thereof,] and DiHikN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, KL,) and if you said DaHakN it would be agreeable with analogy, (Az, TA,) He laughed; (MA, KL, PṢ, TḲ;) contr. of bakaI: (TḲ:) [see also 6:] AlD-aHiku is well known, as meaning the expanding of the face, and displaying of the teeth, by reason of happiness, joy, or gladness; and Alt-abas-umu is the beginning thereof: thus in the Towsheeh and other works: (MF, TA:) and in like manner in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib]; in which it is added that it is also used as meaning simply the being happy, joyful, or glad: and sometimes as meaning simply the wondering [at a thing]; and this is the meaning intended by him who says that it is peculiar to man: (TA:) [i. e.] DaHika, said of a man, signifies also he wondered; syn. Eajiba; (O, Ḳ, TA;) with mino preposed to the object of wonder: (TA:) or he was frightened; or he feared. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, DaHika minohu and bihi, both meaning the same, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) i. e. He laughed at him; derided him; or ridiculed him: or he wondered at him. (Mṣb.) And DaHika Uilayohi [He behaved laughingly, or cheerfully, towards him]. (IDrd and Ḳ in art. bX [See baX-a lahu.])
Said of an ape, He uttered a cry or cries: (Ḳ:) or one says of the ape when he utters a cry or cries, yaDoHaku, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning he displays his teeth, or grins. (TA.)
And DaHika Als-aHaAbu ‡ The clouds lightened. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the usage of the verb in a trad. cited voce taHad-ava. (O, TA.)
And DaHika Algadiyru i. e. ‡ [The pool of water left by a torrent] glistened by reason of its fulness. (TA.)
[And DaHika vagoruhu † His front teeth, or his teeth, glistened by reason of his laughing; meaning he laughed so as to show his front teeth, or his teeth.]

And DaHika Alz-ahoru ‡ The flowers [looked gay, or] were as though they were laughing. (TA.) And DaHikati AlOaroDu ‡ The earth, or land, put forth its plants, or herbage, and its flowers. (TA.) And DaHikati Alr-iyaADu Eani AlOazohaAri ‡ The meadows, or gardens, displayed the flowers. (TA.)

And DaHikati Aln-axolapu ‡ The palm-tree put forth [or disclosed] its DaHok; as also OaDoHakat↓; (TA;) [i. e.] the spathe of the palm-tree, (Skr, O, TA,) that covered the TaloE [or spadix], (O,) burst open. (Skr, O, TA.) And DaHika AlT-aloEu ‡ The TlE [here app. meaning the spathe of the palm-tree] split, or clave, open; and so tabas-ama. (TA.)

And, as some assert, (ISd, TA,) DaHikato signifies also ‡ She menstruated; said of a hare; (ISd, Z, O, Mṣb, TA;) accord. to some, from the DaH-aAk [meaning the interior] of the TaloEap [of the palm-tree] when it bursts open; (ISd, TA;) and hence, (Ḳ, TA,) said also in this sense of a woman, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) accord. to Mujáhid, (O, TA,) and some others, (TA,) in the Ḳur xi. 74, (O, Ḳ, TA,) where some read faDaHakato, which is said to be a well-known dial. var.; (TA;) and likewise, accord. to some, said in this sense of the hyena, (O, TA,) when she sees blood, or as IAạr says, when she eats the flesh of men and drinks their blood: (TA:) [it is commonly asserted by the Arabs that] the hare menstruates like women: (Ḳzw:) but with respect to this meaning as assigned to the verb in the Ḳur xi. 74, Fr says that he had not heard it from any person deserving of confidence; (O, TA;*) and Zj says that it is nought: both say that the meaning there is, she laughed by reason of happiness: (TA:) and some say that there is an inversion in this case, what is meant being fabaX-aronaAhaA biUisoHeqa faDaHikato: (Fr, O, TA:) or the meaning is, she wondered; so says I’Ab; and so Er-Rághib, who adds that it is confirmed by her saying, “shall I bring forth a child when I am an old woman, and this my husband is an old man? verily this is indeed a wonderful thing:” and that faHaADato which is inserted by some of the expositors after faDaHikato is not an explanation of this expression, as some of them have imagined it to be, but is the mention of [a fact which was] a sign that the announcement was not that of an event improbable: or the meaning is, she was frightened; so says Fr.: (TA:) and with respect to the meaning of this verb when said of the hyena, mentioned above, it is rejected by AḤát and others: (TA:) IDrd says, on the authority of AḤát, respecting the following verse of TaäbbataSharrà,
taDoHaku AlD-aboEu liqatolaI hucayolK
wataraI Alc-iYoba lahaA yasotahil-u
that the meaning is † The hyena displays her teeth, or grins, on account of the slain [of Hudheyl], when she sees them, like as they say of the ass when he plucks out the [plant called] Sil-iyaAnap; (O, TA;) or, as others say, † the hyena snarls, displaying her teeth; and sees the wolf raising his voice in calling the [other] wolves to them, i. e. to the slain: (O, TA:*) Abu-l-ʼAbbás says that the meaning is, † the hyena displays her teeth, because the wolf contends with her over the slain: and some say that the poet means, † the hyena rejoices because of the slain. (TA.)
One says also, DaHikati Als-amurapu, meaning † The smrp [or gum-acacia-tree] flowed with its gum: from DHkt meaning “she menstruated.” (Bḍ in xi. 74.)
3. muDaAHakapN [inf. n. of DAHkhu] signifies [The contending, or vying, in laughing, with another; or the laughing with another; or] the laughing together. (KL.)
[Hence,] one says, Aln-aworu yuDaAHiku AlX-amosa † [The flowers vie in brightness with the sun]. (TA.)
And Uin-a raOoyaka layuDaAHiku AlmuXokilaAti ‡ [Verily thy judgment makes sport with ambiguities]; said to him to whom confused and dubious things are apparent and known. (TA.)
4. ADHkhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDoHaAkN, (KL,) said of God, (Ṣ, O,) or of a man, (Ḳ,) He made him, or caused him, to laugh. (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ,* KL, PṢ.)

[Hence,] ADHk AlD-abuEa, said of blood, (TA,) or of the sword, (O, TA,) † [It made the hyena to display her teeth; or to snarl, displaying her teeth: or to rejoice: (see 1, latter part:) but explained as meaning] ‡ it made the hyena to menstruate. (TA.)
And ADHk AlHawoDa ‡ He filled the wateringtrough so that it overflowed: (O, TA:) its glistening being likened to laughing. (TA.)
See also 1, near the middle of the paragraph.
5: see the next paragraph {6}.

6. tDAHk and tDH-k↓ [are both mentioned in the Ḳ and TA as though syn. with each other and with DaHika: and accord. to the KL, the former signifies He laughed: but accord. to the TḲ, the latter signifies he manifested laughing: or] the former is syn. with AstDHk↓ [app. as meaning he affected to laugh, or laughing: or, more exactly, agreeably with analogy, like the contr. tabaAkaI and AisotabokaI, the former signifies thus; and the latter, he desired to laugh]. (Ṣ.)
And you say also, humo yataDaAHakuwna [meaning They laugh together, one with another]. (Ḳ.)
10: see the next preceding paragraph {6}.

hom.sense: DaHokN [originally an inf. n., a contraction of DaHikN,] The appearance, or appearing, of the central incisors [or of the front teeth] by reason of happiness, joy, or gladness. (TA.)
And hence, (TA,) Wonder. (Ḳ, TA.)
[As an epithet,] A man whose teeth are white. (Aṣ, O, TA.)
[And as a subst., properly so termed,] White front teeth. (Aṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And † Honey: (Ḳ:) or white honey; (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA;) likened to the front teeth because of its intense whiteness: (AA, O, TA:) or honey in its comb; syn. XahodN. (Ḳ.)
And, (O, Ḳ,) some say, (O,) † Fresh butter. (O, Ḳ.)
And † Snow. (O, Ḳ.)
And † Blossoms, or flowers, or white blossoms or flowers; syn. naworN: (O, and so in copies of the Ḳ:) or light; syn. nuwrN. (So in a copy of the Ḳ.)

And † The TaloE [or spadix] of the palm-tree when its envelope bursts open from it; (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ;) in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab: (O:) accord. to Th, what is in the interior of the TaloEap [here meaning spathe of the palm-tree]: as AA says, the waliyEap, or waliyE [thus differently written in two different places in the TA,] of the TaloE [or spathe of the palm-tree], which is eaten; as also DaH-aAkN↓. (TA.)
And † The middle of a road; (Ḳ, TA;) and so, accord. to the Ḳ, DaH-aAkN↓; but, correctly, this should have been there mentioned as syn. with DaHokN in the sense next preceding. (TA.)
DaHokapN A single act of DaHik [or laughing; i. e. a laugh]. (Ṣ, O.)
[The pl.] DaHokaAtN signifies ‡ The best of everything: and DaHokaAtu Alquluwbi, the best of possessions, or wealth, and of children: so says Aboo-Saʼeed. (TA.)

entry.sense: DuHokapN A thing, (Lth, TA,) or a man, (Ṣ, O. TA,) that is laughed at, or ridiculed; i. e. yuDoHaku minohu: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) an epithet importing more discommendation than DuHakapN. (Ḳ.)
See also maDoHakN.

DuHakapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) an epithet importing discommendation, (Ḳ,) and DuHuk-apN↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) and DaH-aAkN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) an epithet importing commendation, (TA, [but the contr. is implied, or rather plainly indicated, in the Ḳ,]) and DaHuwkN↓, (Ḳ,) and miDoHaAkN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) which last is [also] applied to a woman, (Ṣ, O,) One who laughs much (kaviyru AlD-aHiki). (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
DuHuk-apN: see the next preceding paragraph.
DaHuwkN: see DuHakapN.
[Also] A man cheerful in countenance. (O.)
And † A wide road: (Ṣ, O:) or ‡ a distinct, an apparent, or a conspicuous, road; as also DaH-aAkN↓: pl. of the former (in this sense, TA) DuHokN. (Ḳ, TA.)
DaH-aAkN: see DuHakapN:
and see DaHokN, last two sentences:
and DaHuwkN.
DaAHikN Laughing; [&c.;] (KL;) act. part. n. of DaHika. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also applied to clouds (saHaAb), meaning ‡ Appearing, or extending sideways, in the horizon, and lightening. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
[And to the tooth (Als-in-, used as a gen. n.): thus in the phrase DaAHika Als-in-i, meaning † Laughingly, so as to display the teeth.]
See also DaAHikapN.
Also, [or perhaps HajarN DaAHikN,] ‡ Very white stone appearing in a mountain (IDrd, O, TA.) of any colour, as though laughing. (IDrd, O, TA.)
One says also raOoIN DaAHikN, meaning ‡ Judgment that is plain, or perspicuous, (TA,) not confused or dubious. (O, TA.)
And, [using DAHk as a gen. n.,] maA Oakovara DaAHika naxolikumo ‡ [How numerous are the bursting spathes of your palm-trees!]. (TA.)
[And an instance of DaAHikN applied to a woman, without p, meaning † Menstruating, is cited by Bḍ, in xi. 74.]

DaAHikapN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or DaAHikN↓, (Mṣb,) or both, (Mgh,) ‡ The tooth next behind the naAb [or canine tooth]; (Mgh, Mṣb;) [i. e. the anterior bicuspid;] any one of the four teeth that are between the OanoyaAb and the OaDoraAs: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or any one of the teeth that are in front of the OaDoraAs that appear on the occasion of laughing: (Ḳ:) pl. DawaAHiku. (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) OawDaHuwA biDaAHikapK (O, TA,) a phrase occurring in a trad., (O,) means † They smiled. (TA.)

OuDoHuwkapN [A laughable thing;] a thing at which one laughs: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and maDoHakapN↓ signifies [in like manner a cause of laughter;] a thing at which one laughs, or which one ridicules: pl. of the former OaDaAHiyku. (TA.) [See also muDoHikaAtN.]

[maDoHakN lit. A place of laughing: the front teeth; because they appear in laughing; like mabosimN: pl. maDaAHiku.] One says, badato maDaAHikuhu and DuHokatuhu↓ and [in like manner] mabaAsimuhu † [His front teeth appeared, by his laughing]. (TA.)
maDoHakapN: see OuDoHuwkapN.
muDoHikaAtN [pl. of muDoHikapN] i. q. nawaAdiru [as meaning Extraordinary things or sayings, particularly such as cause laughter: see also OuDoHuwkapN]. (TA.)
miDoHaAkN: see DuHakapN.

1. DaHala, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDoHalu}, (Ḳ,) said of water, It was, or became, shallow, (O, Ḳ, TA,) and little in quantity. (TA.) And said of a pool of water left by a torrent, Its water became little in quantity. (Ḳ.)
4. maA OaDoHala xayoraka means maA Oaqal-ahu [i. e. † How little, or scanty, is thy goodness, or bounty, or beneficence!]. (TA.)

Q. Q. 4. AiDomaHal-a, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) mentioned in the Ḳ in a separate art., its author, and some others, holding the m to be radical, but most of the leading authorities on inflection hold it, with J [and Ṣgh and Fei], to be augmentative; (TA;) and AimoDaHal-a, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the dial. of the Kilá- bees, mentioned by AZ, formed by transposition of the m; (Ṣ, O, TA;) and AimoDaHan-a, (Ḳ,) formed by substitution, mentioned by Yaạḳoob; (TA;) It (a thing, Ṣ, O) went away; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and came to nought. (Mṣb.)
And said of clouds (saHaAb), They became removed, or cleared off. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And i. q. AinoHal-a [It became untied, or undone,, &c.]. (Ḳ.)

DaHolN A small quantity of water, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) upon the ground, (M, Ḳ,) shallow, (M,) not deep; (Ḳ;) i. q. DaHoDaAHN; (Ṣ, O;) or the latter has a more general meaning, applying to little or much: (TA:) accord. to some, such that the bottom of it appears: (MF, TA:) or a small quantity of water in a source, or fountain, and in a well, and in a hot spring, and the like; or in a pool left by a torrent, and the like: or water little in quantity; or near in place: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaDoHaAlN and [of mult.] DuHuwlN and DiHaAlN. (Ḳ.)

Hence, (Ṣ, O,) OataAnu AlD-aHoli (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) i. e. A mass of rock of which part is covered by the water and part is protruding; (O;) expl. [more fully and variously] in art. Atn; (Ḳ;) so called because the water does not cover it by reason of its paucity. (Ṣ, O.)
[Hence also,] one says, Uin-a xayoraka laDaHolN i. e. [† Verily thy goodness, or bounty, or beneficence, is] little. (TA.)
gadiyrN DaAHilN A pool, left by a torrent, the water of which has become shallow and has then gone away. (Sh, TA.)

maDoHalN The place of a DaHol: (M, TA:) or a place in which is little water: (O, Ḳ:) the mirage (saraAb) is likened thereto: (TA:) pl. maDaAHilu; (O, TA;) to which Ru-beh, (O,) or El-ʼAjjáj, (TA,) likens clouds. (O,* TA.)

1. DaHaA AlT-ariyqu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaDoHuw, (Ṣ,) inf. n. DaHowN, (Ṣ, and so in the CK,) or DuHuw-N, (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) like Euluw-N, thus accord. to ISd and IḲṭṭ, (TA,) and DuHiI-N, (TA as from the Ḳ, [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,]) The road appeared, or became apparent, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) to a person: so says AZ: (Ṣ:) [and so, app., signifies DaHiIa, aor. yaDoHaI; for] Aṣ says, yusotaHab-u mina Alfarasi Oano yaDoHaI EijaAnuhu i. e. [It is approved as a quality of the horse] that his EjAn [q. v., a word variously expl.,] appear. (Ṣ, TA.)
DaHiyati All-yolapu The night was, or became, cloudless. (TA.)
DaHiIa Alfarasa The horse was, or became, white. (TA.)
Zil-uhu DaHaA ‡ He died: (Ḳ, TA:) it [properly] means his shade, or shadow, became sun: and when a man's shade, or shadow, becomes sun, he himself becomes nought. (IAmb, TA.)

And DaHaA and DaHiIa, aor. of each yaDoHaI, inf. n. DaHowN, (Ḳ, TA,) or, accord. to the M, DuHuw-N, (TA,) and DuHiI-N, He, or it, was smitten by the sun; or the sun came, or fell, upon him, or it: (Ḳ, TA:) or DaHiIa, aor. yaDoHaI, inf. n. DaHFA; and DaHaA, aor. yaDoHuw, inf. n. DaHowN and DuHuw-N, he, or it, was smitten by the heat of the sun. (Ḥam p. 625.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xx. 117], laA taZomaOu fiyhaA walaA taDoHaI [Thou shalt not thirst. therein nor shalt thou be smitten by the sun]; i. e., thou shalt be preserved from the heat of the sun. (TA.)

And DaHaA, inf. n. DaHowN and DuHuw-N and DuHiI-N, He went forth to the sunshine; (Ḳ;) as also AstDHI↓ lilX-amosi; (TA;) [and app. tDH-I↓ also; see Ḥar p. 296, where, for Alnzwl, in Alnzwl llXms as an explanation of Alt-aDaH-iI, I think we should read Alburuwzu:] or DaHiytu lilX-amosi, inf. n. DaHaMCN; and DaHayotu also; aor. of each OaDoHaI; I went forth to the sunshine. (Ṣ.) OaDoHi [the imperative of OaDoHaI↓] occurs in a trad., accord. to the relaters thereof: but Aṣ says that it is [correctly] AiDoHa, with kesr to the A and fet-ḥ to the H; from DaHiytu; being a command to go forth to the sunshine. (Ṣ.)
And DaHiIa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaHFI [or DaHFA], He (a man, Ṣ) sweated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 2. DaH-ayonaAhumo is like Sab-aHonaAhumo [i. e. it signifies We came to them in the time of the morning called AlD-uHaI]: (TA:) and DAHAhu↓, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. muDaAHaApN, is similar to gaAdaAhu and raAwaHahu, meaning, (TA,) He came to him in the time called AlD-uHaI. (Ḳ, TA.)

DH-I Alganama He pastured the sheep, or goats, in the time called AlD-uHaI; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and in like manner, AlUibila the camels. (TA.) And DaH-ayotu AlUibila Eani Alwirodi I pastured the camels with the [morning-pasture called] DaHaMC↓, so that they might come to the water having satisfied themselves with food: and in like manner, EaX-ayotuhaA Eanohu “I pastured them with the [evening-pasture called] EaXaMC,”, &c. (A, TA.)

[Hence,] DaH-ayotuhu, inf. n. taDoHiyapN, I fed him in the time called AlD-uHaI: (Ḳ, TA:) or I fed him with the [morning-meal called] gadaMC, at any time [of the morning]; but more commonly known as meaning, in the time called AlD-uHaI: and the verb primarily relates to camels [and sheep or goats]: or DH-I qawomahu means he fed his people, or party, with the [morning-meal called] gadaMC; or he invited them [thereto, i. e.] to his DaHaMC. (TA.)

IAth says, when the Arabs, in their journeying, or migrating, passed by a piece of land in which was herbage, one of them said, OalaA DaH-uwA ruwayodFA, meaning [Now] be ye gentle with the camels Hat-aI nataDaH-aI↓ i. e. in order that we may obtain of this herbage; then Alt-aDoHiyapu was applied to mean the being gentle in order that the camels may reach the place of alighting [app. in the morning] having satisfied themselves with food: and then taDaH-aI↓ was said of anyone as meaning he ate in the time called [AlD-uHaI or] AlD-aHaMC. (TA.) One says, DaH-ayotu Eani AlX-aIoCi † I was gentle, or I acted gently, with the thing. (Ṣ.) And DH-I Eani AlOamori ‡ He acted gently, or deliberately, in the affair: and so EaX-aI Eanohu. (A, TA.) And DaH-i ruwayodFA, (Ṣ, A, TA,) a prov., (A, TA,) meaning ‡ Hasten thou not; (Ṣ, TA;) from taDoHiyapu AlUibili Eani Alwirodi: [see the third sentence of this paragraph:] or meaning be thou patient a little while: (TA:) or the meaning is, slaughter thou, or sacrifice thou, [deliberately, leisurely, or] without haste: (Meyd:) [for]

DH-I, inf. n. taDoHyapN, signifies [also] He slaughtered, or sacrificed, the [victim termed] OuDoHiy-ap, in the time called AlD-uHaI: and hence, by reason of frequency of usage, he did so in any time of what are termed Oay-aAmu Alt-aXoriyqi: (Mṣb:) and DH-I biXaApK, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or bikaboXK Oawo gayorihi, (Mgh,) he slaughtered, or sacrificed, a sheep or goat, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or a ram or other [victim], (Mgh,) in the time called AlD-uHaI (Mgh, Ḳ) of the day called yawomu AlOaDoHaI; and afterwards said of him who has done so [at any time, even] in the last part of the [said] day. (Mgh.)
See also 4.
And see 5.
3. DAHt Albiladu The countries, or lands, became exposed to the sun, and their herbage consequently dried up. (TA.)
DAHAhu: see 2, first sentence.

4. ADHI He (a man, TA) entered upon the time of morning called AlD-uHaI, (Ḳ,* TA,) or the time called AlD-aHowap, (TA,) [or the time called AlD-aHaMC, for] you say, Oaqamotu biAlmakaAni Hat-aI OaDoHayotu, from AlD-aHaMCu [and therefore meaning I remained in the place until I entered upon the time called AlD-aHaMC], like as you say OaSobaHotu from AlS-abaAHu. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence the saying of ʼOmar, OaDoHuwA liSalaApi AlD-uHaI, (Ṣ,) or biSalaApi AlD-uHaI, (TA,) i. e. Perform ye the prayer of the time called AlDHI at its [proper] time: do not delay it until the time called AlD-aHaMC has become advanced: (TA:) or do not perform that prayer when the time called AlD-uHaI has become advanced. (Ṣ.)

And you say, ADHI fulaAnN yafoEalu kacaA, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) like as you say Zal-a yfEl kcA; (Ṣ;) meaning Such a one became occupied, or engaged, in the time called AlD-uHaI in doing such a thing: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or did such a thing in the first part of the day, (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

[This phrase often means also Such a one became occupied, or engaged, in doing such a thing; betook, set, or applied, himself to doing such a thing; set about, or commenced, doing such a thing; or began to do such a thing; like OaSobaHa and Zal-a, &c. And, like these verbs, ADHI followed by an aor., or by a part. n. in the accus. case, often requires to be rendered simply He, or it, became: see an ex. in a verse cited voce dafiYN.]
ADHI also signifies He performed the supererogatory act of prayer (Aln-aAfilap) in the time called AlD-uHaI. (TA.)
See also 1, last sentence but one.

One says also, ADHI Eani AlOamori, meaning ‡ He withdrew himself far from the affair. (TA. [See also another meaning of this phrase in what follows.]) And AlqaTA yuDoHiI Eani AlmaMCi ‡ The birds called qTA go far from water. (TA.)

ADHI AlX-aIoCa He made apparent, showed, or revealed, the thing. (Ḳ, TA.) And DH-I↓ Eani AlOamori He made the affair, or case, apparent, or manifest: and [so ADHI Eanohu, for] one says, OaDoHi liI Eano Oamorika, with fet-ḥ to the C, meaning Make manifest to me thy affair, or case: so in the M. (TA.)

laA OaDoHaI Qll-ehu lanaA Zil-aka is a deprecatory phrase [lit. May God not cause thy shadow to become sun to us: meaning † may God not deprive us of thee by death: (see DaHaA Zil-uhu:) or it may be similar in meaning to the phrase here following]. (TA.) laA tuDoHinaA Eano Zil-ika [lit. Make us not to go forth into the sun from thy shadow] means † withdraw not from us the shadow of thy compassion: the verb being made trans. by means of En because the phrase implies the meaning of laA tuxorijonaA minohu: and Zl- being here used metaphorically. (Ḥar p. 4.)

entry.sense: 5. taDH-I: see 1, latter half.

And see 2, in two places. It [generally] means He ate in the time of morning called AlD-uHaI: (Ḳ:) or he ate the [morning-meal called] gadaMC; syn. tagad-aI: (Ṣ, TA:) and DH-I↓ also has the former [or the latter] meaning. (ISd, TA.)
10: see 1, latter half.
DaHowN: see the next paragraph.

DuHFI, also written DuHFA, held by some to be of the measure fuEalN, and by others to be [originally DuHowFI i. e.] of the measure fuEolFI, of the former measure accord. to Mbr, and of the latter accord. to Th, (MF, TA,) [The early part of the forenoon, after sunrise: accord. to some, when the sun is yet low: accord. to others, when the sun is somewhat high:] i. q. DaHowapN↓, accord. to most authorities: (MF, TA, and so in one place in the Ḳ:) or this latter signifies the period of the day after sunrise: (Ṣ:) or this signifies the advanced state of the day (AirotifaAEu Aln-ahaAri [which is said by the doctors of the law in the present day to mean when the sun has risen the measure of a rumoH, q. v., or more]); as also DaHowN↓ and DaHiy-apN↓: (Ḳ:) and the DuHaI is after the DaHowap (Ṣ, Ḳ) a little, (Ḳ,) when the sun shines brightly: (Ṣ:) or from sunrise to the time when the day is advanced and very white: thus in the M: (TA:) or it is the spreading of the sun [upon the earth], and the extending of the day: and the time [thereof] is thus named: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or DuHFI is pl. of DaHowapN↓, like as qurFI is of qaroyapN; and its sing. is like DaHaMCN↓, which means the extending of the day, and is of the masc. gender, as though a name of the time [thereof]: then DuHFI became used as a sing., and the time was thus called: (Mṣb:) it is fem. and masc.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:*) he who makes it fem. holds it to be pl. of DaHowapN↓; and he who makes it masc. holds it to be [a sing.] noun of the measure fuEalN, like SuradN and nugarN: (Ṣ:) its dim. is DuHaI-N↓, without p; (Fr, Mṣb, Ḳ;) for they disapproved the affixing the p lest it should be confounded with the dim. of DaHowapN. (Fr, Mṣb.) Using it as an adv. noun, you say, laqiytuhu DuHaI, when you mean [I met him] in the DHI of this day; without tenween. (Ṣ, TA.) See also DaHowapN. [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 162-167, respecting the prayer that is performed in the time thus called, i. e. the prayer termed SalaApu AlD-uHaI, mentioned above, voce OaDoHaI.]
Also The sun: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) because of its appearing in the time thus called. (M, TA.) One says, AirotafaEati AlD-aHaI, meaning The sun became high. (Mṣb.)
And DuHaI AlX-amosi The light of the sun: thus is expl. xci. 1. of the Ḳur. (TA.)

maA likalaAmihi DuHFI means † His speech, or language, has no perspicuity: thus in the M and Ḳ: but in the A, OanoXadaniI XaEorFA layosa fiyhi HalaAwapN walaA DaHaMCN↓ i. e. [He recited to me poetry] in which was no [sweetness nor] plainness of meaning. (TA.)

DaHowapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places. You say, Oatayotuka DaHowapF, meaning [I came to thee] in a [time called] DuHFI↓ [or rather DaHowap], (Ḳ,* TA,) with tenween, unless you mean of this day [in which case you say DaHowapN, without tenween, like as you say in the latter case DuHaI]. (TA.)
DaHoyaA and DaHoyaMCu fems. of OaDoHaI [q. v.].

DaHoyaAnN, which should by rule be DaHowaAnN, Anything exposing itself, or being exposed, to the sun. (IJ, TA.) qul-apN DaHoyaAnapN means [A mountain-top] exposed to the sun: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) occurring in a saying of Taäbbata-sharrà. (Ṣ.) And EaSFA DaHoyaAnapN A staff, or stick, growing in the sun so as to be matured thereby, and extremely hard. (TA.)
See also OaDoHaI.
Also A man who eats in the time called AlD-uHaI: fem. with p {DaHoyaAnapN}. (Ḳ.)

DaHaMCN, with medd, (Ṣ, Hr, Mṣb, TA,) and fet-ḥ, (Hr, Mṣb, TA, [erroneously written in copies of the Ḳ with damm,]) The period [of the forenoon] next after that called AlD-uHaI; i. e. when the day is at the highest: (Ṣ:) or the period near midday: (Ḳ:) or the period of the day when the sun has risen to the fourth part of the sky: (TA:) see also DuHFI, in two places.
And hence, The [morning-meal called] gadaMC; because it is eaten in the time thus called. (Ṣ, TA.) [And also applied to Pasture eaten in that time:] see 2, third sentence.
DuHaI-N dim. of DuHFI, q. v. (Fr, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: DaHiy-apN: see DuHFI:
and see also OuDoHiy-apN.

entry.sense: DaAHK [part. n. of 1, Appearing, &c.]
You say makaAnN DAHK An outer, exterior, or exposed, place: (Ṣ:) and OaroDN DaAHiyapN Land not surrounded by a wall. (TA in art. HwT.) [And particularly A place exposed to the sun.]

[Hence,] mafaAzapN DaAHiyapu AlZ-il-i [A desert, or waterless desert,] having no shade or shadow; and DaAHiyapu AlZ-ilaAli [having no shades or shadows]. (TA.) And XajarapN DaAHiyapN biAlZ-il-i [if not a mistake for DaAHiyapu AlZ-il-i] A tree having no shade. (Ḥar p. 4.)
And badaA biDaAHiI raOosihi [He appeared with, or he showed,] the side of his head. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

DaAHiyapN An outer, exterior, or exposed, side or region or tract of anything: [pl. DawaAHK: whence] one says, humo yanoziluwna AlD-awaAHiIa [They alight, or abide, in the exterior tracts]. (Ṣ.) [Hence also,] DawaAHiI Alr-uwmi The exterior districts of the Greeks. (Ḳ.) And AlD-aAHiyapu mina AlbaEoli What are in the open country, of the palm-trees that imbibe with their roots, without being watered: opposed to AlD-aAminapu mina Aln-axoli: (AO, Ṣ in this art. and in art. Dmn, q. v.:) and AlD-awaAHiI mina Aln-axoli what are outside of the town-wall, of the palm-trees: thus used, AlDwAHI is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) And DawaAHiI qurayoXK Those [of Kureysh] who abide outside of Mekkeh. (TA.) And huwa mino Oaholi AlD-aAHiyapi He is of the people of the desert. (TA.) AlD-awaAHiI also signifies The parts, of a man, that stand out, or are exposed, (Ḳ, TA,) to the sun, (TA,) such as the shoulder-blades, and the shoulders: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of DaAHiyapN. (TA.) And The sides of a watering-trough. (Ḳ.) And The heavens. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[Hence also,] faEalahu DaAHiyapF He did it openly. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
DaAHiyapu AlmaAli means The cattle, (Ḳ,) or sheep or goats, (TA,) that drink in the time of morning called DuHFI. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: OaDoHaI, applied to a horse, i. q. OaXohabu [Of a colour in which whiteness predominates over blackness;, &c.]: fem. DaHoyaMCu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or AlD-aHoyaMCu was, (Ḳ,) or was also, (Ṣ, and so afterwards in the Ḳ,) the name of a certain mare, belonging to ʼAmr Ibn-'Ámir (Ṣ, Ḳ) Ibn-Rabee'ah. (Ṣ.)

And layolapN DaHoyaMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and DaHoyaA with the short A, both mentioned by ISd, (TA,) and UiDoHiyaAnapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and UiDoHiyapN↓ accord. to the Ḳ, but [SM says] I have not found any mention of this last, [meaning except in the Ḳ,] and probably the right word is UiDHiyaAnN↓, as in the books of strange words together with UiDoHiyaAnapN, and accord. to the “Irtisháf ed-Darab” of AḤei one says [also] OaDoHiyaAnN↓ with fet-ḥ, (TA,) A bright night, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in which are no clouds: (Ṣ, TA:) and in like manner, yawomN UiDoHiyaAnN↓, in the Ḳ, erroneously, DaHoyaApN, a bright day, in which are no clouds, as in the M; or bright with the brightness of the DuHaI, accord. to Er-Rághib; or [simply] bright, and so DaHoyaAnN↓, which is likewise applied in this sense to a moon, as also UiDoHiyaAnN↓, and to a lamp, or its lighted wick. (TA.)
And AimoraOapN DaHoyaMCu A woman whose hair of her EaAnap will not grow forth; (Ḳ, TA;) as though her EAnp, being bare of hair, had no shade upon it. (TA.)
maA OadoriI OaI-u AlD-aHoyaMCi huwa is a saying mentioned by Az in art. ThI as meaning I know not what one of mankind, or of the people, he is. (TA.)

OaDoHFI [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is OaDoHaApN]: see OuDoHiy-apN. Hence, yawomu AlOaDoHaI [The day of the victims; which is the tenth of Dhu-l- Hijjeh]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,* TA;) so says Yaạḳoob; (TA;) or Eiydu AlOaDoHaI [the festival of the victims]: (Mṣb:) and by AlOaDoHaI when it is made masc. is meant that day. (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: UiDoHiyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
UiDoHiyaAnN and OaDoHiyaAnN, and the former with p {UiDoHiyaAnapN}: see OaDoHaI, in five places.
AlUiDoHiyaAnu is also the name of A certain plant, (Ḳ, TA,) resembling the OuqoHuwaAn [or chamomile] in appearance. (TA.)

OuDoHiy-apN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure OufoEuwlapN [as though originally OuDoHuwyapN], (Mṣb,) and UiDoHiy-apN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) pl. [of each] OaDAHiI-u; and DaHiy-apN↓, of which the pl. is DaHaAyaA; and OaDoHaApN, of which the pl. is OaDoHFI↓, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, [in copies of the Ḳ and in my copy of the Mgh written OaDoHaI, but it is properly speaking a coll. gen. n. of which OaDoHaApN is the n. un., and is therefore with tenween,]) like OaroTaApN and OaroTFI; (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;*) A sheep or goat (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL), &c. [i. e. meaning also a camel and a bull or cow] (KL) that is slaughtered, or sacrificed, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) in the time called AlD-uHaI, (Ḳ,) on the day called yawomu AlOaDoHaI [the day of the victims, which is the tenth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh]. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* KL.)
OaroDN maDoHaApN A land from which the sun is hardly, or never, absent; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. an exposed land. (TA.)
muDoTaHK and mutaDaH-K↓ and musotaDoHK↓ A man entering upon the time of morning called AlD-uHaI. (Ḳ,* TA.)
mutaDaH-K: see what next precedes.
musotaDoHK: see what next precedes.

1. Daxuma, [aor. _u {yaDoxumu},] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DixamN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) accord. to the copies of the Ḳ DaxomN, but this is wrong, (TA,) and DaxaAmapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It, or he, was, or became, large, big, bulky, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) or thick: (Ṣ:) or large in body, portly, or corpulent, and fleshy. (Ḳ.)
4. ADxm lahu (Ibn-ʼAbbád and Ḳ * voce Oadolafa) [i. q. OagolaZa lahu] † He spoke to him in a rough, harsh, coarse, rude, uncivil, or ungentle, manner. (TḲ in art. dlf.)

DaxomN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DaxamN↓ (Ḳ) and DuxaAmN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaDoxamu↓, (Ḳ,) which last is also with teshdeed of the final letter, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. ODoxam-u↓, in poetry, (Ṣ, TA,) for there is no word [properly] of the measure OafoEal-u, and IJ mentions [evidently in the same sense,] like Uirodab-N [in measure], (TA,) Large, big, bulky, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) or thick; (Ṣ;) applied to a thing (Mṣb, Ḳ) of any kind: (Ḳ:) or large in body, portly, or corpulent, and fleshy: (Ḳ:) pl. DxaAmN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) like sihaAmN pl. of sahomN: (Mṣb:) fem. DaxomapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) applied to a woman; (Mṣb;) pl. DaxomaAtN, with the x quiescent, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) because it is an epithet. (Ṣ.) See also miDoxamN.

It was said to a man, Uin-a laka laxayorN [app. meaning “Verily thou hast wealth”]; and he replied, Oajalo xayorN Daxomu AlEunuqi [app., ‡ Yea, large wealth]; which is tropical. (TA.) And one says, lahu suwdadN DaxomN † [He has great lordship or dignity], and XarafN DaxomN [great nobility], and XaOonN aDaxomN [great importance or rank]. (TA.)
DaxomN applied to a road means ‡ Wide. (Ḳ, TA.)
And applied to water, ‡ Heavy. (Ḳ, TA.)
DaxamN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Dixam-apN, applied to a woman, ‡ Very wide, or wide and fat, (EariyDapN OariyDapN,) and soft, or tender. (Ḳ, TA.)
DuxaAmN: see DaxomN.
OaDoxamu: see DaxomN.
One says [also], hecaA OaDoxamu minohu [This is larger, bigger,, &c., than it, or he]. (Ṣ.)
OaDoxam-u and UiDoxam-N: see DaxomN.
OuDoxuwmapN A woman's EiZaAmap [or thing resembling a pillow], (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) with which she makes herself [to appear] large behind her waist [or posteriors]. (TA.)
miDoxamN, as an epithet applied to a chief, or lord, ‡ Noble, and portly, or corpulent; (Ḳ, TA;) as also DaxomN↓. (TA.)
And, applied to a man, (TA,) ‡ Vehement in dashing himself against another; and in striking, or beating. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Dad-ahu, (AZ, Ḳ,) first pers. Dadadotuhu, [aor. _u {yaDodudu},] inf. n. Dad-N, He overcame him: (AZ, L:) and also, (AZ, L,) or Dad-ahu fiI AlxuSuwmapi, (Ḳ,) He overcame him in litigation, altercation, or contention. (AZ, L, Ḳ.)

And Dad-ahu Eanohu He averted him; turned him, or sent him, away, or back; or caused him to return, or go back, or revert; from it: (L, Ḳ:) i. e., a thing, or an affair: (L:) and prevented, or hindered, him from doing it; (Ḳ;) by gentle means: (L, Ḳ:) as also Sad-ahu: heard by Aboo-Turáb from Záïdeh. (L.)
Dad-a Alqirobapi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yaDodudu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. Dad-N, (AA, Ṣ,) He filled the water-skin. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. DAd-hu, (inf. n. muDaAd-apN, Mṣb,) He, or it, was, or became, contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him, or it; (AHeyth, Ṣ,* L, Ḳ;) said with respect to two men when one desires what is long, and the other, what is short; or one, darkness, and the other, light; or one, to pursue one course, and the other, to pursue another: (AHeyth, L:) or he, or it, was, or became, separated from him, or it, by contrariety, opposition, or repugnance: (Mṣb:) [or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd-aAni in the Mṣb, it was, or became inconsistent with it.]
4. ADd- He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, angry. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is not, as some assert it to be, a quasi-pass. [of Dad-ahu], like as Oakab-a is of kab-ahu. (TA.)

6. tDAd-A [They two were, or became, contrary, opposed, or repugnant, each to the other: or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd-aAni in the Mṣb, they two were, or became, inconsistent, each with the other.]

Did-N (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DadiydN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and DadiydapN↓ (Th, M) The contrary, or opposite, (AA, IAạr, Ṣ,* M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing: (AA, Mṣb:) or Did-u XaIoCK signifies that which is repugnant to a thing, so that it would overcome it; as black is to white, and death to life: (Lth, L:) [or, accord. to the explanation of mutaDaAd-aAni in the Mṣb, that which is inconsistent with a thing:] pl. of the first OaDadaAdN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, &c.) One says also, huwa Did-uka and Dadiyduka↓ He is contrary, or opposed, or repugnant, to thee; as when thou desirest what is long, and he, what is short; or thou, darkness, and he, light; or thou, to pursue one course, and he, to pursue another. (AHeyth, L.) And Did-N is sometimes a pl., (Ḳ,) or sometimes denotes a collective body; (Akh, Ṣ, L;) as in the phrase yakuwnuwna Ealayohimo Did-FA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [xix. 85], (Ṣ, L,) meaning They shall be adversaries, or enemies, to them: (ʼIkrimeh, Jel:) or helpers against them. (Fr, Jel.) One says also, Alqawomu EalaI-a Did-N waAHidN, meaning The people are assembled together against me in contention, or altercation, with me. (L.)

Did-N in lexicology signifies A kind of muXotarak [or homonym]; being a word that has two contrary meanings; as jawonN, which means both “black” and “white;” and jalalN, which means both “great” and “small” pl. as above. (Mz, 26th nwE.) [Did-N is itself a word of this kind, as is shown by what here follows.]

Also, (AA, Th, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and DadiydN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) The like, or equal, (AA, Th, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing. (AA, Mṣb.) Thus they have two contrary meanings. (Ḳ.) One says, laA Did-a lahu and laA Dadiyda↓ lahu There is no like, or equal, to him, or it. (Ṣ, L.) And laqiIa Alqawomu OaDodaAdahumo The people, or party, found, or met, their equals, or fellows. (L.)
DadadN: see DaAd-N.
DadiydN: see Dad-N, in four places.
DadiydapN: see Did-N, first sentence.
DaAd-N, or DaAdidN↓ and DadadN↓ One who fills vessels for people when they seek, or demand, water: pl. DudadN, [which is anomalous,] on the authority of AA. (L.)
DaAdidN: see what next precedes.
humaA mutaDaAd-aAni They two are contrary, opposed, or repugnant, each to the other: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:) or they two are inconsistent; or such as cannot be, or exist, together; as night and day. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. Dar-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Dar-a bihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaDoruru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. Dar-N; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and DAr-hu↓, [which see also below,] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muDaAr-apN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and DiraArN; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and ADr-hu↓, (Ḳ,) or ADr-↓ bihi, (Mṣb,) or both, inf. n. UiDoraArN; (TA;) He, or it, harmed, injured, hurt, marred, mischiefed, or damaged, him, or it; contr. of nafaEahu; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) did to him, or it, an act that was evil, or disliked, or hated. (Mṣb.)
Dar-ahu Uilayohi: see 8.

laA yaDur-aka Ealayohi jamalN ‡ No camel will be more sufficient for thee than he; syn. laA yaziyduka: and laA yaDur-uka Ealayohi rajulN ‡ [No man will be more sufficient for thee than he; or] thou wilt not find a man who will be more sufficient for thee than he; i. e. laA tajidu rajulFA yaziyduka EalaI maA Einoda hecaA Alr-ajuli mina AlkifaAyapi: (ISk, Ṣ:) and maA yaDur-uka EalaI AlD-ab-i SayodN ‡ No animal that is hunted is more sufficient for thee than the Dab-; and so maA yaDiyruka: and maA taDur-uka EalayohaA jaAriyapN ‡ No girl, or young woman, is more sufficient for thee than she; syn. maA taziyduka: (A:) and maA yaDur-uka Ealayohi XayoYFA ‡ He, or it, is not at all more sufficient for thee than he, or it; syn. maA yaziyduka. (IAạr, TA.)
Dar-a, [sec. pers. app. Darurota, and aor. yaDur-u,] inf. n. DaraArapN, † He was, or became, blind: part. n. DariyrN [q. v.]. (MA.)

entry.sense: 3. DAr-hu, inf. n. muDaAr-apN and DaraArN, He harmed him, injured him, or hurt him, in return, or in requital: whence the saying in a trad., lA Darara walaA DiraAra fiI AlUisolaAmi There shall be no harming, injuring, or hurting, of one man by another, in the first instance, nor in return, or requital, in El-Islám: (Mgh, TA:*) DiraArN is syn. with muDaAr-apN: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to some, it is syn. with DararN; and in the phrase in a trad. mentioned above, is added as a corroborative. (TA.) See also 1. muDaAr-apN in the case of a testament is the not executing it; or the violating it in part; or the bequeathing to any unfit person or persons; and the like; contrary to the sun-ap. (TA.)

He disagreed with, or differed from, him; dissented from him; was contrary, opposed, or repugnant, to him; or he acted contrarily, contrariously, adversely, or in opposition, to him; syn. xAlafahu. (Ḳ.) And hence, accord. to some, the saying in a trad., (O, Ḳ,) relating to the seeing God on the day of resurrection, (O,) laA tuDaAr-uwna fiI ruWoyatihi, (O, Ḳ,) i. e. Ye will not differ, one from another, nor dispute together, respecting the truth of the seeing Him; (Zj, O,* TA;) because of his manifest appearance: (Zj, TA:) or the meaning is, laA tuDaAm-uwna, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and thus some relate it, (TA,) meaning ye will not draw yourselves together, (Ḳ, TA,) and straiten one another; one saying to another “Show me Him,” like as people do in looking at the new moon, but each will by himself have the sight of Him: (TA:) or, as some say, it is laA taDaAr-uwna↓ [originally tataDaAr-uwna], meaning laA taDaAm-uwna, [which is the same in signification as laA tuDaAm-uwna], i. e. with fet-ḥ to the t: (TA, and so in one of my copies of the Ṣ:)
and some say, lA tuDaAruwna, from AlD-ayoru; (Mgh, TA;) [i. e. ye will not be hurt;] meaning ye will not hurt one another: (M in art. Dyr:) and some, laA tuDaAmuwn, from AlD-ayomu. (Mgh, TA.)
See also 4; and the phrase tazaw-aja EalaI muDaAr-apK, voce Dir-N.

hom.sense: 4. ADr-hu and ADr-bihi: see 1, first sentence.
ADr-hu EalaI AlOamori He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) [See also 8.]

ADr-, intrans., ‡ It (anything) approached so near as to harm, injure, or hurt; (TA;) or so near as to straighten, or incommode. (L.) You say, ADr- bihi, meaning ‡ It approached very near to him, so as to annoy him: (TA, from a trad.:) or ‡ he drew very near to him: (Ṣ, A:) or ‡ he clave, or stuck, to him. (A.) And ADr- biAlT-ariyq ‡ He approached the road, but was not upon it. (TA.) And banuw fulaAnK yuDir-u AlT-ariyqu ‡ The sons of such a one are one the travelled track. (A.) And ADr- Als-ayolu mina AlHaAYiTi † The torrent drew near to the wall: and Als-aHaAbu UilaI AlOaroDi the clouds to the earth. (Ḳ.)
ADr- Ealayohi ‡ He importuned him; plied him; plied him hard; pressed him; pressed him hard; was urgent with him; persecuted him, or harassed him. (A.)
ADr- Alfarasu EalaI faOosi All-ijaAmi ‡ The horse champed the fOs [q. v.] of the bit; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A;) and so ADz-. (Ṣ.)
ADr- fulaAnN EalaI Als-ayori AlX-adiydi † Such a one bore patiently hard journeying. (TA.)

Also, (Mṣb,) inf. n. UiDoraArN, (Ṣ,) He took to himself a wife while having another wife: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) [and so, app., DAr-↓: (see Dir-N:)] or he gave [a woman] in marriage to a man having at the time another wife. (TA.)
ADr- yaEoduw (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA) signifies He hastened (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) somewhat in running, accord. to AʼObeyd; (Ṣ, TA;) but Et-Toosee says that this is a mistake, and that it is correctly ASr-. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tDr-r He was [harmed, injured, or hurt; or] afflicted, grieved, or sick: and he experienced straitness, pressure, or inconvenience. (KL.)
6. laA taDaAr-uwna [originally tataDaAr-uwna]: see 3.

8. ADTr-hu UilaI kacaA It, (a thing, or an affair, TA,) or he, [a man, or God,] necessitated, constrained, compelled, forced, or drove, him to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing; or impelled, or drove, him, against his will, to it, or to do it; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) so that he had no means of avoiding it; as also Dar-ahu↓ Uilayohi: (Mṣb:) it made him to want, or be in need of, such a thing: (Ḳ, TA:) from DararN signifying “narrowness,” or “straitness.” (TA.) [See also 4. Hence the phrase, laOaDoTar-an-aka UilaI OaSolika, expl. in art. ASl. See also the Ḳur ii. 120, and xxxi. 23.]

AuDoTur-a UilaI kacaA He was, or became, necessitated, constrained, compelled, forced, or driven, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing; or was impelled, or driven, against his will, to it, or to do it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he wanted, or was or became in need of, such a thing. (Ḳ.)
Dar-N: see the next paragraph, in two places.

hom.sense: Dur-N Harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage; contr. of nafoEN; as also Dar-N↓, (A, Ḳ,) or this is an inf. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the former is a simple subst.; (ADk, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and DararN↓ [which is now the most common]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) or an evil state or condition; (ADk, T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DararN↓ and taDir-apN↓ and taDur-apN↓; (Ḳ; for the right reading in the Ḳ is wAlD-araru suwoCu AlHaAli, as in the L, &c.; not wAlDrr wswC AlHAl; TA; [but in some of the copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA, this signification is assigned to Dar-N instead of Dur-N; and in the latter, its pl. is said to be OaDur-N;]) and poverty; and bodily affliction: but the contr. of nafoEN is termed Dar-N↓, with fet-ḥ: (ADk, T, Mṣb, TA:*) [see also Dar-apN and DararN and Dar-aMCu and DaruwrapN and DaAruwraMCu, all of which have similar meanings:] and disease; (A, Mṣb;) thus in the Ḳur xxi. 83: (Mṣb:) or leanness: (Ṣ, A, TA:) the state, or condition, of him who is termed Dariyr [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

Dar-N The taking a wife in addition to another wife; (Ṣ;) a subst. from Dar-apN. (Ḳ.) You say, nukiHati AlmaroOapu EalaI Dir-K The woman was taken to wife in addition to a former wife. (Ṣ.) And, accord. to Aboo-ʼAbd-Allah Et-Tuwál, tazaw-ajotu AlmaroOapa EalaI Dir-K and Dur-K↓ [I took the woman to wife in addition to another wife]. (Ṣ.) And tazaw-aja EalaI Dir-K and Dur-K↓ i. e. muDaAr-apK↓, meaning He married so as to have two or three wives together. (Ḳ.) And Kr mentions the phrase, tazaw-ajotu AlmaroOapa EalaI Dir-K kun-a lahaA [I took to wife the woman in addition to others who were her fellow-wives]: and if it be so, Dir- is an inf. n. [used in this instance as an epithet, and therefore applicable to a pl. number as well as to a single person], formed by the rejection of the augmentative letter [in its verb, i. e. OaDar-a], or it is a pl. that has no sing. (TA.)

One says also rajulN Dir-u OaDoraArK (Ḳ, TA) i. e. A man [who is] a strong one of strong ones; like as one says Sil-u OaSolaAlK and Dil-u OaDolaAlK: (TA:) or very cunning (daAhiyapN) in his judgment, or opinion. (Ḳ, TA.)

Dar-apN [Necessity, or need;] a subst. from 8: (Ḳ, TA:) hardness, distressfulness, or afflictiveness, of state or condition: and annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) See also [Dur-N, and] DararN, and Dar-aMCu, and DaruwrapN.

A woman's husband's wife; her fellow-wife: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) an appellation disliked by the Muslim; jaArapN being used in preference to it; accord. to a trad.: (TA:) pl. DaraAYiru (Mṣb, Ḳ) and Dar-aAtN; (Mṣb;) the former extr. [with respect to rule]; (TA;) the latter regular. (Mṣb.) [See also Eal-apN.]
Hence, sing. of DaraAYiru signifying ‡ Discordant things or affairs; likened to fellow-wives, who will not agree. (TA.)
And [hence also, app.,] AlD-ar-ataAni is a term applied to † The two stones of a mill. (Ṣ, M.)

The flesh of the DaroE [or udder]: (Ṣ:) or the udder (DrE) altogether, (Ḳ, TA,) except the OaTobaMC [or teats], when containing milk, but not otherwise: (TA:) or the base of the DrE, which is never, or scarcely ever, without milk in it: (TA:) or the base of the vadoI [or breast]: and i. q. xilofN [q. v.]. (Ḳ.) One says Dar-apN XakoraI, meaning A full Dr-p: (Ṣ in this art.:) or a Dr-p having much milk. (Ṣ in art. Xkr.)

Dar-apu AlUibohaAmi The portion of flesh that is beneath the thumb, which is what corresponds to the Oaloyah in the hand: (Ṣ:) or AlD-ar-apu signifies the portion of the palm of the hand extending from beneath the little finger to the wrist: (Zj, in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or the inner side of the hand, (Ḳ, TA,) over against the little finger, corresponding to the Alyp in the hand: (TA:) or the portion of flesh beneath the thumb: (Ḳ:) or the root thereof [i. e. of the thumb]: (TA:) and that part of the flesh of the sole of the foot upon which one treads, next the great toe. (Ḳ.) [See OaloyapN.]
The pl. of Dar-apN (in all the senses expl. above, TA) is DaraAYiru, (Ḳ, TA,) which [as said above] is extr. (TA.)
And AlD-ar-ataAni signifies The buttocks, on each side of the bone thereof: (Ḳ:) or the two flabby portions of flesh, on each side. (M, TA.)

Also Much property, (Ṣ,) or many cattle, (Ṣ,* TA,) exclusive of money: (TA:) or property, or cattle, (mAl,) upon which one relies [for his maintenance], but belonging to another, or others, (Ḳ, TA,) of his relations: (TA:) and a detached number of cattle, of camels, and of sheep or goats. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: Dur-apN: see Dar-aMCu.
DararN: see Dur-N, in two places.

Also Defect, deficiency, detriment, or loss, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so Dar-apN↓ and DaraArapN↓, (TA,) that happens to a thing, (Ḳ,) or to articles of property. (Mṣb.) You say, daxala Ealayohi DararN fiI maAlihi [Defect, deficiency, detriment, or loss, came upon him in his property, or cattle]. (TA.) And huwa fiI Darari xayorK [He is in a state of defective, or little, prosperity]. (TA.) See also Dar-aMCu.

Also Narrowness, or straitness. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say makaAnN cuw DararK A narrow place. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.) And laA Darara Ealayoka and lA DaAruwrapa↓ and lA taDir-apa↓ [app. No straitness shall befall thee: or no evil: or no adversity: or no want]. (Ṣ.)
And Narrow. (Ḳ.) You say makaAnN DararN A narrow place. (TA.) And maMCN DararN Water in a narrow place. (IAạr.)
And The brink, or edge, of a cave, or cavern. (AA, O, Ḳ.) One says, laA tamoXi EalaI hecaA AlD-arari [Walk not thou on this brink, or edge, of a cave]. (AA, O.)

hom.sense: DariyrN i. q. muDaAr-apN [i. e. Injurious conduct, either in the first instance or in return or requital:, &c.: see 3]: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) a subst. in this sense: (TA:) but it is mostly used in the sense here next following. (Ṣ, TA.)

‡ Jealousy. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) One says, mA OaXad-a Dariyrahu EalayohaA ‡ How great is his jealousy on her account! (Ṣ, A.) And Uin-ahu lacuw DariyrK EalaI QmoraOatihi ‡ Verily he is jealous on account of his wife. (TA.)

Also Spirit (nafosN), and remains of stoutness of body (baqiy-apu jisomK): (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, remains of spirit (baqiy-apu nafosK). (TA.) One says naAqapN caAtu DariyrK A she-camel strong in spirit, slow in becoming fatigued: (Ṣ, TA:) also expl. as meaning that injures the [other] camels by the vehemence of her pace, or the hardness of her journeying. (TA.) And baAqK DariyruhaA, referring to camels, is expl. by Aṣ as meaning Whose strength is lasting. (TA.)

Also Patience, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and endurance. (Ṣ.) One says, Uin-ahu lacuw DariyrK Verily he has patient endurance of evil: (TA:) and Uin-ahu lacuw DariyrK EalaI AlX-ar-i waAlX-idapi Verily he has patient endurance of evil and hardship; (Aṣ, Ṣ,* TA;) a phrase used in relation to a man and to a beast. (TA.)
Also [an epithet] signifying Anything intermixed, or mingled, with Dur- [i. e. harm, injury,, &c.]; and so maDoruwrN↓. (Ḳ.)

† Blind; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [a more respectful epithet than OaEomaI]; pl. OaDir-aMCu: (Ḳ:) † harmed by the loss of an eye, or by a constant and severe disease: (Mṣb:) ‡ diseased: (A, Ḳ:) and † lean, or emaciated: (Ḳ:) affected with a malady of long continuance; or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: (TA:) fem. with p {DariyrapN}: (A, Ḳ:) and pl. as above. (TA.)
And Persevering, and strong. (TA.) [Thus having contr. meanings.]
And Very patient (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) in endurance of everything; applied to a beast, (AA, Ṣ,) and also to a man. (TA.)

Also The brink of a valley; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the side thereof: one says, nazala fulaAnN EalaI OaHadi DariyraI AlwaAdiI, meaning [Such a one alighted] upon one of the two sides of the valley: (Ṣ:) pl. OaDir-apN. (TA.)
[Freytag has explained it also, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, as meaning The last part of a journey.]

entry.sense: DaraAYiru Persons in want, needy, or poor. (Ṣ.)
Also pl. of Dar-apN, [q. v.,] (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) in various senses. (TA.)
DaraArapN: see DararN: and Dar-aMCu, in two places.
Also † Blindness. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [See 1, last sentence, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.]

DaruwrapN Necessity, necessitude, need, or want; (Lth, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DaAruwrapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and DaAruwrN↓ and DaAruwraMCu↓ and Dar-apN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. DaruwraAtN. (TA.) You say, HamalaniI AlD-aruwrapu EalaI kacaA wakacaA [Necessity urged me to do such and such things]. (Lth.) And rajulN cuw DaAruwrapi↓ and DaruwrapK A man in want. (Ṣ.) [And hence fiI AlD-aruwrapi as meaning In the case of necessity in poetry or verse: and DaruwrapF by necessity; meaning by poetic license. See also Daruwriy-apN.]
And Difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness. (Mṣb.) [See also Dur-N, and Dar-apN, and Dar-aMCu.]

DaruwriI-N [Necessary knowledge]; as opposed to AikotisaAbiI-N, [natural, bestowed by nature, instinctive, or] such as the creature has by [divine] appointment; and, as opposed to AisotidolaAliI-N, [intuitive, immediate, axiomatic, or] such as originates without thought, or reflection, and intellectual examination of an evidence or a proof. (Kull.) [See also badiyhiI-N.]
[Daruwriy-apN as an epithet applied to a proposition means Qualified by the expression biAlD-aruwrapi (by necessity).]
[And the pl. Daruwriy-aAtN means Necessary, or indispensable, things.]
[Daruwriy-apN Necessity. (See also DaruwrapN.)]
[As fem. of the epithet DaruwriI-N, see this latter word.]

hom.sense: Dar-aMCu A hurtful state or condition; (IAth;) contr. of sar-aMCu: (IAth, Mṣb:) or hardship, distress, or straitness of condition [or of the means of subsistence, or of the conveniences of life]; (AHeyth;) i. q. Xid-apN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also baOosaMCu, like which it is a fem. n. without a masc.; and accord. to Fr, OaDur-N and OaboWusN may be used as pls. of these two ns.: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Az, † that [evil] which relates to the person; as disease: whereas bOsMC is that which relates to property; as poverty: (Bḍ in ii. 172:) or detriment, or loss, with respect to property and with respect to persons; (A, Ḳ;) as also Dar-apN↓, or Dur-apN↓, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) and DaraArapN↓: (Ḳ:) and [hence] poverty: and punishment: and drought, or barrenness; or vehement, or intense, drought; (TA: [see also DaAruwraMCu:]) and † disease of long continuance; or such as cripples, or deprives of the power to move or to stand or to walk; (A, Ḳ;) as also DararN↓, as used in the Ḳur iv. 97: or, accord. to Ibn-ʼArafeh, the latter there means † a hurtful malady that cuts one off from serving in war against unbelievers and the like; as also DaraArapN↓; relating to sight,, &c. (TA.)

[Also, accord. to Freytag, Tangled trees, in a valley: but the word having this meaning is correctly DaraMCN, belonging to art. Drw and DrI, q. v. And be explains it also as meaning a bare, or an open, place; and the contr. i. e. a place covered with trees; referring to the “Kitáb el-Addád.”]

entry.sense: Dar-aArN [That harms, injures, hurts,, &c., much]. (TA in art. xlw.)

DaAr-N [act. part. n. of 1; Harming, injuring, hurting,, &c.; or that harms,, &c.; noxious, injurious,, &c.]. Aln-aAfiEu AlD-aAr-u, an appellation of God, means He who benefiteth and who harmeth whomsoever He will, of his creatures. (TA.)
DaAruwrN: see DaruwrapN.
DaAruwraMCu Drought: and hardship, distress, or adversity. (Ḳ.) See also DaruwrapN. [And see Dur-N, and Dar-aMCu.]
[SifapN QDoTiraAriy-apN i. q. SifapN xiloqiy-apN i. e. A natural quality; opposed to QxotiyaAriy-apN.]
taDir-apN and taDur-apN: see Dur-N: and for the former see also DararN.

hom.sense: muDir-N Approaching (Ḳ, TA) to a thing: and approaching so near as to harm, injure, or hurt. (TA.) saHaAbN muDir-N means Clouds approaching the earth. (Ṣ, A.)

Also A man having two wives, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or having [several] wives at the same time. (Mṣb.) And a woman having a fellow-wife, (TA,) or having fellow-wives; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) having a fellow-wife, or two fellow-wives; as also muDir-apN. (Ḳ.)
And A man having a Dar-ap [q. v.] of cattle: (TA:) or who has a Dar-ap of cattle that return to him in the afternoon, or evening, from the place of pasture. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: maDar-apN A cause, or means, of harm, injury, hurt, mischief, or damage; contr. of manofaEapN: (Ṣ, TA:) [and simply] harm, injury, hurt,, &c.; syn. DararN: pl. maDaAr-u. (Mṣb.)
miDoraArN A woman, and a she-camel, and a mare, that takes fright, and runs away, and goes at random, (tanid-u watarokabu XidoqahaA,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
maDoruwrN: see DariyrN.

bayoEu AlmuDoTar-i, which is forbidden in a trad., is of two kinds: one is The sale that one is compelled to contract against his will; and this is null: the other is the sale to which one is necessitated to consent in consequence of a debt that he has incurred or of a burden that has come upon him, so that he sells at a loss that which is in his possession; and this kind of sale is valid, though disapproved by the people of knowledge. (IAth, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. Darabahu, aor. _i {yaDoribu}, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. DarobN, (Ṣ, O, &c.,) [He beat, struck, smote, or hit, him, or it;] and Dr-bhu↓ [signifies the same in an intensive sense, i. e. he beat,, &c., him, or it, much, or violently; or in a frequentative sense, i. e. several, or many, times: or rather Dr-b is used in relation to several, or many, objects, as will be shown in what follows]: (Ḳ:) accord. to Er-Rághib, AlD-arobu signifies the making a thing to fall upon another thing; and, as some say, the making it to fall with violence, or vehemence. (TA.) You say, Darabahu bihi [He struck him, or it, with it], i. e. with a sword, (A, Mgh, Mṣb), &c. (A, Mṣb.) And taDoribu fiI HadiydK baAridK [Thou beatest upon cold iron]: a prov. [expl. in art. Hd]. (Ḥar p. 633.) And Darabotu zayodFA sawoTFA, meaning bisawoTK [i. e. I struck Zeyd with a whip], or Darobapa sawoTK [a stroke of a whip]: (M in art. swT, q. v.:) and Darabahu miAYapa sawoTK [He struck him a hundred strokes of the whip]. (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. sHl, &c.) And Darabotu Eunuqahu [I smote his neck, meaning I beheaded him]; and Dar-abotu↓ AlOaEonaAqa [I smote the necks, meaning I struck off the heads]; the teshdeed denoting muchness [of the action] or multiplicity [of the objects]:
AZ says that, when the object is one, the Arabs use only the former verb, without teshdeed; but when there is a plurality of objects, either of the verbs; (Mṣb;) [so that] one says, DarabuwA OaEonaAqahumo [They smote their necks, or beheaded them], and Oamara bitaDoriybi↓ Alr-iqaAbi [He gave the order to smite the necks, or to strike off the heads]: (A:) faDaroba Alr-iqaAbi in the Ḳur xlvii. 4 is originally faQDoribuwA Alr-iqaAba DarobFA [meaning Then do ye smite the necks, i. e. strike off the heads]; (Bḍ;) the inf. n. being here put for its verb. (Jel.) [Respecting the phrase huwa QloyaDoribuka, see 1 in art. jdE.]
[Hence a variety of meanings and phrases here following.]

Daraba kalobahu EalaI AlS-ayodi † [He beat, or disciplined, or trained, his dog for the purpose of the chase]: whence the phrases Daraba Ealayohi jirowatahu and Daraba jirowapa nafosihi and Darabotu jirowatiI Eanohu [expl. voce jirowapN]. (Z, and TA in art. jrw.)

laA tuDorabu OakobaAdu AlUibili Uil-aA valaAvapi masaAjida † Camels shall not be ridden, save to three mosques: [namely, that of Mekkeh, that of El-Medeeneh, and that of El-Aksà at Jerusalem:] a trad. (TA. [See also 4 in art. Eml.])

[Daraba bihi AlOaroDa, lit. He smote with him, or it, the ground; meaning † he cast, threw, or flung, him, or it, upon the ground. And Daraba bisaloHihi AlOaroDa † He cast forth his excrement, or ordure, upon the ground.] And [hence] Daraba AlOaroDa and AlgaAYiTa ‡ He voided excrement, or ordure; (A, TA;) and so AlxalaMCa. (TA.) [Daraba binafosihi AlOaroDa see expl. in the latter half of this paragraph.]
Darabotu Alqawosa biAlmiDorabi I struck the string of the bow with the wooden implement [or mallet] used in separating cotton. (Mṣb.)
Daraba AlEuwda [He struck the chords of the lute; meaning he played upon the lute; and so Daraba biAlEuwdi]. (Ṣ.)

Daraba Alwatida, aor. and inf. n. as above, He beat [or knocked or struck] the tent-peg, or stake, so that it became firm in the ground. (Lḥ, TA.) And [hence] Daraba Alxayomapa ‡ He pitched the tent, by knocking in its pegs with a mallet: (Kull p. 231:) or he set up the tent. (Mṣb.)

Daraba Ald-irohama, aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He struck, coined, or minted, the dirhem, or piece of money. (TA.) And Daraba EalaI Qsmihi † [He struck, coined, or minted, money in his name]. (ISd, TA in art. jwz.)
Daraba EalaI Almakotuwbi ‡ He sealed, or stamped, the writing. (A,* TA.) [And Daraba Ealayohi † He erased it; namely, anything written.]
Daraba AlT-iyna EalaI AljidaAri † [He stuck, or applied, the mud upon the wall, as a plaster]. (TA.)

Hence, accord. to some, the phrase Duribato Ealayohimu Qlc-il-apu, in the Ḳur ii. 58, considered as meaning † Vileness was made to cleave to them: or the meaning is, † encompassed them, like as the tent encompasses him over whom it is pitched. (Ksh, Bḍ.) And [in like manner] one says, Duribato Ealayohimu DariybapN ‡ An impost, of the tax called jizoyap, &c., was imposed upon them. (A,* Mgh, Mṣb.*) And Daraba EalaI AlEabodi AlOitaAwapa ‡ He imposed upon the slave the tax according to a fixed time. (TA. [See DirybapN.]) And Durba Ealayohimu AlbaEovu † The being sent to the war was appointed them and imposed upon them as an obligation. (Mgh in art. bEv.)
Daraba AlX-abakapa EalaI AlT-aAYiri † He cast the net over the bird: (Mgh:) and Duriba Alfax-u EalaI AlT-aAYiri ‡ [The snare was cast over the bird]. (A, TA.)

Daraba All-ayolu biOaruwaAqihi † [The night cast its folds of darkness;] meaning the night came. (TA.) [And † The night became dark, or was dark; as appears from the following verse.] Homeyd says,
saraI mivola naboDi AlEiroqi waAll-ayolu DaAribN
biOrowaAqihi waAlS-uboHu qado kaAda yasoTaEu
† [He went on in his night-journey, like the pulsing of the vein, while the night was casting its folds of darkness over the earth, and the dawn had almost risen]. (TA. [See also DaAribN.]) You say also, Daraba Ealayohi HijaAbFA † [He put, or let down, a veil, or curtain, or covering, over him, or it]. (TA.) And Duriba bayonahumaA sad-N † [A barrier was set between them two]. (A in art. sd.)
