DarabonaA EalaI McaAnihimo [in the Ḳur xviii. 10] means ‡ We prevented their sleeping; (Ḳ, TA;) as though by putting a covering over their ears; a metonymical [and elliptical] mode of saying we made them to sleep by preventing any sound from penetrating into their ears, in consequence of which they would have awoke: (Zj, L, TA:) or Daraba EalaI McaAnihimo means † he poured upon them sleep so that they slept and did not awake: and one says also, Darabotu Aln-awoma EalaI Oucunihi [meaning † I poured sleep upon him by closing his ear]. (Mṣb.)
Darabati, AlEaqorabu, (A, Ḳ,* TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ The scorpion stung. (A, Ḳ,* TA.)

[Darabatohu Alr-iyHu † The wind beat it, or blew upon it; namely, herbage, and water, &c.] And Darabahu Albarodu (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA) † The cold smote it so as to injure it; namely, herbage; and in like manner one says of the wind: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) and ADrbhu↓ Albarodu (A, TA) ‡ The cold smote it by its vehemence, so that it dried up; and in like manner one says of the wind: (TA:) and ADrb↓ AlD-ariybu AlOaroDa † The hoar-frost, or rime, fell upon the land, so that its herbage became nipped, or blasted. (AZ, TA. [See also Dariba.]) And Duriba bibaliy-apK † He was smitten with a trial, or an affliction. (L, TA.)
Tariyqu mak-apa maA DarabahaA AlEaAma qaTorapN ‡ [The road to Mekkeh, not a drop of rain has fallen upon it this year]. (A, TA.)

Daraba AlfaHolu Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) aor. _i {yaDoribu}, (TA,) inf. n. DiraAbN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DarobN also, accord. to Fr, but this latter, though agreeable with analogy, is disallowed by Sb and Akh, (TA,) ‡ The stallion leaped the she-camel; (Mṣb, TA;) i. e. (TA,) compressed (A, Ḳ, TA) her. (TA.) DiraAbu Aljamali is used elliptically for vamanu DiraAbi Aljamali ‡ The hire of the camel's leaping the female: the taking of which, as also the taking of the hire of any stallion for covering, is forbidden in a trad. (TA.)

Daraba AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCi ‡ He mixed the [one] thing with the [other] thing; (A, Ḳ;) as also Dr-bhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoriybN: (TA:) accord. to some, said peculiarly in relation to milk; (MF, TA;) but [SM says,] this I have not found in any lexicon. (TA.) Daraba All-abana fiI Als-iqaMCi means ‡ Haqanahu [i. e. He collected the milk in the skin, and poured fresh milk upon that which was curdled, or thick, or upon that which was churned; or he poured the milk into the skin, and kept it therein that its butter might come forth]. (A.) In the L and other lexicons it is said that Darabotu bayonahumo fiI AlX-ar-i means I caused them to become confused [or I involved them] in evil or mischief. (TA. [And Dr-bt bayonahumo has a similar meaning: see 2.]) And Durbati AlX-aApu bilawoni kacaA means The sheep, or goat, was intermixed with such a colour. (L, TA.)
Daraba AlX-ajaru biEuruwqihi fiI AlOaroDi [The trees struck their roots into the earth]. (A and TA in art. Erq.)

[Hence, the saying,] Darabato fiyhi fulaAnapu biEiroqK ciI OaXabK i. e. AilotibaAs; (Ṣ and TA in the present art., and in like manner, in both, in art. AXb, with the addition of ciI before AilotibaAsK;) ‡ [app. meaning Such a woman implanted, or engendered, in him a strain, i. e. a radical, or hereditary, quality, of a dubious kind: or the pronoun in fyh relates to a family, or people; for it is said that] the meaning is, such a woman corrupted their race by her bringing forth among them: or, as some say, Erqt fiyhimo Eiroqa sawoCK [i. e. Ear-aqato, or, accord. to more common usage, OaEoraqato, i. e., implanted, or engendered, among them, or in them, an evil strain, or radical or hereditary disposition]. (TA. [This saying is also mentioned in the A, as tropical, but is not expl. therein.])

Daraba biAlqidaAHi, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and Daraba AlqidaAHa, (A, TA,) ‡ He turned about, or shuffled, (OajaAla,) the arrows, [in the ribaAbap (q. v.), in the game called Almuyosir,] EalaI Aljazwri [for the slaughtered camel]. (Mgh. [See HuroDapN.]) [And † He played with the gamingarrows; practised sortilege with arrows, or with the arrows.] You say, Darabotu maEa Alqawomi bisahomK † I practised sortilege with the people, or party, with an arrow; syn. saAhamotuhumo. (Mṣb.) And Daraba biAlqidoHayoni † He practised sortilege with the two arrows; one of which was inscribed with the sentence “My Lord hath commanded me,” and the other with “My Lord hath forbidden me:” a person between hope and despair is likened to one practising this mode of sortilege, which was used by the people of the Time of Ignorance when they doubted whether they should undertake an affair or abstain from it. (Ḥar pp. 465 and 553.) One says also, Daraba fiI AljazuwribisahomK meaning † He obtained a share, or portion, of the slaughtered camel. (Mgh.) And hence the saying of El-Ḥareeree, waDarabotu fiI maroEaAhaA binaSiybK † [And I obtained a share of its pasture]. (Mgh.) And the lawyers say, yaDoribu fiyhi biAlv-uluvi i. e. † He shall take thereof somewhat, according to what is due to him, of the third part. (Mgh.)
They say also, Daraba fiI maAlihi sahomFA i. e. † He assigned [a share, or portion, of his property]: and thus is expl. the saying of Aboo-Ḥaneefeh, laA yaDoribu lilomuwSaI lahu fiymaA zaAda EalaI Alv-uluvi † He shall not assign, or give, to the legatee, aught of more than the third part; the true objective complement being suppressed. (Mgh.)

Daraba biyadayohi [lit. He beat with his arms; meaning † he moved his arms about, or to and fro; brandished, tossed, or swung them]: you say, Daraba biyadayohi waHar-akahumaA fiI miXoyatihi † [He swung his arms, and moved them about, in his manner of walking]. (TA in art. jdf. [See jadafa.]) And Daraba fiI AlmaMCi [biyadayohi being understood after the verb] † He swam. (Ḳ.)

Daraba biyadihi UilaI XaIoCK † He made a sign, or pointed, with his hand, towards a thing. (TA.) And Daraba [alone] † He made a sign, or pointed. (Ḳ.) And Daraba biyadihi UilaI kacaA † He put forth his hand towards such a thing, to take it, or to point, or make a sign. (TA.) And Daraba yadahu UilaI Eamali kacaA † [He applied his hand to the doing of such a thing]. (Lth, TA.) [And Daraba yadayohi fiI AlmaAli a phrase expl. to me by IbrD as meaning † He busied his hands with the property, in the giving, or dispensing of it.]

Daraba EalaI yadihi † [He struck his (i. e. another man's) hand; meaning] he struck, or made, the bargain with him; or ratified the sale with him: for it is a custom, when two persons are bargaining together, for one of them to put his hand upon the other's in ratifying the bargain. (TA, from a trad.)

And ‡ He prohibited, or prevented, or hindered, him, from doing a thing, or from doing a thing that he had begun: (TA:) and [in like manner] Daraba EalaI yadayohi ‡ he withheld, or restrained, him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.) And (i. e. the former phrase) ‡ He (the judge, A, Mgh, TA) prohibited, or interdicted, him from the using, or disposing of, his property according to his own free will. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.)
Also ‡ He corrupted, vitiated, marred, or disordered, his affair, or case, or state. (A, Mṣb, TA.)

Daraba Eanohu † He turned away a person or thing from him [or it]; as also ADrb↓: (TA:) [or] ADrb↓ Enh signifies, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or signifies also, (TA,) and (Mṣb, TA) so does Daraba Enh, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [the latter app. for Daraba nafosahu Eanohu,] † He turned away from, avoided, shunned, or left, him, or it; (Ṣ * Mṣb, Ḳ * TA;*) namely, a person, (TA,) or a thing. (Mṣb.) OafanaDoribu Eanokumu Qlc-ikora SafoHFA, in the Ḳur [xliii. 4], is said to mean † Shall we then neglect you, and not teach you what is incumbent on you? the phrase being taken from a rider's striking his beast with his stick when he desires to turn him from the course that he is pursuing: or the meaning is, † shall we then turn away the Ḳur-án from you, and not invite you thereby to the faith, turning away ourselves from you? (TA.) One says also, Darabotu Eanohu SafoHFA meaning † I turned away from him and left him. (Ṣ and TA in art. SfH: see 1 in that art.) See also the saying Daraba OaxomaAsahu fiI OasodaAsihi voce xumusN.
And fulaAnN yaDoribu OaxomaAsFA liOasodaAsK: see voce ximosN.

Daraba binafosihi AlOaroDa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DarobN, (TA,) [lit. He smote with himself the ground; and hence, † he cast, threw, or flung, himself upon the ground; app. often used in this sense; (a phrase similar to Daraba bihi AlOaroDa expl. before;) and hence,] † he remained, stayed, or abode; (Ḳ;) and so ADrb↓ (AZ, ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) as used in the phrase ADrb Alr-ajulu fiI Albayoti ‡ The man remained, stayed, or abode, in the tent, or house, (AZ, ISk, Ṣ, A, TA,) not quitting it: (ISk, A, TA:) and [in like manner] Daraba bcanabihi, [AlOaroDa being understood,] † He stayed, or abode, and remained fixed. (Ḳ in art. cnb. [See also other explanations of this last phrase in a later part of this paragraph.]) And Daraba Alwatida bimaHal-i kacaA ‡ He remained, stayed, or abode, [lit., struck the tent-peg,] in such a place of alighting. (A.) And Darabati AlUibilu biEaTanK, [AlOaroDa being understood after AlAbl,] † The camels lay down [in a place by the water]: (Ṣ in art. ETn:) or satisfied themselves with drinking and then lay down around the water or by the watering-troughs, to be brought again to drink another time: (IAth, TA in that art.:) and [hence,] Daraba Aln-aAsu biEaTanK, occurring in a trad., † The people's camels satisfied themselves with drinking until they lay down and remained in their place [at the water]: (TA in the present art.:) or the people satisfied their thirst and then abode at the water. (Ḳ in art. ETn.)
Daraba bicaqanihi AlOaroDa ‡ He was cowardly; and feared; (A, O,* Ḳ, TA;) and clave to the ground: (O, TA:) or he was, or became, affected with shame, shyness, or bashfulness. (A, TA.)

yaDoribu lahu AlOaroDa kul-ahaA [lit. He beats for it the whole land, i. e. in journeying,] means † he seeks it through the whole land: so says AZ in explanation of the phrase here following. (O, TA.) yaDoribu Almajoda † He seeks to gain, or obtain, glory: (O, Ḳ:) or he applies himself with art and diligence to gain glory, (yakotasibuhu,) and seeks it through the whole land. (AZ, TA. [See also 8.])

Daraba All-abina, (A,) or All-ibona, ‡ He made [or moulded] bricks. (MA.) And Daraba AlxaAtama ‡ He made, fashioned, or moulded, the signet-ring. (TA.) [Hence one says,] AiDoribohu EalaI TaboEi hecaA i. e. † [Make thou it, fashion it, or mould it,] according to the model, make, fashion, or mould, of this. (IAạr, O and Ḳ in art. TbE.) And hecihi Dariybatuhu Al-atiI Duriba EalayohaA, and DuribahaA, and Duriba alone, [for Duriba EalayohaA,] meaning TubiEa [i. e. † This is his nature, with an adaptation, or a disposition, to which he was moulded, or created; or to which he was adapted, or disposed, by creation]. (Lḥ, TA.) And Duriba fulaAnN EalaI Alkarami ‡ [Such a one was moulded, or created, with an adaptation or a disposition, to generosity; or was adapted, or disposed, by creation, or nature, to generosity]. (A.)

Daraba mavalFA (Ṣ, A, O, &c.) ‡ He rehearsed, propounded, or declared, a parable, a similitude, an example, or a proverb; said of God [and of a man]: (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, TA:) or he mentioned, or set forth, a parable,, &c.: or he framed a parable: thus expl., the verb has but one objective complement: or the phrase signifies he made [such a thing] an example, or the subject of a parable or similitude, &c.; and so has two objective complements: in the saying in the Ḳur [xxxvi. 12] waQDoribo lahumo mavalFA OaSoHaAba Qloqaroyapi † [And propound thou to them a parable, the people of the town] i. e., the story of the people of the town, [or make thou to them a parable, or similitude, or an example, the people of the town;] mvlA may be in the accus. case as an objective complement, ADHAb Alqryp being a substitute for mvlA; or ASHAb Alqryp may be regarded as a second objective complement [i. e. second in the order of the words, but first in the order of the sense]: the phrase is differently expl. on account of the different meanings of the verb Daraba; which signifies he described, or rehearsed; and he declared, propounded, or explained; and he made, caused to be, or constituted;, &c.; accord. to some, it is taken from the phrase Daraba Aldirohama [q. v.]; because of the impression which a parable or the like makes upon the mind: accord. to some, from DariybN signifying “a like;” because the first thing is made like the second: accord. to some, from Daraba AlT-iyna EalaI AljidaAri [q. v.; because the mud, applied as a plaster, conforms to the shape of the wall]: and accord. to some, from Daraba AlxaAtama [q. v.]; because of the correspondence between a parable or the like and the object to which it is applied, and the correspondence between the signet and its impression. (TA, from the M and L, &c.) yaDoribu Qll-ehu QloHaq-a waQlobATila, in the Ḳur [xiii. 18], means † God likeneth, or compareth, truth and falsity. (TA.) One says also, Daraba bihi mavalFA † [He made him, or it, a subject of a parable, a similitude, an example, or a proverb; he propounded, or framed, a parable,, &c., respecting him, or it]. (TA.) And yuDorabu Almavalu likacaA [The proverb,, &c., is applied to, in relation to, or to the case of, such a thing]. (Meyd, &c., passim.)
Daraba lahu OajalFA † He specified, or notified, to, or for, him, or it, a term, or period. (Mgh, Mṣb.*)
Daraba lahumo TariyqFA † He assigned to them, or made for them, a way; syn. jaEala. (MA. [App. from a phrase in the Ḳur xx. 79, q. v.])

AlD-arobu as a conventional term of the accountants, or arithmeticians, means The multiplying a number by another number; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as when you say, [Daraba xamospF fiI sit-apK He multiplied five by six; and] xamosapN fiI sit-apK bivalaAviyna [Five multiplied by six is thirty]. (Mṣb.)

Daraba [is often intrans., and thus] signifies also taHar-aka [i. e. † It was, or became, in a state of commotion,, &c.]: (Ḳ:) [see also 8, which is more commonly used in this sense:] or, so with strength, or force. (TA.) [And hence several phrases here following.]

Daraba AlEiroqu (A, TA,) inf. n. DarobN and DarabaAnN, (TA,) ‡ The vein pulsed, or beat, (A, TA,) and throbbed: (TA:) and Daraba, inf. n. DarabaAnN, ‡ it (the vein) pained, and was, or became, in a state of strong commotion. (TA.) And Daraba AljuroHu, inf. n. DarabaAnN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) ‡ The wound [throbbed; or] pained violently: (A, Mṣb:) and so AlDirosu ‡ [the tooth]. (A, TA.)

Darabati Aln-aAqapu, (A, Ḳ,) or, as in some lexicons, AlmaxaADu, (TA,) ‡ The she-camel, (A, Ḳ,) or the pregnant camel, (TA,) raised her tail, and smote her vulva with it, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and then went along. (Ḳ, TA.)
Daraba fiI jahaAzihi ‡ He (a camel) took fright, and ran away at random, (Ṣ, A, L, TA,) and ceased not to gallop and leap until he had thrown off all his furniture, or load. (L, TA.)

jaMCa yaDoribu biXar-K ‡ He came hastening [with mischief, or] in an evil affair. (A.) It is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, When such and such things shall happen, (mentioning faction, or sedition, or the like,) Daraba yaEosuwbu Ald-iyni bicanabihi, meaning, accord. to AM, † The leader of the religion shall hasten to go away through the land, fleeing from the faction, or sedition: or, as some say, shall go away hastily through the land, with his followers. (O, TA. [But see yaEosuwbN: and see also canabN.]) And you say also, Darabotu fiI Als-ayori, (Mṣb,) inf. n. DarobN, (Ṣ,) † I hastened in journeying. (Ṣ,* Mṣb.) And Daraba fiI AlOaroDi, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaDoribu}, (TA,) inf. n. DarobN (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) and maDorabN (Ṣ, TA) and DarabaAnN, (Ḳ, TA,) † He journeyed in the land (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) seeking sustenance, (Ṣ,) and for the purpose of traffic: (Mgh:) [and Daraba AlOaroDa, as shown above, has a similar meaning:] or ‡ he went forth in the land as a merchant; (A, Ḳ;) or warring and plundering, (Ḳ,) or so Daraba fiI sabiyli Qll-ehi [meaning in the cause of God]: (A:) or he hastened through the land: (A, Ḳ:) or he arose, and hastened in his journey through the land: (TA:) or he went, or went away, in the land: (A, Ḳ:) or he traversed, or journeyed through, the land. (TA.) The verb is [similarly] used in relation to almost all employments: you say, Daraba fiI Alt-ijaArapi † [He travelled for the purpose of traffic]: (TA:) and Uin-a liIfiI Oalofi dirohamK lamaDorabFA i. e. DarobFA [Verily I have to make a journey for the sake of, or on account of, a thousand dirhems]. (Ṣ, TA: but in my copies of the Ṣ, lI is omitted.) And Darabati AlT-ayoru, aor. as above, ‡ The birds went, or went away, [or migrated,] seeking sustenance. (Ḳ, TA.)

Daraba said of time, † It went, passed, or passed away. (Ḳ.) And Daraba Ald-ahoru mino DarabaAnihi, or, accord. to one reading, mino Darobihi, occurring in a trad., ‡ The time in part passed; [the time pursued a part of its course;] or a part of the time passed. (TA.) And Daraba Ald-ahoru DarabaAnahu † Fortune, or time, produced, or brought to pass, its events: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) a phrase like quDiIa mina AlqaDaMCi. (Ṣ, L, TA.) And Daraba Ald-ahoru mino DarabaAnihi Oano kaAna kacaA wakacaA ‡ [Fortune, or time, brought to pass, among its events, that such and such things happened]. (A, L, TA.) And Daraba Ald-ahoru bayonanaA ‡ Fortune, or time, separated us: (AO, A, TA:) or made a wide separation between us; syn. baE-ada. (Ḳ.)
Also † It was, or became, long: (Ḳ, TA:) so in the saying, Daraba All-ayolu Ealayohimo † [The night was, or became, long to them]. (TA.)
And Daraba Uilayohi † It inclined to it. (TA.) [One says, yaDoribu UilaI Als-awaAdi † It inclines to blackness, and UilaI AlHumorapi to redness,, &c.: often occurring in the lexicons.]
DaArabahu faDarabahu, aor. of the latter _u: see 3.
Darubato yaduhu i. q. jaAda DarobuhaA [meaning Excellent, or how excellent, is his hand, or arm, in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting! a phrase similar to ramuwto yaduhu]. (Ḳ.)

Dariba, (IḲṭṭ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDorabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DarabN, said of herbage, ‡ It was marred, or spoilt, by the cold: (A:) or it was smitten by the cold, (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA,) and injured thereby, and by the wind. (IḲṭṭ, TA.) And Daribati AlOaroDu, inf. n. DarabN, † The land was smitten by hoar-frost, or rime, and its herbage was nipped, or blasted, thereby: (AZ, TA:) and Duribat [in like manner] ‡ it (i. e. land) was smitten by hoar-frost, or rime; or had hoar-frost, or rime, fallen upon it. (Ṣ, A, TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence; and in two places in a sentence shortly after that.
Dr-b AlX-aIoCa biAlX-aIoCi: see 1, in the second quarter of the paragraph.
[Hence,] Alt-aDoriybu bayonu Alqawomi † The exciting discord, or strife, or animosity, between, or among, the people, or party. (Ṣ, TA.)
And Dr-b, inf. n. taDoriybN, signifies also † He excited, incited, urged, or instigated, and roused to ardour, a courageous man, in war, or battle. (TA.)
Dr-b AlmuDar-abapa, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He sewed (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) [meaning quilted] with cotton (Mgh, Mṣb) the muDar-abap [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
Dr-bt Eayonuhu His eye became depressed in his head. (Ḳ.)

Dr-b, inf. n. as above, also signifies † He exposed himself, or became exposed, (taEar-aDa,) to the snow, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the Dariyb [which signifies also, and more commonly, hoar-frost, or rime]. (TA.)
And He drank what is termed Dariyb, (O, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the milk thus called, (O,) or Xahod [meaning honey, or honey in its comb, or honey not expressed from its comb]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. DArbhu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muDaArabapN (Mṣb, TA) and DaraAbN, He contended with him in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting; he beat him,, &c., being beaten,, &c., by him; (TA;) [he returned him beating for beating, blow for blow, or blows for blows; he bandied, or exchanged, blows with him: and] he contended with him in fight. (Ṣ, TA.) One says, DArbhu faDarabahu↓, aor. of the latter verb _u, (Ḳ, TA,) agreeably with the general rule respecting verbs signifying the surpassing, or overcoming, in a contest, (MF, TA,) He contended with him in beating,, &c., and he surpassed him, or overcame him, therein. (Ḳ,* TA.) See also 6.

[Golius says, as on the authority of the KL, that DArb signifies also “Coivit camelus;” and Freytag, as on the authority of the Ḳ, that it signifies “inivit camelus camelam:” but in the KL it is only said that DaraAbN is an inf. n. of a verb having this meaning; and its verb in this sense, as is said in the Ṣ and A and Mṣb and Ḳ, is Daraba, which has been thus expl. in the first paragraph.]

DArb fiI AlmaAli and biAlmaAli, inf. n. muDaArabapN, means ‡ He trafficked with the property. (A.) And DArb lahu (A, Mgh, Ḳ) fiI maAlihi, (A, Mgh,) or DArbhu fI AlmaAli, (Ṣ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, A, Mgh,) means ‡ He trafficked for him with his property [or with the property]; (A, Mgh;) because he who does so generally journeys in the land seeking gain; (Mgh;) app. from AlD-arobu fiI AlOaroDi [the journeying in the land] for the purpose of seeking sustenance: (TA:) and is syn. with qaAraDahu, (Ṣ,* Mgh, Ḳ,* TA,*) he gave him of his property for the purpose of his trafficking therewith on the condition that the gain should be between them two or that the latter should have a certain share of the gain: and accord. to En-Naḍr, DArbhu is said of him who does thus and also of the person thus employed. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. ADrb AlfaHola Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ,) and ADrb Aln-aAqapa AlfaHola, (A, TA,) inf. n. UiDoraAbN, (TA,) ‡ He made the stallion to leap the she-camel. (Ṣ,* A,* TA.)
ADrb jaOoXFA liOamori kacaA ‡ He disposed, or accommodated, and subjected, himself to such a thing, or such an affair. (A, TA.)
ADrb Als-amuwmu AlmaMCa † The smwm [or hot wind] caused the earth to imbibe the water (OanoXafahu AlOaroDa). (Ḳ.)
ADrb linafosihi xaAtamFA ‡ [He caused a signet-ring to be made, fashioned, or moulded, for himself]. (A, TA. [See also 8.])
ADrbhu Albarodu: and ADrb AlD-ariybu AlOaroDa: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.

[Accord. to the TA, OuDoribonaA (there written ADribnA) seems to signify † We were smitten by hoar-frost, or rime: or our land, or herbage, was smitten thereby: thus resembling OujolidonaA and OuSoqiEonaA: but perhaps the right reading is OaDorabonaA: for]
OaDoraba Alqawomu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. UiDoraAbN, (TA,) signifies † The people, or party, had hoar-frost, or rime, fallen upon them. (Ḳ, TA.)

ADrb Alxubozu † The bread (Ḳ, TA) i. e. the bread baked in hot ashes (TA) became thoroughly baked, (Ḳ, TA,) and in a fit state to be beaten with a stick and to have its ashes and dust shaken off. (TA.)

ADrb Eanohu: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph, in two places. [ADrb Eani AlOamori is expl. in a copy of the A as meaning Ear-afa Eanohu, and in the TA, (probably from that copy of the A, as I have reason to believe that it was used by the author of the TA,) is expl. by Erf Enh; but the right reading is indubitably Eazafa Eanohu, with the dotted z; meaning ‡ He turned away from the thing, or affair; a signification given in the first paragraph: it is said in the A to be tropical. And ADrb Eanohu also signifies † He digressed from it; made a digression, or transition, from it; namely, a subject of speech or discourse: and particularly † he turned from it and retracted it.]
ADrb Alr-ajulu fiI Albayoti: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
ADrb signifies also ‡ He was silent; he spoke not: or he lowered his eyes, looking towards the ground: syn. OaToraqa. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tDr-b [He beat, struck, smote, or hit, himself much, or violently; or several, or many, times]. One says, tDr-b biAlHaSaI [He smote himself much with pebbles], (Ḳ in art. kvH,) and biAlt-uraAbi [with earth, or dust, as a man sometimes does in vexation]. (L ibid.)
See also 8, in two places.

6. tDArbwA, (A, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, in the Ṣ tDArbA,) and ADTrbwA↓, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, in the Ṣ ADTrbA,) and DArbwA↓, (Ḳ,) [They contended in beating, striking, smiting, or hitting, one another; and particularly, in fight;] they smote one another with the sword. (MA.) One says, ADTrb↓ AlEabodaAni biAlEaSawayoni, meaning The two slaves beat each other with the two sticks, or staves. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: 8. ADTrb: see 6, in two places. The inf. n. is AiDoTiraAbN, of which the dim. is DutayoriybN↓, the T being changed [back] into t because the D becomes movent. (Ṣ and O in art. Tlq.)

[Hence, said of a thing, Its several parts collided; or were, or became, in a state of collision: and hence,] i. q. taHar-aka (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maAja; (Ḳ;) [but more significant than either of these; meaning he, or more generally it, was, or became, in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion, tumult, disturbance, or disorder; was, or became, agitated, convulsed, or unsteady; struggled; floundered; tossed, or shook, about, or to and fro; moved, or went, about, or to and fro, or from side to side; wabbled; wagged; quivered, quaked, trembled, or shivered; fluttered; flickered; and the like;] and tDr-b↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ. [Daraba, also, is sometimes used in the sense of taHar-aka, as mentioned before.]) One says, Almawoju yaDoTaribu The waves [dash together, are tumultuous, or] beat one another. (Ṣ.) And ADTrb Alwaladu biAlbaToni [The child was, or became, in a state of commotion in the belly]; (A;) And tDr-b↓ fiI AlbaToni [which means the same]. (TA.) And ADTrb Albaroqu fiI Als-aHaAbi The lightning was, or became, in a state of commotion in the clouds; [or it flickered therein;] syn. taHar-aka. (TA.) And ADTrb fiI Oumuwrihi He went to and fro occupied in his affairs for the means of subsistence: (Mgh:) and ADTrb, alone, signifies he sought to gain; or applied himself with art and diligence to gain; syn. Aikotasaba; (Ḳ, TA;) and is used by El-Kumeyt with Almajoda as its objective complement. (TA. [See also yaDoribu Almajoda, in the latter half of the first paragraph.]) And ADTrb Alr-ajulu † The man was tall, and therewithal loose, lax, flabby, uncompact, slack, or shaky, in make, or frame. (Ḳ,* TA.) And ADTrb Haboluhumo [properly, Their rope was shaky, loose, or slack; meaning] † their word, or sentence, or saying, varied, or was discordant: (Ḳ:) or their words, or sayings, [conflicted, or] varied, or were discordant: and so OaqowaAluhumo [their sayings]. (Kull p. 56.) And ADTrb raOoyuhu † [His opinion was, or became, confused, weak, or unsound]. (TA in art. rx.) And ADTrb Eaqoluhu † [His mind, or intellect, was, or became, disordered, confused, or unsound]. (Ḳ, in art. twh.) And ADTrb Oamoruhu † His affair, or state, was, or became, disordered, unsound, or corrupt; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) syn. Aixotal-a; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [it was, or became unsound, or unsettled; as is indicated in the TA in art. zl:] and ADTrbt AlOumuwru † The affairs were, or became, complicated, intricate, confused, discordant, or incongruous; syn. Aixotalafat: (Mṣb:) and ADTrb AlOamoru bayonahumo † [The affair, or case, was, or became, complicated, intricate, or confused, so as to be a subject of disagreement, or difference, between them]. (Mṣb voce Xajara, q. v.)
ADTrb xaAtamFA † He asked, or ordered, that a signet-ring should be made, fashioned, or moulded, for him: (Ḳ,* TA: [see also 4:]) occurring in a trad. (TA.)
ADTrb binaMCF fiI Almasojidi occurs in a trad. as meaning † He set up a structure upon stakes driven into the ground in the mosque. (TA.)
10. AstDrbt † She (a camel) desired the stallion. (Ḳ.)
And AstDrbhu faHolFA He desired, or demanded, of him a stallion to cover his she-camels; like AsTrqh fHlA. (TA. in art. Trq.)

AstDrb AlEasalu The honey became Daraba; (Ṣ;) i. e., became thick; (A;) or became white and thick: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the verb in this sense is similar to Aisotanowaqa in relation to a he-camel, and Aisotatoyasat in relation to a she-goat. (Ṣ.)

DarobN an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n.; (TA;) i. q. maDoruwbN↓ [Beaten, struck,, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) in some of the copies of the Ḳ, it is made the same as DarobN signifying “a species”, &c.: but this is a mistake. (TA.) One says dirohamN DarobN ‡ [A coined dirhem]; using the inf. n. as an epithet, as in the phrases maMCN gaworN and maMCN sakobN. (Ṣ.) And hecaA dirohamN Daroba AlOamiyri, in which Drb may be thus put in the accus. case as an inf. n., [the meaning being hecaA dirohamN maDoruwbN Daroba AlOamiyri ‡ This is a dirhem coined with the coining of the prince,] which is the most common way. (L, TA.)

‡ A light rain; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) or so maTarN DarobN: (A:) diymapN signifies “a lasting, or continuous, and still, rain;” and DarobN, a little more than diymapN, or a little above this: and DarobapN↓ [as the n. un.] signifies a fall, or shower, of light rain. (Aṣ, TA.)
† A make, form, fashion, mould, or cast; syn. SiygapN. (Ṣ, TA.)
† A sort, or species; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also DariybN↓; (Ḳ;) and accord. to some copies of the Ḳ maDoruwbN, but this is a mistake: the pl. of the first is DuruwbN. (TA.)

Also ‡ A like [of a thing and of a person]; (ISd, A, Ḳ, TA;) and so DirobN↓, as related on the authority of Z; (TA;) and DariybN↓; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, TA;) as in the phrase Dariybu AlX-aIoCi the like of the thing, (Ṣ, TA,) and fulaAnN Dariybu fulaAnK such a one is the like of such a one: (IAạr, TA:) or DarobN signifies a like in stature and make: (IAạr, TA:) its pl. is DuruwbN; (TA;) and the pl. of DariybN↓ is DaraAYibu (Ṣ) and DurabaMCu, this latter occurring in a trad., in the phrase, cahaba hecaA waDurabaAWuhu This went away, and the likes of him. (TA.) One says also Daroba qawolihi [meaning † In the like of his saying; referring to a saying in the Ḳur-án, &c.; a phrase similar to naHowa qawolihi]. (AZ, T voce Uino in several places.)

A man penetrating, or vigorous and effective; light, or active, in the accomplishment of an affair or of a want; (Ḳ, TA;) not flaccid, or flabby, in flesh. (TA.) And (Ḳ) a man (Ṣ, TA) light of flesh, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) lean and slender. (TA.) The pl. is DurubN; or, accord. to IJ, this may be pl. of DaruwbN↓. (L, TA.)
The last foot of a verse: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaDorubN and [of mult.] DuruwbN. (TA.)
See also DarabN.
[Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag, explains it also as meaning Sour milk: but this is app. a mistake for SarobN, with the unpointed S.]

entry.sense: DirobN: see the next preceding paragraph.

DarabN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DarobN↓, but the former is the better known, (Ḳ,) Thick honey: (A:) or white honey: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or thick white honey: (Ṣ:) or, as some say, wild honey: and DarabapN↓ signifies the same: or a portion thereof: (TA:) DarabN is masc. and fem.: (Ṣ:) [for] it is said to be pl. of DarabapN↓, or a coll. gen. n., which is in most cases masc. [but is also fem.]. (Mṣb.)
DaribN: see miDorabN.

Also ‡ Herbage smitten and injured by the cold, and by the wind. (TA.) And ‡ Herbage smitten by hoar-frost, or rime. (TA.) And OaroDN DaribapN ‡ Land smitten by hoarfrost, or rime, so that its herbage is nipped, or blasted, thereby. (AZ, TA.)
DarobapN [inf. n. un. of Daraba; A single act of beating, striking,, &c.: a blow, stroke,, &c.].
See also DarobN, fourth sentence.

DarobapF waAHidapF means † At one time; once. (Mgh, Mṣb.) So in the saying, laA Mxucu maAliI Ealayoka Uil-aA DarobapF waAHidapF † [I will not take what is due to me on thy part save at one time, or once]. (Mgh.)
Darobapu AlgaAYiSi, which is forbidden, is † The saying of the diver for pearls, to the merchant, I will dive for thee once, and what I shall bring up shall be thine for such a price. (T, Mgh, TA.)
DarabapN: see DarabN, in two places.
DaruwbN: see miDorabN: and see DarobN, near the end.

hom.sense: DariybN i. q. maDoruwbN↓ [Beaten, struck,, &c.]. (Ḳ, TA.)
A tent-peg, or stake, struck so as to be firm in the ground; as also maDoruwbN↓. (Lḥ, TA.)
See also DarobN, in three places.

Also, (Aṣ, ISd, Ḳ, TA,) or Dariybu AlX-awoli, accord. to Aboo-Naṣr, † Milk of which some is milked upon other: or, accord. to some of the Arabs of the desert, milk from a number of camels, some of it being thin, and some of it thick: (Ṣ:) or milk of which some is poured upon other: (Aṣ, TA:) or such as is milked from a number of camels (ISd, Ḳ, TA) into one vessel, and mixed together, not consisting of less than the milk of three camels: (ISd, TA:) or milk upon which other has been milked at night, and other on the morrow, and which has been mixed together. (TA.) [See also SariybN.]
And What is bad, of the kind of plants called HamoD: or what is broken in pieces, thereof. (Ḳ.)
See also miDorabN.

[Hence,] ‡ The person who is intrusted, as deputy, with [the disposal of] the gaming-arrows [in the game called Almayosir]: or the person who shuffles those arrows, or who plays with them; (Aal-aciI yaDoribu biAlqidaAHi;)
as also DaAribN↓: (Ḳ:) or both of these epithets signify the person who shuffles those arrows (Aal-aciI yaDoribu biAlqidaAHi); and he is the person who is intrusted, as deputy, with [the disposal of] them: (Ṣ:) the former is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Sb, TA:) and the pl. is DurabaMCu. (Ṣ, A.) You say, huwaDariybiI, meaning ‡ He is my playfellow with the gamingarrows (mino yaDoribu AlqidaAHa maEiI). (A, TA.)

And AlD-ariybu is a name of † The third arrow of those used in the game called Almayosir: (Ḳ,* TA:) that arrow is thus called by some: by others Alr-aqiybu [q. v.]: it has three notches; and three portions are assigned to it if successful, and three fines if unsuccessful. (Lḥ, L, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] DariybN signifies also † A share, or portion. (Ḳ.)
Also † Hoar-frost, or rime; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like jaliydN and saqiyTN: (Ṣ in art. jld:) and † snow. (Ḳ.)
And † The head: (Ḳ:) so called because often in a state of agitation. (TA.)
And i. q. XahodN [i. e. honey, or honey in its comb, or honey not expressed from its comb]: and EasalN DariybN honey becoming, or become, white and thick. (TA. [See also DarabN.])
Also Big-bellied, (baTiynN, [in some copies of the Ḳ baTon,]) [as an epithet] of men, (Ḳ, TA,) and of others. (TA.)

entry.sense: DariybapN A man, (Ḳ,) or anything, (T, Ṣ,* TA,) living or dead, (T, TA,) struck, or smitten, with the sword: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) the p is affixed, though the word has the meaning of a pass. part. n., because it becomes numbered with substs., like naTiyHapN and OakiylapN. (Ṣ.)
[And also] The place [or part] upon which the blow, or stroke, falls, of the body that is beaten, or struck. (Ḥam p. 129.)

And Wool, or [goats'] hair, separated, or plucked asunder, with the fingers, and then folded together, and bound with a thread, and spun: (Ṣ: [more fully expl. voce saliylapN:]) and wool that is beaten with a mallet: (TA:) or a portion of wool: (Ḳ:) or a portion of cotton, and of wool: (TA:) pl. DaraAYibu. (Ṣ.)

Also ‡ An impost that is levied, of the poll-tax or land-tax and the like, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and of [the tolls, or similar exactions, termed] OaroSaAd: (Ṣ, O, TA:) pl. as above. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, &c.) And (hence, TA) ‡ The gal-ap [as meaning the income, or revenue, arising from the service] of a slave; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) i. e. Dariybapu AlEabodi means what the slave pays to his master, of the impost that is laid upon him: DariybapN being of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN. (TA.)

And ‡ A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like: [as though signifying a particular cast of constitution, moulded by the Creator:] syn. TabiyEapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and sajiy-apN: (Ṣ:) pl. as above. (A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN kariymu AlD-ariybapi [‡ Such a one is generous in respect of nature]; and laYiymu AlD-ariybapi [‡ mean, &c.]; (Ṣ;) and Uin-ahu lakariymu AlD-araAYibi [‡ Verily he is generous in respect of natural dispositions]: and xuliqa Aln-aAsu EalaI DaraAYiba Xat-aI [Men are created of diverse natures, &c.]. (TA.)
See also maDoribN.
Dar-aAbN: see miDorabN.
DaAribN [Beating, striking, smiting, or hitting:, &c.:] act. part. n. of Daraba [in all its senses]. (Ḳ, TA.)

A she-camel that strikes her milker: (Ṣ, Ḳ:). or one which, having been submissive, or tractable, before conceiving, afterwards strikes her milker away from before her: or [the pl.] DawaAribu signifies she-camels that resist after conceiving, and become repugnant, so that one cannot milk them. (TA.)

Also, and DaAribapN, (Ḳ, TA,) the former a possessive epithet [i. e. denoting the possession of a quality], and the latter a verbal epithet [i. e. an act. part. n.], (TA,) ‡ A she-camel that raises her tail, and smites with it her vulva, (Ḳ, A, in which latter only the pl. is mentioned,) and then goes: (Ḳ:) pl. DawaAribu. (A, TA.) And the former is like tDrAb, [i. e. tiDoraAbN↓, as appears from what follows,] expl. by Lḥ as meaning † A she-camel that has been covered by the stallion, [and app. that raises her tail in consequence thereof,] but respecting which one knows not whether she be pregnant or not: (TA:) or tiDoraAbN↓ signifies a she-camel recently covered by the stallion [and therefore often raising her tail]. (Mz, 40th nwE.)

The former (DaAribN) signifies also † Swimming, (Ṣ, TA,) in water. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
layaAliIa All-ahowi yaTobiyniI faOatobaEuhu
kaOan-aniI DaAribN fiI gamorapK laEibu
[In the nights of diversion he calls me and I follow him as though I were swimming in a deep water, sporting therein]. (Ṣ, TA.)
TayorN DawaAribu ‡ Birds seeking sustenance: (Ṣ, A, TA:) or birds traversing the land, [or migrating,] in search of sustenance. (L, TA.)
See also DariybN.

DaAribN also signifies † A dark night: (Ḳ:) or a night of which the darkness extends to the right and left, and fills the world. (Ṣ, O. [So in my copies of the Ṣ and in the O and TA: but accord. to Golius, as from the Ṣ, “yet not filling the air.”]) See the verse of Homeyd cited in the first paragraph. [J cites as an ex. of the last of the meanings expl. above, and so does Ṣgh in the O, the verse in the sentence here next following.]

† Anything long: applied in this sense to a night: thus in the following verse:
waraAbaEatoniI taHota layolK DaAribi
bisaAEidK faEomK wakaf-K xaADibi
† [And that she helped me in lifting and putting on the loads, beneath the darkness of a long night, with a plump fore arm and a hand dyed with hinnà]. (TA.)

† A place, (Ṣ,) or a depressed place, (Ḳ, TA,) and a valley, (TA,) in which are trees. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) And † A piece of rugged ground extending in an oblong form in a plain, or soft, tract. (Ḳ, TA.) And † The like of a raHobap in a valley [app. meaning where the water flows into it from its two sides: see art. rHb]: pl. DawaAribu. (Ḳ.)
DaAruwbN [an irregular instrumental noun, like TaAHuwnN and some other words of the same measure,] ‡ A snare for catching birds. (A, TA.)
DutayoriybN dim. of AiDoTiraAbN, inf. n. of 8, q. v.
tiDoraAbN: see DaAribN, former half, in two places.
maDorabN is an inf. n. (Ḥam p. 129.) [See the sentence explaining the phrase Daraba fiI AlOaroDi; and also the sentence next following it, towards the close of the first paragraph.]
And it is also a noun of place [and of time, like maDoribN, which is the regular form]. (Ḥam ibid.) See the next paragraph, in five places.
maDoribN [and maDorabN↓, q. v.,] A place, or time, [the latter, as is said in the explanation of a phrase mentioned in what follows,] of beating, striking, smiting, or hitting:
and also, † a place, or time, of journeying. (KL.)
maDoribu AlZ-aribaAni means † The line, or long mark, upon the face of the animal called ZrbAn [as though it were a place upon which it had been struck]. (TA in art. Zrb, q. v.)
And maDoribN, † A place where a tent is pitched, or set up. (Mṣb.)
See also miDorabN.

Also, (thus in the TA in art. swf, as from the A,) or maDorabN↓, (thus in a copy of the A in the present art.,) ‡ i. q. masaAfapN [meaning A space, or tract, or an extent, over which one journeys; as being a place of beating the ground]: so in the saying, bayonahumo maDorabN↓ baEiydN [or maDoribN, i. e. ‡ Between them is a far-extending space to be traversed]. (A.)

[maDoribu EasalapK is a euphemism for † The place of injection of sperma: and hence it means † the source from which one springs; origin, ancestry, or parentage;, &c.] One says, maA OaEorifu lahu maDoriba EasalapK (Ṣ, A) meaning OaEoraAqahu [i. e. ‡ I know not the sources (or the source) from which he has sprung; or his ancestry, or parentage]: (Ṣ:) or maA yuEorafu lahu maDoribu EasalapK ‡ No source or origin [or parentage], nor people, nor ancestor or father, nor nobility, pertaining to him, is know. (M, Ḳ, TA.) And maA lifulaAnK maDoribu EasalapK (Ṣ, A, in the latter lizayodK,) i. e. ‡ [Such a one has no source] of kindred (nasab), nor of cattle or property (maAl). (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lakariymu AlmaDoribi ‡ [Verily he is generous in respect of origin]. (A, TA.) [See also DariybapN.]
One says also, Oatati Aln-aAqapu EalaI maDoribihaA, meaning † The she-camel arrived at the time [of year] of her being leaped by the stallion; making the time to be like the place. (Ṣ.)

maDoribN, (Ṣ, A, O, and so in the M in art. rm,) or maDorabN↓, (Ḳ,* TA,) with fet-ḥ to the m, (Ḳ, TA,) and to the r also, (TA,) [but this is app. a mistake, as the weight of authority is in favour of the former,] † A bone in which is marrow: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a bone that is broken and from which marrow is extracted [or sought to be extracted]. (M in art. rm.) One says, of a sheep or goat, (Ṣ, A,) that is emaciated, (Ṣ,) maA yurim-u minohaA maDoribN ‡ [Not a bone of her that is broken for its marrow contains any marrow]; i. e. when a bone of her is broken, no marrow will be found in it. (Ṣ, A.)

And maDoribN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDorabN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDoribapN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDorabapN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and maDorubapN↓ (Sb, TA) signify The part of a sword, with which one strikes: (Mṣb, and Ḥam p. 129:) or [the part] about a span from the extremity: (Ṣ, TA:) or the part exclusive of, or below, the Zubap [q. v.] (duwna AlT-ubapi): (TA:) or the edge (Had-) thereof; (Ḳ, TA;) thus expl. by several of the leading lexicologists: (TA:) and so DariybapN↓: which last also signifies a sword: (Ḳ:) [i. e.] a sword itself is sometimes thus called, as ISd says: (TA:) the pl. of maDoribN is maDaAribu. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)

[maDoribu mavalK means † The secondary idea, or thing, signified by a parable or proverb, and compared to the primary idea, or thing; the thing, or case, to which a parable or proverb is applied: correlative of maworidu mavalK: pl. maDaAribu.]
And [the pl.] maDaAribu signifies † Stratagems in war. (IAạr, TA.)
muDoribN [part. n. of OaDoraba, q. v.]. You say, raOayotu Hay-apF muDoribFA (Ṣ, TA) and muDoribapF (TA) ‡ I saw a serpent still, not moving. (Ṣ, TA.)

And, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as an epithet applied to a man, (Ṣ, A,) it signifies Xadiydu AlD-arobi [One who beats, strikes, smites, or hits, vehemently]; (Ṣ, O;) or kaviyru AlD-arobi [one who beats,, &c., much]; as also DaruwbN↓ (A, Ḳ) and Dar-aAbN↓ (A) and DariybN↓ (Ḳ, TA) and DaribN↓. (O, Ḳ, TA. [But in none of these lexicons is this signification mentioned in such a manner as to show that it necessarily relates to any but the first of these words, namely, miDorabN: that it does so, however, is indicated by the measures of all of them.])

Also, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or maDoribN↓, with fet-ḥ to the m and kesr to the r, (Mgh,) [thus] written like majolisN by MF, and pronounced by the vulgar maDorab, but both of these are [said to be] incorrect, (TA,) A [tent such as is called] qub-ap: (Mgh:) or a great [tent of the kind called] fusoTaAT; (O, Ḳ, TA;) the fsTAT of a king: (TA:) pl. maDaAribu. (Mgh, TA.)
maDoribapN and maDorabapN and maDorubapN: see maDoribN.
muDar-abN Sewed [meaning quilted] with cotton: applied in this sense to a bisaAT [or thing that is spread like a carpet, &c.]. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
muDar-abapN [a subst. signifying A quilt; a quilted garment and the like: see 2]. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)

miDoraAbN The thing [i. e. plectrum] with which a lute (Euwd) is struck [or played]: (Ṣ:) pl. maDaAriybu. (TA in art. Trb.) [See an ex. voce Tarwb. The plectrum commonly used for this purpose in the present day is a slip of a vulture's feather, and is termed riyXapN: see the chap. on music in my “Modern Egyptians.”]
See also miDorabN.

maDoruwbN: see DarobN and DariybN, the latter in two places. Dhu-r-Rummeh says, speaking of a cake of bread (xubozap),
wamaDoruwbapK fiI gayori canobK bariyYapi
kasarotu liQSoHaAbiI EalaI EajalK kasoraA
[Many a thing (meaning many a cake of bread) beaten for no offence, free from blame, I have broken for my companions in haste, with a vigorous breaking]. (TA, after explaining the phrase OaDoraba Alxubozu [q. v.].)
Also † Staying, abiding, or remaining, [fixed, or settled,] in a tent, or house. (TA.)

muDaAribN One who is employed by another to traffic for him with his (the latter's) property, on the condition of their sharing the gain together: and also one who employs another to traffic for him with his (the former's) property, on that condition: thus expl. by En-Naḍr; and Az also allows the use of the word in these two senses. (TA.)
muDoTarabN may mean AiDoTaraAbN [i. e. it may be used as an inf. n. of AiDoTaraba (q. v.), agreeably with a general rule]:

and it may mean A place of AiDoTiraAb: (Ḥam p. 142:) [thus used it often means a place in which one goes to and fro seeking the means of subsistence: and simply a place in which one seeks gain: see AiDoTaraba fiI Oumuwrihi: and see also the syns. muraAgamN (in two places) and munotafadN.]
[It is also a pass. part. n.: and hence the phrase muDoTarabaAtN lilomaEaAXi, meaning The things that are desired to be gained for subsistence, or sustenance: see maraAgibu.]
muDoTaribN [A thing having its several parts in a state of collision: and hence, a thing, and a man, in a state of commotion, agitation, convulsion,, &c.: see its verb, 8].
One says, jaMCa muDoTariba AlEinaAni [lit. He came with quivering rein]; meaning he came discomfited, or put to flight, and alone. (Ḳ.)
And rajulN muDoTaribu Alxaloqi ‡ A man incongruous, unsound, faulty, or weak, in respect of make: (A, TA:) tall, and [loose, lax, flabby, uncompact, slack, shaky, or] not strong of make. (TA.)
And HadiyvN muDoTaribu Als-anadi † A tradition unsound, faulty, or weak, in respect of the authority upon which it rests, or to which it is traced up or ascribed; syn. muxotal-N. (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Darajahu, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaDoriju}, (O,) or _u, (L,) inf. n. DarojN, (O, L,) He split it, slit it, or rent it asunder or open; (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) and so Dr-jhu↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things, inf. n. taDoriyjN]; namely, a garment, &c. (L.) [Hence,] Daraja Aln-aAra i. q. fataHa lahaA EayonFA [i. e. He made an opening in the live coals of the fire, in order that it might burn up well]. (AḤn, TA.)

And He smeared it, daubed it, or defiled it; (O, L, Ḳ;) and so Dr-jhu↓ [but app., in this case also, in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things]; namely, a garment, (A, L,), &c., (L,) with blood, (A, L,) or with something similar thereto, that was red, or with something yellow. (L.)
And He threw it, or threw it down. (Ḳ.)

Darajato bijir-tihaA and jaraDato [signify the same, i. e. She was choked with her cud; or she swallowed her cud with difficulty; the former verb being app. formed by transposition from the latter; but jariDato seems to be better known than jaraDato]; said of a camel. (O, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see above {1}, in two places.
One says also, Dr-j Oanofaha bidamK, (Ṣ, O,) or biAld-ami, (Ḳ,) He made his nose to bleed. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

And Dr-j Alv-awoba, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoriyjN, (Ṣ, O,) He dyed the garment, or piece of cloth, of a red colour, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) making it less fully dyed than that which is termed muXobaE, and more so than that which is termed muwar-ad. (Ṣ, O.)
[Hence,] Dr-j AlkalaAma, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (O,) ‡ He embellished the speech, (A, O, Ḳ,) and amplified it, (A,) as one does in excuses, or pleas, (O,) with truth, or with falsehood. (A, O.)

Dr-jt jayobahaA She (a woman) loosened her jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom of her shift or the like, so that the edges were not drawn together, or buttoned]. (O, Ḳ:* in the latter, Dr-j Aljayoba, inf. n. as above.)
Dr-jnA AlUibila We urged on the camels, in making a hostile, or predatory, incursion. (O, Ḳ.*)
5: see 7, in four places.

tDr-j also signifies It (a garment, A, L) became smeared, daubed, or defiled, (Ṣ, A, O, L, Ḳ,) with blood, (Ṣ, A, O, L,) or with something similar thereto, that was red, or with something yellow. (L.)
And tDr-j Alxad-u ‡ The cheek became red, (O, Ḳ, TA,) on an occasion of shame. (O.) You say, kal-amotuhu fataDar-aja xad-aAhu ‡ I spoke to him and his cheeks became red. (A,* TA.)
And tDr-jt AlmaroOapu ‡ The woman displayed her finery, or ornaments, and beauties of person or form or countenance, to men, (A, O, Ḳ, TA,) and embellished herself. (A, TA.)

7. AnDrj It (a thing, or garment, &c., L) split, slit, or rent asunder or open; (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ;) as also AnDrj; (TA in art. DrH;) and so tDr-j↓ [but app. in an intensive sense, or said of a number of things]: (L:) the latter is said of a garment in the former sense; (TA;) or as meaning it became much rent, or rent in several places. (L.) When the fruits of herbs, or leguminous plants, appear, one says, AinoDarajato EanohaA lafaAYifuhaA and OakomaAmuhaA [i. e. Their envelopes, or pericarps, and their calyxes, rent asunder or open, so as to disclose them]. (A, TA. [And the like is said in the Ṣ and O.]) And one says also, taDar-ajato↓ Eani Albaqoli lafaAYifuhu, meaning AinofataHat [i. e. The envelopes, or pericarps, of the herbs, or leguminous plants, opened so as to disclose what was within them]. (Ṣ, O.)
And tDr-j↓ Aln-aworu The blossoms opened. (Ḳ.) And AnDrj AlX-ajaru The buds of the trees burst open and the extremities of the leaves appeared. (L.) And tDr-j↓ said of lightning means taXaq-aqa [i. e. It clave the clouds, and extended high, into the midst of the sky; or it was in a state of commotion in the clouds; or it spread wide and long]. (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ.)

Also It was, or became, wide, or ample. (El-Muärrij, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) You say, AnDrjt lanaA AlT-ariyqu The road was, or became, wide to us. (TA.) And AnDrj maA bayona Alqawomi The space between the people was, or became, far-extending: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) and so AnDrj. (Ṣ in art. DrH.)
AnDrjt AlEuqaAbu The eagle darted down upon the prey: (O, Ḳ:) or betook itself, or advanced, to it: (O:) or took a sidelong course to it. (O, Ḳ.*)

DarijN A garment, or piece of cloth, smeared with a red, or yellow, colour; as also UiDoriyjN↓: or this latter is only [applied to a garment, or piece of cloth,] of [the kind called] xaz-. (TA.) [And Dariju AlOanaAmili means Having the ends of the fingers smeared, or defiled, by blood: see Ḥam p. 799.]
DarojapN and DarajapN A species of bird. (TA.)
EadowN DariyjN A vehement running. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: UiDoriyjN A yellow [garment of the kind called] kisaMC; (Ḳ;) a yellow sort of Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC]: (Ṣ, O:) or a ksMC made of excellent [down of the kind called] miroEiz-aI: (TA:) or Oakosiyap made of the best of miroEiz-aI: (Lth, O, TA:) and, (O, Ḳ,) accord. to Lḥ, (TA,) red [cloth of the kind called] xaz-: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and Oakosiyapu AlUiDoriyji signifies the Aksyp of red xaz-; (A, TA;) or of yellow xaz-. (TA. See also DarijN.) And vawobN UiDoriyjN A garment saturated with redness. (A.)
And A red dye: (O, Ḳ, TA:) so it is said to signify: and hence vuwobN muDar-ajN↓ [meaning A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed of a red colour in the manner expl. voce Dr-j]. (TA.)

And A horse that is swift and excellent; or swift, or excellent, in running; (AO, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) vehement in running; (Ṣ, O, TA;) or having a large mane: (AO, TA:) or wide in the labaAn [or breast, or middle of the breast]. (TA.)

entry.sense: miDorajN: see its pl., maDaAriju, below.
muDar-ajN: see UiDoriyjN.
muDar-aju Alxad-ayoni ‡ Having the cheeks made red. (A,* TA.)
AlmuDar-aju, (so in the O,) or AlmuDar-iju↓, (so accord. to the Ḳ, there said to be like muHad-iv,) The lion. (O, Ḳ.)
AlmuDar-iju: see what next precedes.
EayonN maDoruwjapN An eye wide in the fissure: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) a wide eye. (A.)

hom.sense:
maDaAriju i. q. maXaAq-u [i. e. Fissures; lit. places of slitting: pl. of maXaq-N]. (O, Ḳ.) Himyán Ibn-Koháfeh Es-Saadee says, describing the tushes of a stallion-camel,
OawosaEona mino OaXodaAqihi AlmaDaArijaA
[That widened the fissures of the sides of his mouth]. (O.)
Also Old and worn-out garments, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) that are used for service and work, like what are called maEaAwizu: sing. miDorajN↓. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O.)

1. DaraHahu, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDoraHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DaroHN, (Ṣ, A, O, L,) He removed it from its place; put it away or aside; pushed, or thrust, it away: (Ṣ, A,* O, L, Ḳ:) he took it, and threw it away or aside: (L:) he pushed it, or thrust it, away with his foot: (Expos. of the “Amálee” of El-Ḳálee:) [and] DaraHa biAlX-aIoCi [if not a mistranscription for DrH AlX-aIoCa] He threw [from him] the thing; and put it away or aside: and DaraHa Eanohu Alv-awoba He cast off from him the garment. (A.) See also 4. [And see 8.] [Hence] DaraHotu Ean-iI XahaAdapa Alqawomi ‡ I invalidated the testimony of the people or party, or annulled its claim to credibility, (jaraHotuhaA,) and cast it from me, or rejected it: (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:*) said by one against whom false witness has been borne, and who has shown its falseness. (A.)

And DaraHati Ald-aAb-apu birijolihaA, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDoraHu}, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. DaroHN (Ṣ, O) and DiraAHN, (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ,) this latter from Sb, (TA,) [but it seems to be implied in the Ḳ that the verb with DiraAHN for its inf. n. has its aor., as well as this inf. n., like that of kataba, which I do not think to be the case,] The beast kicked with its hind leg: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or AlD-aroHu is with the fore legs; and Alr-amoHu, with the hind legs. (TA.) One says, fiyhaA DiraAHN [It has a habit of kicking with the hind leg: or, with the fore leg]; a phrase mentioned by I’Ab. (Ṣ.)
DaraHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or DaraHa DariyHFA, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yaDoraHu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. DaroHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He dug a DariyH [q. v.], (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) lilomay-iti [for the corpse]. (A,* Ḳ.)

DaraHa, inf. n. DaroHN, also signifies [He clave the ground; (see DariyHN;) and] he split, slit, or rent asunder or open, anything; like Daraja, with j: (TA:) but the phrase DaraHonaA Alburuwda, in a verse of Dhur-r-Rummeh, as some relate it, is expl. by AA as meaning We threw off the [garments called] brwd: others relate it with j; and in this case he says that it means “we rent asunder” or “open.” (Az, O, TA.)
DaraHa [as though quasi-pass. of DaraHahu] signifies also He, or it, was, or became, distant, or remote; or removed to a distance; went far away. (L.) [See also 7.]
And DaraHati Als-uwqu, inf. n. DuruwHN (O, Ḳ, TA) and DaroHN, (TA,) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 3. DArHhu i. q. saAb-ahu and raAmaAhu; (O, Ḳ;) i. e. DArHhu and sAb-hu and rAmAhu are [all] one [in signification, app. meaning He reviled him, or vilified him, being reviled, or vilified, by him; so that the last seems to be here used tropically]. (TA.)
And i. q. qaArabahu [He drew him near to him]; (O, Ḳ;) namely, his companion. (O.)
Also, inf. n. muDaAraHapN, He, or it, resembled, and corresponded to, him, or it; syn. DaAraEahu and qaAbalahu. (TA. [See AlD-uraAHu.])

4. ADrH i. q. OaboEada: (Ḳ:) you say, OaDoriHohu Eanoka, (so accord. to two copies of the Ṣ,) or ADoraHohu↓, (so in one of my copies of the Ṣ, [i. e. AiDoraHohu, from DaraHahu, in my other copy of the Ṣ ADorHohu, so that the correct form of the verb in this sense is doubtful,]) meaning OaboEidohu [i. e. Remove thou, or put far away, him, or it, from thee]. (Ṣ.) [In the TA, it is also expl. as meaning dafaEa, which is likewise a signification of DaraHa.]
And He corrupted, or vitiated, (O, Ḳ,) him, or it. (O.)
And OaDoraHotu Als-uwqa I made, or found, the market to be stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic; syn. OakosadotuhaA. (O, Ḳ.*)
7. AnDrH It was, or became, wide, or ample. (TA.) You say, AnDrH maA bayona Alqawomi The space between the people was, or became, far-extending: like AnDrj. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
Also It split, slit, or rent asunder or open: like AnDrj. (TA.)

8. ADTrHwA fulaAnFA They cast such a one aside: (O,* L, TA: [see also 1, first sentence:]) the vulgar say AiT-araHuwA, thinking it to be from AlT-aroHu, whereas it is from AlD-aroHu: or, accord. to Az, it may be that, in AT-rHwA, the t of the measure AifotaEala is changed into T, and D incorporated into it. (L, TA.)

hom.sense: DaroHN inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, A, &c.)
bayoniI wabayonahumo DaroHN means Between me and them is a wide distance, and solitude. (TA.)
Also A skin. (O, Ḳ.)
niy-apN DaraHN i. q. baEiydapN [app. meaning A distant, or remote, thing, or place, that is the object of an action or a journey:, &c.]; (O, Ḳ;) as also TaraHN, &c. (O.)
DaraHN applied to a man, Bad, corrupt, or vitious. (El-Muärrij, O, Ḳ.)
AlD-araHu is also used by poetic license for [the inf. n.] AlD-aroHu. (O.)

entry.sense: DaraAHi, like qaTaAmi, (Ḳ, TA,) is a verbal noun like nazaAli, (TA,) meaning AiDoraHo, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. AuboEudo: you say, DaraAHi Eanohu Remove thou to a distance, or go far away, from him, or it. (TA.)

AlD-uraAHu, (O, Ḳ, TA,) or, accord. to Mujáhid, AlD-ariyHu↓, (O, TA,*) [The temple called] Albayotu AlmaEomuwru, (O, Ḳ, TA,) corresponding to, or over against, [i. e. directly over,] the Kaabeh, (O, TA,) in Heaven, (O,) in the Fourth Heaven, (Ḳ, TA,) or in the Seventh, or in the Sixth, and said to be beneath the EaroX, or in the First Heaven: (TA:) accord. to ʼAlee, it is entered every day by seventy thousand angels. (O.)

qawosN DaruwHN A bow that propels the arrow with vehemence; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;*) as also TaruwHN [q. v.]. (Ṣ and O and Ḳ in art. TrH.) And daAb-apN DaruwHN A beast that kicks with its hind leg (Ṣ, Ḳ) [or with its fore legs: see 1].
DariyHN Distant, or remote: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)

Also A trench, or an oblong excavation, in the middle of a grave; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so DariyHapN↓: (TA:) in this sense [likewise] of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mṣb:) what is termed laHodN is in the side: (Ṣ:) or a grave (Ḳ, TA) altogether: (TA:) or a grave without a laHod: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. DaraAYiHu. (Mṣb.) One says, naw-ara Qll-ehu DariyHahu (A, TA) i. e. [May God illumine] his grave. (TA.)
See also AlD-uraAHu.
DariyHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
maDoraHN: see maDoraHiI-N.
miDoraHN A garment, or piece of cloth, or other thing, used as a repository for clothes: pl. maDaAriHu. (O.)

maDoraHiI-N A hawk, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) and a vulture, (A,) having long wings; (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ;) as also maDoraHN↓; (O, Ḳ;) but the former is the more common: a hawk of this description is of an excellent kind: (TA:) and to the wings of the vulture of this sort is likened the extremity of the tail of a she-camel with the coarse hairs that are upon it: (Kf, TA:) or white, applied to a hawk and to a vulture; (A;) or thus, applied to a vulture; and sometimes, so applied, black: (Ḥam p. 95:) or a vulture intensely red [or brown]: (AḤát, O:) [and a hawk in which is redness; otherwise it is not thus called: (so in the Deewán of Jereer, accord. to Freytag:)] or i. q. OajodalN and SaqorN and qaTaAmiI-N: (AʼObeyd, TA:) [it is mentioned in the Ḳ again in art. mDrH; for,] accord. to some, the m is radical: (TA in art. mDrH:) or, applied to a hawk, it means that darts down sideways; or that thrusts the prey. (Ḥam ubi suprà.)
[Hence,] ‡ A chief, (Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ,) such as is generous, or noble, (Ḳ,) or of ancient (A, O) and generous (O) origin. (A, O.)
Also White as an epithet applied to anything. (Ḳ.)
And ‡ Tall, or long. (Ḳ, TA.)
XaIoCN muDoTaraHN A thing cast aside. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8. AiDoTarada, as though from Darada: see 8 in art. Trd.

hom.sense: 1. Darasahu, (A, TA,) aor. _i {yaDorisu}, (TA,) inf. n. DarosN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He bit it: (TA:) or he bit it vehemently with the OaDoraAs [pl. of DirosN, q. v.]; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also Dr-shu↓: (A:) or with the Daros. (T, TA.)
He (a beast of prey) chewed his flesh, (i. e., the flesh of his prey,) without swallowing it; (A;) as also Dr-shu↓. (A, TA.)
He bit it (namely an arrow) to try it; to know if it were hard or weak: (Ṣ:) he marked it (namely an arrow) by biting it with his OaDoraAs, (M, A,) or with his teeth. (Az, TA.)
† He tried him with respect to his claims to knowledge or courage. (IAạr.)
Darasatohu AlHuruwbu, inf. n. DarosN, ‡ Wars tried, or proved, him, and rendered him expert, or strong; (TA;) as also Dr-sthu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoriysN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Darasahumu Alz-amaAnu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. DarosN, (Ḳ,) ‡ Fortune became severe, rigorous, afflictive, or adverse, to them; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;*) as also Dr-shm↓. (A, TA.)
Darasa naAbuhaA ‡ She was evil in disposition: (TA:) and DarosN [alone] the being evil in disposition. (IAạr.)
DarosN also signifies † The biting of blame, or reprehension. (IAạr.)
And ‡ The keeping silence during a day, until the night: (O, Ḳ, TA:) as though biting one's tongue. (TA.)

And Darasa AlbiYora, aor. _i {yaDorisu} (O, Ḳ, TA) and _u {yaDorusu}, (TA,) inf. n. DarosN, (O, TA,) † He cased the well with stones: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, he closed up the interstices of its casing with stones: and in like manner one says of any building. (TA.)

Darisato OasonaAnuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDorasu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DarasN, (Ṣ,) His teeth were set on edge (kal-ato) by eating or drinking what was acid, or sour. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.) And Darisa Alr-ajulu The man's teeth were set on edge. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Wahb Ibn-Munebbih, that a certain bastard, of the Children of Israel, offered an offering, and it was rejected; whereupon he said, yaA rab-i yaOokulu OabawaAIa AlHamoDa waOaDorasu OanaA Oanota Oakoramu mino celika [O my Lord, my two parents eat sour herbage, and are my teeth set on edge? Thou art more gracious than to suffer that]: and his offering was accepted. (O in art. HmD.) [See Jer., xxxi. 29; and Ezek., xviii. 2.]
Also Darisa, inf. n. DarasN, ‡ He was angry by reason of hunger: because hunger sharpens the OaDoraAs. (TA.)
And DarisuwA biAlHarobi † They persisted in war until they fought one another. (T, O, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Dr-shu inf. n. taDoriysN: see Darasahu, in five places.
taDoriysN also signifies ‡ An indentation, or serration, (Az, TA,) like OaDoraAs, (TA,) in a sapphire (yaAquwtap) and a pearl, or in wood. (Az, TA.)

hom.sense: 3. DaArasotu AlOumuwra ‡ I became experienced in affairs, and knew them. (T, TṢ.)

DArswA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muDaArasapN and DiraAsN; so in the Tekmileh; but in the M, tDArswA↓; (TA;) ‡ They warred, or fought, one against another, and treated one another with enmity, or hostility: (Ḳ, TA:) from DarasN, [inf. n. of Darisa,] signifying the “being angry by reason of hunger.” (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. ADrshu It (acid, or sour, food, or drink,) set his teeth on edge; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;*) syn. Oakal-a OasonaAnahu. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.) [And so, app., ADrs OasonaAnahu.]
Also ‡ He, or it, (an affair, or event, Ṣ,) disquieted him. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.)
And ADrshu biAlkalaAmi † He silenced him by speech. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
5: see what next follows {6}.

hom.sense: 6. tDArs, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in the M tDr-s↓, (TA,) ‡ It (a building) was, or became, uneven, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and irregular, (A,) having in it what resembled OaDoraAs. (M.)
tDArswA: see 3.

entry.sense: DarosN † Land of which the herbage is here and there (IAạr, T, O, Ḳ, TA) and on which rain has fallen here and there: (IAạr, T, TA:) and a portion of land upon which rain has fallen a day or part of a day. (TA.)
See also DirosN.

hom.sense:
DirosN A tooth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OaDoraAsN, and (sometimes, Ṣ, Mṣb) DuruwsN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaDorusN [which is a pl. of pauc., as is also, properly, the first of the pls. here mentioned]; and quasi-pl. n. Drs [written in the TA without any syll. signs, so that it may be DarosN, or DirosN (like the sing.), or DarasN]; so in the M [of which I am unable to consult the portion containing this art.]: (TA:) or [a lateral tooth; for] the ADrAs are the teeth, except the central incisors: (Mgh:) or [this explanation, which I find only in the Mgh, is incomplete, and the word sometimes means the teeth absolutely, but properly] the molar teeth, or grinders, which are twenty in number, [including the bicuspids,] next behind the canine teeth: (Zj, in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or i. q. OaroHaMCN: (Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ, art. rHI: [see sin-N: and see also rabaAEiyapN:]) DirosN is masc.; (Mgh, Ḳ;) and sometimes fem.: (Mgh:) or what is thus called is masc. when thus called; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) but if called sin-N, it is fem.: (Mṣb:) or it is properly masc.; and if found in poetry made fem., sin-N is meant thereby: (Zj, Mṣb:) but Aṣ denies its being made fem.; (Mṣb, TA;) and as to the saying ascribed to Dukeyn,
fafuqiYato EayonN waTan-ato Dirosu
[And an eye was put out, and a tooth, or grinder, sounded], he says that the right reading is waTan-a AlD-irosu [and the tooth, or grinder, sounded], and that he who heard these words understood them not. (TA.) What are called OaDoraAsu AlEaqoli and OaDoraAsu AlHulum [The wisdom-teeth, and the teeth of puberty] are four: they come forth after the [other] teeth have become strong. (TA. [See naAjicN.])
[Hence,] sing. of DuruwsN (Ḳ) which signifies † The stones with which a well is cased. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And † A finod [app. as meaning a peak, or the like,] in a mountain. (TA.)

And † A rough [hill, or eminence, or elevated place, such as is termed] Oakamap (T, O, Ḳ, TA) and [such as is termed] OaxoXab: (T, TA:) or rough ground; written by Ṣgh DarosN↓: (IAạr, TA:) or a portion of a [tract such as is termed] quf-, somewhat elevated, very rugged, rough to the tread, consisting of a single piece of stone [or rock], unmixed with clay, or soil, and not giving growth to anything: pl. DuruwsN. (TA.)

Also ‡ Light rain: (IAạr, TA:) or a rain little in quantity: (Ṣ, O:) or a light rain: pl. DuruwsN: (Ḳ:) or DuruwsN mino maTarK means scattered rains: (Aṣ, TA:) or scattered showers of rain: (Ṣ, O:) and some say, i. q. judur [app. a mistranscription, probably for xadarN, which signifies rain; or clouds, or mist, and rain]: and [it is. said that] DirosN signifies also a raining cloud that has not [much] width. (TA.)
See also muDar-asN, last sentence.

entry.sense: DarisN A man having his teeth set on edge. (TA.)

And ‡ A man angry by reason of hunger; (AZ, Ḳ, TA;) because hunger sharpens the OaDoraAs: (TA:) and DariysN↓ signifies † very hungry; (Ḳ, TA;) so that there is nothing that comes to him but he eats it, by reason of hunger: (TA:) pl. of the latter DaraAsaI, like as HazaAnaI is a pl. of HaziynN. (Ḳ.)

And ‡ A man (Ṣ, A, O) refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (Yz, Ṣ, A, O, Ḳ:) evil in disposition, or illnatured, and very perverse or cross or repugnant and averse; syn. XarisN. (Ḳ.) You say rajulN DarisN XarisN. (Yz, Ṣ, A, O.) [See DaruwsN.]
See also muDar-asN, last sentence.
DirosapN Ruggedness, and roughness. (TA.)
DuraAsN Toothache. (MA.)
DiraAsN [seems to signify, properly, A disposition to bite].

[Hence,] Aln-aAqapu bijin-i DiraAsihaA means † The she-camel is in the case of the recentness of her bringing forth, when she defends her young one; from the epithet DaruwsN; (Ṣ, Meyd, O; but in the Ṣ and O, hiIa, referring to the she-camel, is put in the place of AlnAqp;) and is a prov., applied to the man whose nature is evil on the occasion of his defending. (Meyd.) And one says, Ait-aqi Aln-aAqapa bijin-i DiraAsihaA, meaning ‡ Beware thou of the she-camel in the case of the recentness of her bringing forth, and of her evil disposition towards him who approaches her, by reason of her attachment to her young one. (A, TA.) [In the TA, in art. jn, this saying is mentioned with DiraAmihaA in the place of DiraAsihaA: the former may perhaps be another reading; but I rather think that it is a mistranscription for the latter. And in the present art. in the TA, it is added that Ṣgh has mentioned (app. in the TṢ, for he has not done so in the O,) El-Báhilee's having explained AlD-iraAsu as meaning siyomN lhm; and that it is likewise explained in the T as meaning siyomN: but I know no such word as siyomN; nor do I know any word of which it is likely to be a mistranscription, though I have diligently searched for such. This word siyomN has been altered by the copyist in each instance in the TA; so that it seems to have been indistinctly written by the author.]
[Hence also] DiraAsu AlHarobi † The biting of war. (Ḥam p. 532.)

hom.sense: DaruwsN A she-camel of evil disposition, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that bites her milker: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or that has a habit of biting to defend her young one. (TA.)
[Hence,] HarobN DaruwsN ‡ Devouring, biting, war: (TA:) or vehement war. (Ḥam p. 87.)
And A she-camel whose flow, or stream, of milk does not make any sound to be heard. (TA.)
DariysN † Stones resembling OaDoraAs [i. e. teeth or lateral teeth or molar teeth]: with such, a well is cased. (TA.)
And † The vertebræ of the back. (O, Ḳ.)
Also, and maDoruwsapN↓, † A well (biYorN) cased with stones. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also DarisN.

entry.sense: OaDorasu an imitative sequent to Oaxorasu as an epithet applied to a man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: muDar-asN † A sort of figured cloth or garment, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) having upon it forms resembling OaDoraAs [i. e. teeth or lateral teeth or molar teeth], (Ḳ,) or thought by IF to be thus called because having upon it such forms: (O:) or, applied as an epithet to [the kind of garments called] rayoT, as meaning figured with the marks of folding: or meaning folded in a square form: or, as some say, muDar-asapN signifies a sort of cloths, or garments, upon which are lines and ornamental borders. (TA.)
And † An arrow that is not smooth, or even; because it has in it what resemble OaDoraAs. (TA.)
And Hr-apN muDar-asapN and maDoruwsapN↓ † [A stony tract] in which are stones like the OaDoraAs of dogs. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: AlmuDar-isu The lion, that chews the flesh of his prey without swallowing it: (O, Ḳ:) or the lion; so called because he does thus. (TA.)
maDoruwsapN: see DariysN: and also muDar-asN.

1. DaraTa, aor. _i {yaDoriTu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and DariTa, aor. _a {yaDoraTu}; (Mṣb;) inf. n. DariTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, in the Mṣb said to be of the latter verb,) and DaroTN (Mṣb, Ḳ, in the Mṣb said to be of the former verb,) and DariyTN and DuraATN, (Ḳ,) or the last is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) [a coarse word, signifying] He broke wind, i. e. emitted wind from the anus, with a sound. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [When it is without sound, you say fasaA.] Hence the prov., OawodaI AlEayoru Uil-aA DariTFA The ass had no power remaining except [that of] emitting wind from the anus, with a sound: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) applied to a vile, or an abject, person, and to an old man; and in allusion to a thing's becoming in a bad, or corrupt, state, so that there remains of it nothing but what is of no use: (Ḳ:) the last word is in the accus. case as denoting a thing of a different kind from that signified by the preceding noun. (O.) And Oajobanu mina Almanozuwfi DariTFA [More cowardly than he who is exhausted by emitting wind from the anus, with a sound]: another prov.: [its origin is variously related: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 320:] or Almanozuwfu DariTFA [or DaroTFA, for it is differently written in different copies of the Ḳ,] is a certain beast, between the dog and the cat, (Ḳ,) or between the dog and the wolf, (O,) which, when one cries out at it, emits wind from the anus, with a sound, by reason of cowardice. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
2: see 4, in two places.
4. ADrThu, and Dr-Thu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) He made him to emit wind from the anus, with a sound: (Ṣ:) or he did to him that which caused him to emit wind from the anus, with a sound. (O, Ḳ.)

ADrT bihi; and Dr-T↓ bh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoriyTN; (Ḳ) He derided him, and imitated to him with his mouth the action of one emitting wind from the anus, with a sound; (Ṣ;) he made to him with his mouth a sound like that of an emission of wind from the anus, and derided him. (Ḳ,* TA.) ADrT biAls-aAYili, said in a trad., of ʼAlee, means He treated the asker with contempt, disapproving what he said; he derided him. (TA.)
DariTN: part. n. of DariTa. (Mṣb.)

DaroTapN [inf. n. un. of 1; A single emission of wind from the anus, making a sound]. It is said in a prov., of him who has done a deed of which he has not done the like before nor after, kaAnato minohu kaDaroTapi AlOaSam-i [There proceeded from him what was like the DrTh of the deaf]. (Ṣgh, TA.)
DuraATN An emission of wind from the anus, with a sound: (Ṣ, TA:) or the sound thereof: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, Sawotu AlfaqoHi is put for Sawotu Alfayoxi:]) a subst. from 1. (Mṣb.)
DaruwTN: see Dar-aATN.
DurayoTN: see sur-ayoTaI.
DurayoTaI: see sur-ayoTaI.
DurayoTaMCu: see sur-ayoTaI.

Dar-aATN and DaruwTN↓ and Dir-awoTN↓ are all [intensive] epithets from 1; (Ḳ;) [signifying One who emits wind from the anus, with a sound, much, or frequently;] the last mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)
Dir-awoTN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Dur-ayoTN: see sur-ayoTaI.
Dur-ayoTaI: see sur-ayoTaI.
Dir-iyTaI: see sur-ayoTaI.
OaDoraTu: see OaToraTu, in art. TrT.

muDar-iTu AlHijaArapi † [as though signifying He who makes the stones to emit sounds, from fear:] an appellation given to ʼAmr Ibn-Hind, because of his strength and hardiness and courage, (Ṣ,) or because of the awe which he inspired. (A, TA.)
1. DaraEa, said of a lamb or kid, He took [with his mouth] the DaroE [meaning dug] of his mother. (TA.) [This seems to be regarded by some as the primary signification.]

And (TA) the same, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a man, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yaDoraEu}; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and DariEa, aor. _a {yaDoraEu} and DaruEa, aor. _u {yaDoruEu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) of the first (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and of the third (TA) DaraAEapN, (Ṣ Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (Ḳ) of the second (TA) DaraEN; (Ḳ;) He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and low, abject, or abased; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) Uilayohi (Ḳ) and lahu [to him]: (TA:) or DariEa and DaraEa signify he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself, (Ḳ,* TA,) [like tDr-E, which is more commonly used in this sense,] and made petition for a gift: (TA:) and DaruEa, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. DaraEN, (Mṣb,) or DaraAEapN, (TA,) he was, or became, weak; (Ḳ, TA;) and it is said that the verb in this last sense is from DaraEa in the sense expl. in the first sentence: so in the “Mufradát” [of Er-Rághib]: DariEa, likewise, like fariHa [in measure], signifies he was, or became, weak in body, slender, spare, or light of flesh: and DuruwEN, [app. as an inf. n. of which the verb is DaraEa,] the being lean, or emaciated. (TA.) For another explanation of DaraAEapN, see 5.
[DaraEa is made trans. by means of b:] one says, DaraEa bihi farasuhu His horse humbled him, or abased him: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or, as in the L, overcame him. (TA.)
DaraEa minohu, said of an animal of prey, (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. DuruwEN, (Ḳ,) He approached (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ, TA) him i. e. a man, (IḲṭṭ, TA,) or it i. e. a thing. (Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph {2}.

2. taDoriyEN signifies The drawing near, or approaching, by little and little, in a deceitful, or guileful, manner, going this way and that, or to the right and left; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) as also taDar-uEN↓: (Ḳ:) you say Dar-aEa and taDar-aEa. (O, TA.)

And Dar-aEati AlX-amosu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O,) ‡ The sun approached the setting; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [like Dj-Et;] and DaraEat↓ signifies the same; [like DajaEat;] or the sun set; (Ḳ;) and DaAriEati↓ AlX-amosu, inf. n. muDaAraEapN, signifies the same as DaraEat and Dr-Et. (TA.)

And Dar-aEati Alqidoru i. q. HaAna Oano tudorika [i. e. The cookingpot approached, or attained, to the time of the cooking of its contents; and so, app., DArEt↓, accord. to the TA, but the passage in which this is there indicated presents an obvious mistranscription]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, tudoraka is erroneously put for tudorika.])

And Dar-aEa Alr-ub-u [app. means The rob, or inspissated juice, became nearly mature; or] the expressed juice was cooked, but its cooking was not complete. (O, Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, Alr-ub-a is erroneously put for Alr-ub-u, and Tabax for Tubixa, and yutim-a Taboxahu for yatim-a Taboxuhu.])

3. muDaAriEapN is syn. with muXaAbahapN: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, its primary meaning is The sharing [in a thing, or particularly in the DaroE, or udder], like muraADaEapN, which is the “sharing in sucking.” (TA.) You say DArEhu He, or it, resembled him, or it; was, or became like him, or it. (Ḳ, TA.) And bayonahumaA muraADaEapu AlkaAsi wamuDaAraEapu AlOajonaAsi [Between them two are the sipping of the wine-cup, and the resemblance of kinds; or compotation and congeniality]: said in the A to be from AlD-aroEu. (TA.) [See also an ex. voce taHal-aja.]
Also i. q. muqaArabapN [meaning The approaching a thing]. (TA.) See 2, in two places.

4. ADrEt, said of a ewe or she-goat, Her milk descended [into her udder, i. e. she secreted milk in her udder, as is shown in the lexicons in many places, (see for instance, Oarad-ato, and rid-apN,)] a little before her bringing forth: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] said of a she-camel, her milk descended from (mino [a mistranscription for fiI i. e. into]) her udder near the time of bringing forth; and the epithet applied to her is muDoriEN↓ [without p]: or, as in the A, said of a she-camel and of a cow, her udder (DaroEuhaA) became prominent before bringing forth: (TA:) or, said of a ewe or she-goat, she showed herself to be pregnant, and became large in her udder. (T in art. rmd.) And OaDoraEato EalaI raOosi Alwaladi [She secreted milk, or became large, in the udder, at the time of bringing forth, or when about to produce the young, like as one says kaAna celika EalaI raOosi fulaAnK expl. in art. rOs], said of a ewe or goat. (Ṣ in arts. rmd and rbq [in both of which the meaning is clearly shown] and in art. dfE [in which last see several sentences].)
[Hence, app.,] OaDoraEotu lahu maAliI † I gave him liberally, unsparingly, or freely, my property. (O, Ḳ.*)

And ADrEhu signifies also He, or it, lowered, humbled, or abased, him. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.) Thus, in a trad. of ʼAlee, OaDoraEa Qll-ehu xuduwdakumo May God lower, or humble, or abase, your cheeks. (TA.) One says also, kaAna mazohuw-FA faOaDoraEahu Alfaqoru [He was proud, haughty, or insolent, and poverty lowered, or humbled, or abased, him]. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., AlHum-aI OaDoraEatoniI laka, (Ṣ, Meyd, A, O,) or liln-awomi, (Meyd, O, Ḳ,) accord. to different relations, (Meyd, O,) [meaning The fever abased me to thee, or to sleep;] asserted by El-Mufaddal to have been first said by a certain man named Mureyr, to a Jinnee by whom he was carried off while sleeping under the influence of fever, after he had been making a fruitless search after his two brothers, Murárah and Murrah, who had also been carried off by Jinn: [his story is related at length in the O and TA, as well as by Meyd.; and is given in Ḥar p. 568, and in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. pp. 364-5:] the prov. is applied to the case of abasement on the occasion of need. (Meyd, O, TA.)
One says also, ADrEhu Uilayohi He, or it, constrained him to have recourse to him, or it. (TA.)
And ADrEhu AlHub-u Love rendered him lean, or emaciated. (TA.)

5. tDr-E He lowered, humbled, or abased, himself: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or he addressed himself with earnest, or energetic, supplication: (TA:) syn. Aibotahala, to God (UilaI Qll-ehi): (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or he manifested DaraAEap↓ i. e. severe poverty, (O, TA:) and want, (TA,) to God: (O, TA:) or i. q. taEar-aDa biTalabi AlHaAjapi, (Ḳ, TA,) or yaTolubu AlHaAjapa; (CK;) you say, jaMCa fulaAnN yataDar-aEu and yataEar-aDu i. e. Such a one came asking, or petitioning, to another for a thing that he wanted. (Fr, Ṣ, O.) [See also taSar-aEa.]
Also He writhed; and asked, or called, for aid, or succour. (TA.)
And, said of the shade, ‡ It contracted, shrank, or decreased; or it went away; syn. qalaSa: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ, TA:) and taSar-aEa is a dial. var. thereof.
See also 2.
