hom.sense: DaroEN a word of well-known meaning; (TA;) [properly and generally, the udder, but sometimes applied to the dug, or teat:] the DaroE is of every female that has a cloven hoof, or of the she-camel: (Ṣ, O:) [i. e.] of each of these: (Ḳ:) or [of the former only; i. e.] of the sheep or goat and of the cow and the like; that of the camel being termed xilofN: (Lth, O, Ḳ:) it is, to the clovenhoofed female, like the vadoI to the woman: (Mṣb:) or, to cattle, like the vadoI to the woman: (Towsheeh, TA:) accord. to the IF, it is of the sheep or goat and of other animals: accord. to IDrd, of the sheep or goat [only]: AZ says, it comprises the OaTobaMC, which are the OaxolaAf, and in which are the OaHaAliyl, which are the orifices for the passing forth of the milk: (O:) the pl. is DuruwEN. (O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) maA lahu zaroEN walaA DaroEN [lit. He has not seed-produce nor an udder] means ‡ he has not anything: (TA:) or it means he has not land to sow, nor ewe or she-goat or she-camel or other animal having a DaroE. (O.)
See also the next paragraph, in two places.

entry.sense: DiroEN A like; a similar person or thing; (IAạr, O, Ḳ;) as also DaroEN↓: (IAạr, TA in art. SrE:) and so SiroEN (O, TA) and SaroEN. (O and Ḳ and TA in art. SrE.)
And A sort, or species: and a state, condition, or manner of being: of a thing: as also DaroEN↓: and so SiroEN and SaroEN. (TA in art. SrE.)
And A strand of a rope: (O, Ḳ:) and so SiroEN: (O:) pl. DuruwEN. (O, Ḳ: and the CK adds OaDoruEN.)

DaraEN Lowly, humble, submissive, or in a state of abasement; [originally an inf. n., and therefore, as an epithet,] applied to a single person and to a pl. number: (O:) and DaAriEN↓ signifies the same, applied to a single person; (O, Mṣb;) as also musotaDoriEN↓, (Ḳ,*TA:) accord. To Lth, one says, xad-uka DaAriEN↓, (O,) and OaDoraEu↓, which signifies the same, (Ḥam p. 344,) and janobuka DaAriEN↓, [meaning, as is implied in the O, Thy cheek is lowly, &c., and so thy side, and the like is said in the Ḥam p. 590,] and Oanota DaAriEN↓ [Thou art lowly, &c.]: (O:) and the pl. of DaAriEN is DaraEapN and DuruwEN: (TA:) or DaAriEN↓ signifies, and so DariEN↓, and [in an intensive sense] DaruwEN↓ and DaraEapN↓, lowering, humbling, or abasing, himself: (Ḳ:) or thus, and making petition for a gift: (TA:) and DaraEN signifies weak; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also DariEN↓; (Ḳ;) the former (Mṣb, Ḳ) originally an inf. n. (Mṣb) [and therefore, as an epithet,] applied to a single person and to a pl. number: (Ḳ:) and DaraEN and DaAriEN↓ small; applied to anything: or small in age, weak, (Ḳ, TA,) and lean, spare, or light of flesh: (TA:) and DaAriEu↓ Aljisomi, (Ṣ,) and DariEN↓, (TA,) lean, spare, or light of flesh, and weak, in the body; (Ṣ, TA;) applied to a man: (Ṣ:) and DaraEN applied to a colt, not having strength to run, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of the smallness of his age. (TA.) Also † Cowardly, or weak-hearted: you say, huwa waraEN DaraEN [both app. meaning the same]. (TA.) And, applied to a man, ‡ Inexperienced in affairs; ignorant; or in whom is no profit nor judgment; syn. gumorN. (TA.)
DariEN: see DaraEN, in three places.
DaraEapN: see DaraEN.
It is also a pl. of DaAriEN [as mentioned above, voce DaraEN]. (TA.)
subabapN DuraEapN occurs in a trad. as meaning A reviler of men, who becomes like them and equal to them. (TA.)
DaruwEN: see DaraEN.

hom.sense: DuruwEN pl. of DaroEN [q. v.]. (O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Also A species of grape, (AḤn, O, Ḳ.) growing in the Saráh (Als-araAp), (AḤn, O,) white, large in the berries, (AḤn, O, Ḳ,) having little juice, great in the bunches, like the sort of raisins called TaAYifiI-. (O.)
It is also a pl. of DaAriEN [as mentioned above, voce DaraEN]. (TA.)

DariyEN and DariyEapN (IF, Ṣ O, Ḳ) and DaroEaMCu↓, (O, Ḳ,) applied to a ewe or she-goat, Large in the DaroE [or udder]; (IF, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) and in like manner applied to a woman: (Ḳ:) or ↓the last is applied to a woman as meaning large in the breasts, and in like manner to a ewe or she-goat: (IDrd, TA:) or, accord. to the L, the second and ↓third, as first expl. above, are applied to a ewe or she-goat, and to a camel; and the first is applied to a ewe or she-goat, as meaning goodly in the DaroE. (TA.)

Also, the first of these words, (O, Ḳ;) mentioned in the Ḳur lxxxviii. 6, (O,) i. q. XiboriqN; (O, Ḳ;) which is A bad sort of pasture, upon which the pasturing cattle do not make (laA taEoqidu) fat nor flesh, and which renders them in a bad condition if they do not quit it and betake themselves to other pasture; (AḤn, O;) or, accord. to IAth, the Xbrq is a certain plant in El-Ḥijáz, having large thorns: (TA:) or, the plant called Xiboriq that is dried up; (Fr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) Xbrq being its appellation when it is in its fresh state; (Fr, Ḳ, TA;) the people of El-Ḥijáz call it DryE in its dry state; (Fr, TA;) and it is [said to be] a plant which the beast will not approach, because of its bad quality: (Ḳ:) and (Ḳ) what is dry of any tree; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ;) accord. to some, peculiarly, of the Earofaj and xul-ap; (TA;) or [any] dry herbage: (TA in art. bHt:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lth, (O,) a certain plant in water that has become altered for the worse by long standing or the like, having roots that reach not to the ground: (O, Ḳ:) or a certain thing in Hell, more bitter than aloes, and more stinking than the carcass, and hotter than fire; (Ḳ, TA;) the food of the inmates of Hell; but this was unknown to the [pagan] Arabs: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) as some say, (O,) a certain plant, (Ḳ, O,) green, (O,) thus in the L, but in the “Mufradát” red, (TA,) of fetid odour, cast up by the sea, (O, Ḳ,) light, and hollow: (TA:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to Abu-l-Jowzà, (O,) the prickles of the palm-tree: (O, Ḳ:) and, (Ḳ,) accord. to IAạr, (O,) the [thorny tree called] Eawosaj, in its fresh state. (O, Ḳ.)
Also Wine: or thin wine: (Ḳ:) or thin beverage. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)
And the skin that is upon the bone, beneath the flesh (Lth, O, Ḳ) of the rib: (Lth, O:) or the integument upon it. (TA.)

entry.sense: DaAriEN: see DaraEN, in seven places.
nujuwmN DawaAriEu mean ‡ Stars inclining to setting, or to the places of setting. (A and TA in art. xDE.)

hom.sense: OaDoraEu: see DaraEN;
and for its fem. DaroEaMCu: see DariyEN, in three places.

entry.sense: muDoriEN an epithet applied to a she-camel [and app. to a ewe or she-goat]: see 4.
[muDar-iEN part. n. of the intrans. verb Dar-aEa.]

[In the TA, voce kavoCN, mSrE, which is evidently a mistranscription for muDar-iEN, is expl. as an epithet applied to a preparation of OaqiT (q. v.) as meaning Such as has become thick, or coagulated, and almost thoroughly cooked: on the authority of AḤát.]

AlmuDaAriEu [as a conventional term of grammar] The future tense; [or rather the aorist; for it is properly the present, and tropically the future:] so called because it resembles nouns in admitting the desinential syntactical signs. (TA.)
musotaDoriEN: see DaraEN.

Q. 1. Darogamati AlOaboTaAlu, [inf. n. DarogamapN,] † The men of valour acted like lions; as also taDarogamat↓: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, AlD-arogamapu and Alt-aDarogumu↓ signify † the choosing of valiant men [app. as antagonists] in war, or battle. (TA.) And you say, Darogama AlOaboTaAlu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA fiI AlHarobi † [The men of valour attacked one another like lions in war, or battle]. (Ṣ, TA.)
Q. 2. taDarogama: see what precedes, in two places.
DirogamN, or DarogamN: see the next paragraph.

DirogaAmN, (MA, Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ,) and DirogaAmapN↓, (MA, Ḳ, and so in other copies of the Ṣ,) and DirogamN↓, (MA,) or DarogamN↓, like jaEofarN, (Ḳ, TA,) The lion: (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ:) or a lion accustomed to prey, strong, and bold. (TA.)
And AlD-irogaAmu is also applied to † The constellation of the Lion. (Ḥam p. 110.)
DirogaAmapN: see DirogaAmN.
Hence, as being likened to a lion, (TA,) ‡ Courageous; (Ḳ, TA;) as an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
And † A powerful stallion [camel]. (Ḳ.)
And ‡ A strong man; (Ḳ, TA;) as being likened to a lion. (TA.)
And DirogaAmapN mino TiynK is said in the Nawádir el-Aaráb to mean Slime, or mire. (TA.)

1. Darimati Aln-aAru, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDoramu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaramN; (Mṣb, TA;) and ADTrmt↓, and [in an intensive sense] tDr-mt↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) The fire became kindled; or it burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; syn. Ailotahabat, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or AiXotaEalat. (Ḳ.)
And Darima AlX-aIoCu The thing was, or became, intensely hot. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
And Darimati AlHarobu, and ADTrmt↓, and [in an intensive sense] tDr-mt↓, † The war was, or became, kindled; or it burned fiercely, or raged. (TA.)

And Darima, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) said of a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ He was, or became, vehemently hungry: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or he burned with hunger: said by Z to be tropical: (TA:) and so tDr-m↓ juwEFA, syn. taHar-aqa. (TA in art. Hrq.) And one says of him who is vehemently hungry, Darima XacaAhu † [lit. His flies have become vehemently hungry, or burning with hunger]. (Ṣ in art. Xcw.)
And Darima fiI AlT-aEaAmi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He applied himself to the eating of the food vigorously, or with energy, not pushing away aught thereof. (Ḳ, TA.)

And Darima said of a horse, ‡ He ran vehemently [or ardently]: and they say also Darima Alr-aqaAq, [or perhaps correctly Darima fiI Alr-aqaAqi,] meaning ‡ He ran vehemently in a tract of soft ground: (TA:) and ADTrm↓ jaroyuhu † [His running was, or became, vehement, or ardent,] is likewise said of a horse. (Aṣ, Ṣ * and Ḳ * in art. mj.)
2: see the next paragraph {4}.

4. ADrm Aln-aAra, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDoraAmN; (Mṣb;) and Dar-amahaA↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but this is with teshdeed to denote intensiveness [of the signification]; (Ṣ;) and AstDrmhA↓, (Ḳ,) in which the prefix is not meant to denote demand; (TA;) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) syn. OawoqadahaA, (Ḳ,) or OaXoEalahaA. (Ṣ in art. XEl.)
5: see 1, in four places.
8: see 1, in four places.
One says also, ADTrm AlmaXiybu ‡ Whiteness of the hair became glistening (AiXotaEala, Ḳ, TA) and much in degree. (TA.)
And ADTrm AlX-ar-u bayonahumo † Evil became excited among them. (TA.)
[And ADTrm is said of a stallion-camel meaning † He was, or became, excited by lust, or by vehement lust: see its part. n., below.]

DiromN and DuromN, (Ḳ, TA,) the former of which is that commonly known, (TA,) A species of tree or plant (Xajar) of sweet odour, (Ḳ, TA,) found in the mountains of Et-Táïf and El-Yemen, (TA,) the fruit of which is like the acorn, and the flower like that of the [species of marjoram called] saEotar, (Ḳ, TA,) fed upon by bees, (TA,) and the honey thereof has an excellent quality, (Ḳ, TA,) and is called Easalu AlD-iromapi: (TA: [DiromapN being the n. un.:]) or it is what is called in the ancient Greek language OusoTuwxuwduws [app. a mode of writing ςοιχάδος, gen. of ςοιχὰς; for it is applied in the present day to stœchas, commonly called French lavender]. (Ḳ, TA.)
DaramN: see DaramapN, in two places:
and DiraAmN.
DarimN [part. n. of 1: Becoming kindled;, &c.]
[And hence, ‡ Burning with hunger; or] vehemently hungry; (Mṣb;) [or simply] hungering, or hungry: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [burning with anger; or] violently angry. (Mṣb.)
And † A beast of prey in a state of excitement by lust. (TA.)
And ‡ A horse that runs vehemently [or ardently]; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so Darimu AlEadowi. (TA.)
And † The young one of the eagle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

DaramapN A palm-branch with its leaves upon it, or a XiyHap [i. e. plant of one of the species of wormwood called XiyH], having fire [kindled] in its extremity: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] DaramN↓. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] one says, maA bihaA naAfixu DaramapK, [in the CK, DiromapK, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ DaromapK, both of which are wrong, There is not in it (namely, the house, Ald-aAr,) a blower of a Daramap,] meaning, ‡ anyone. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
Also A live coal. (Ḳ.)
And Fire, (Ḳ, TA,) itself, as some say; (TA;) or so DaramN↓, (Ḥam p. 77, and Ḥar p. 27,) sometimes. (Ḥam ibid.)

DiraAmN [is like the inf. n. DaramN used as a simple subst., signifying] A kindling, or burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire, (Ṣ, A, TA,) in [the species of high, coarse grass called] HalofaMC, and the like thereof: (Ṣ, TA:) [and] the blazing, or flaming, of the [plant called] Earofaj [q. v.]. (Mgh.)
[See also a phrase mentioned voce DiraAsN.]

Also (Ṣ) Fragments, or broken pieces, of firewood, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which fire quickly kindles, or burns up, burns brightly or fiercely, blazes, or flames: (Ṣ:) or such as is weak and soft (Ḳ, TA) thereof: (TA:) such as has [i. e. leaves] no live coals: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of DaramN↓; which is expl. in the A as meaning slender firewood; (TA;) or which means firewood, and what is thrown into fire [as fuel]: (Ḥar p. 27:) or DiraAmN signifies firewood that has kindled, or burned up,, &c.: as also DiraAmapN↓. (Ḳ.)
DariymN i. q. HariyqN, (Ṣ, A, TA,) [as meaning] Burnt with, or in, fire: (KL:) in the Ḳ, the word expl. as signifying HariyqN is said to be like HayodarN, i. e. DayoramN↓. (TA.)
And † Burning in the bowels. (TA.)
DiroyamN The gum of a certain tree. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: DiraAmapN: see DiraAmN, last explanation.
Also The terebinth-tree. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DayoramN: see DariymN.
muDoTarimN † A stallion [camel] excited by lust, or by vehement lust. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. DariIa bihi, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaraAwapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DarFA (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DaroIN and DaraMCapN, (Ḳ, TA, [the last in the CK written DaraAp,]) He was, or became, attached, addicted, or devoted, to it; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA;) and (TA) he habituated, or accustomed, himself to it, (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA,) so that he could hardly, or in nowise, withhold himself from it; (TA;) and emboldened himself to do it or undertake it or the like: and he kept, or clave, to it; and became attached, addicted, or devoted, to it; like the animal of prey to the chase. (Mṣb.) [And Dariyahu occurs in the M, in art. mrs, in explanation of tamar-asa bihi, app. for DariIa bihi, in the same sense.] It is said in a trad., Uin-a liloUisolaAmi DaraAwapF i. e. Verily there is a habituating and an attachment of oneself to El-Islám; meaning, one cannot withhold himself from it. (TA.) And in a saying, (Ṣ,) or trad., (M, TA,) of ʼOmar, Uiy-aAkumo wahecihi AlmajaAzira faUin-a lahaA DaraAwapF kaDaraAwapi Alxamori (Ṣ, M, TA) i. e. [Avoid ye these places where cattle are slaughtered and where their flesh is sold, for] there is a habituating of oneself to them, and a yearning towards them, like the habituating of oneself to wine; for he who habituates himself to flesh-meat hardly, or in nowise, withholds himself from it, and becomes extravagant in his expenditure. (TA. [See also majozarN.]) And one says of a dog, DariIa biAlS-ayodi, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) [in Ḥar p. 579 fI AlSayd, which I do not find elsewhere,] aor. _a, (Ṣ,) inf. n. DaraAwapN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh,) or DarFI and DiraMCN and DaraMCN, (M, Ḳ,) the last on the authority of AZ, (M,) He became habituated, or accustomed, to the chase. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) And Dariyati Aljar-apu biAlxal-i [The jar became seasoned with vinegar] and biAln-abiyci [with must or the like]. (TA.) And DariIa Aln-abiycu The nbyc became strong [by remaining several days in the jar or skin]. (TA.)

DaraA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u, inf. n. DarowN, (Ṣ,) or Duruw-N, (Ḳ,) said of a vein, It shed blood: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the T, it quivered, and gushed with blood or made a sound by reason of the blood coming forth: Z says that the form of the verb is altered because of the alteration of the meaning. (TA.) And DaraI, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i, (Ḳ,) [likewise] said of a vein, (M,) signifies It flowed, (M, Ḳ, TA,) and ran [with blood]; on the authority of IAạr. (TA.) And DaraA, aor. _u, said of a wound, It ceased not to flow [with blood]. (IAth, TA.)
And DaraA, inf. n. Drw [whether DarowN or Duruw-N is not shown], said of a man, He hid, or concealed, himself. (IḲṭṭ, TA. [See also 10.])

entry.sense: 2. Dr-Ahu bihi, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;,) inf. n. taDoriyapN; (Ḳ;;) and ADrAhu↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;;) He caused him to become attached, addicted, or devoted, to it; (M, Kudot;, TA;) he habituated, or accustomed, him to it, (M,* Mṣb, Kudot;,* TA,) [so that he could hardly, or in nowise, withhold himself from it; (see 1, first sentence;)] and emboldened him to do it or undertake it or the like. (Mṣb.) And Dr-I Alkaloba biAlS-ayodi, (Ṣ;,* Mgh,) inf. n. as above; (Sudot;, Mgh;) and ADrAhu↓ bihi, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA, ast;) inf. n. UiDoraMCN; (Mgh;) He habituated, or accustomed, the dog to the chase; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) and incited him, or caused him to become attached or addicted, thereto. (Ṣ.)
4: see the next preceding paragraph {2}, in two places.
10. AisotaDorayotu lilS-ayodi I deluded, or circumvented, the object, or objects, of the chase, at unawares. (Ṣ. [See also 1, last meaning.])
DaruwN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

hom.sense: DirowN A dog, (M,) or young dog, (Ṣ, Kudot;,) such as is termed DaArK [i. e. habituated, or accustomed, to the chase]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also DariI-N↓: (Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, kAlD-araI is erroneously put for kaAlD-ariI-i:]) the latter word is like ganiI-N: (TA:) the fem. of the former is with p {DirowapN): and the pl. [of pauc.] OaDorK [originally OaDoruwN] and [of mult.] DiraMCN. (Ṣ, M.)

And A taint of jucaAm [or elephantiasis]: (M, Ḳ:) occurring in a trad. in which it is said of Aboo-Bekr, Oakala maEa rajulK bihi DirowN mino jucaAmK [He ate with a man in whom was a taint of elephantiasis]: it is from [the inf. n.] AlD-araAwapu; as though the disease became attached, or habituated, to the person: (M, TA:) mentioned by Hr in the “Ghareebeyn:” (M:) or, as some relate it, the word is with the fet-ḥ, [i. e. DarowN↓,] and is from DaraA said of a wound, the meaning being in whom was a wound having an incessant flowing. (TA.)

Also, and DarowN↓, A species of tree, of sweet odour, with [the wood of] which the teeth are rubbed and cleansed, and the leaves of which are put into perfume; (M, TA;) i. q. maHolabN [q. v.]; so says Lth: (TA:) AḤn says, the places of its growth are mostly in El-Yemen; (M, TA;) and some say that the Dirow is the buTom [or terebinth-tree, or the fruit thereof]: (M:) AḤn says also, it is of the trees of the mountains, and is like the great oak, (M, TA,*) having clusters [of berries] like those of the oak, but its berries are larger; its leaves are cooked, and, when thoroughly cooked, are cleared away, and the water thereof is returned to the fire, and coagulates, (M, TA,) becoming like qubayoTaMC [q. v.], (M,) and is used medicinally as a remedy for roughness of the chest and for pain of the fauces: (M, TA:) or the gum of a certain tree called the kamokaAm [i. e. the cancamum-tree], brought from El-Yemen: (Ṣ:) or this is a mistake, for it is the tree so called, not its gum: (Ḳ:) [but] it is said in the T, on the authority of AḤn, that kamokaAm signifies the bark (qirof) of the tree called Dirow: and some say that it is the resin (Eilok) of the Dirow: and in the Moḥeeṭ of Ibn-ʼAbbád it is said that kamokaAm signifies the bark (qirof, or, as some say, liHaMC,) of the tree called Dirow, and is an aromatic perfume: (TA:) and (Ḳ, TA) IAạr says, (TA,) the Dirow is the Hab-ap xaDoraMC [or fruit of the terebinth-tree], (Ḳ, TA,) which is also sometimes used for rubbing and cleansing the teeth: when a girl rubs and cleanses her teeth with a stick of the tree called Dirow the saliva with which the stick is moistened from her mouth is like honey: (TA:) and the word is also pronounced DarowN↓. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DaraMCN A level tract of land in which are beasts of prey and a few trees: (M, Ḳ:) or a piece of land, or ground, that conceals one: (AA, TA:) and trees, &c., that conceal one: (M:) or a thicket; or tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees; in a valley. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, tawaAraI AlS-ayodu min-iI fiI DaraMCi AlwaAdiI [The game hid itself from me in the tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees of the valley]. (Ṣ.) And fulaAnN yamoXiI AlD-araMCa, with fet-ḥ, meaning Such a one goes along lurking among the trees that conceal him. (Ṣ.) And huwa yadib-u lahu AlD-araMCa wayamoXiI lahu Alxamara [He creeps to him in the thicket, and walks, or goes along, to him in the covert of trees]: said of a man when he deludes, or circumvents, his companion: (Ṣ:) but accord. to IAạr, DrMC here means a low, or depressed, place. (Meyd.) And fulaAnN laA yudab-u lahu AlD-araMCu [app. meaning The thicket will not be crept through to such a one: but mentioned after the last of the explanations here following]. (M.) [See also Dar-aMCu, in art. Dr.]
[It is said that] it signifies also The hiding or concealing, oneself: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) [or] the walking, or going along, in that which conceals one from him whom one beguiles, or circumvents. (M.)
DiraMCN, a pl. epithet, [of which the sing. is probably DuriI-N↓,] Courageous: hence, in a trad., Uin-a fiynaA DiraMCu Qll-ehi [Verily among us are the champions of God]. (TA.)
DariI-N: see DirowN, first sentence.
Applied to a vein, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) ‡ Flowing; as also DaArK↓: (M:) or flowing much; (TA;) of which the blood hardly, or in nowise, stops; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though it were habituated to the flowing. (TA.)
See also DiraMCN.

DaArK Attached, addicted, or devoted, to a thing; (TA;) habituated, or accustomed, thereto, (Mṣb, TA,) so as hardly, or in nowise, to withhold himself therefrom; (TA;) and emboldening himself to do it or undertake it or the like: and keeping, or cleaving, thereto; being attached, addicted, or devoted, to it; like the animal of prey to the chase. (Mṣb.) [Hence,] kalobN DaArK, (Ṣ, Mgh,) or kalobN DaArK biAlS-ayodi, (M, Ḳ,) A dog habituated, or accustomed, to the chase: (Ṣ, Mgh, TA:) and kalobapN DaAriyapN. (Ṣ. [See also DirowN, first sentence.]) [kalobN DaArK biAlS-ayodi is also expl. in the TA by the words UicaA taTaE-ama bilaHomihi, app. meaning A dog having his appetite excited by tasting the flesh of the game.] DawaArK [is pl. of DaArK applied to an irrational animal, and as such] signifies [Animals accustomed to prey; rapacious, or ravenous, beasts; and particularly] lions. (TA.) And AlmawaAXiI AlD-aAriyapu The cattle that are in the habit of pasturing upon peoples' seed-produce. (Nh, TA.) And bayotN DaArK biAll-aHomi A house, or tent, in which flesh-meat is habitually found so much that its odour remains in it. (TA.) And siqaMCN DaArK biAll-abani, thus correctly, as in the M, but in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ biAls-amoni, (TA,) A skin in which milk is long kept so that its flavour becomes good. (M, TA.) And jar-apN DaAriyapN biAlxal-i and biAln-abiyci [A jar become seasoned with vinegar and with must or the like]. (M, TA.) AlUinaMCu AlD-aAriI, occurring in a trad. of ʼAlee, is said to mean The jar that runs [or leaks]; and the drinking from it is forbidden because it renders the drinking troublesome: thus expl. by IAạr: but it is also expl. as meaning the wine-jar that has become seasoned with wine (DariIa biAloxamori); so that when nabiyc is put into it, it becomes intoxicating. (TA.) And EiroqN DaArK means A vein shedding blood: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [or quivering, and gushing with blood or making a sound by reason of the blood coming forth: (see the verb:)] or flowing, or running: (TA: see DariI-N:) or accustomed to be opened, and therefore when the time for it is come and it is opened, emitting its blood more quickly. (TA.)

1. DaE-a, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) an inf. n. of which the verb is DaE-a, aor. _u {yaDoEuEu}, (TḲ,) The breaking, or training, (Ṣ,) or training well, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) a he-camel, (IAạr, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and a she-camel, not previously trained: (IAạr, O, Ḳ:) or the saying to a camel DaEo↓ in order that he may become well trained. (Th, Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. DaEoDaEahu, (inf. n. DaEoDaEapN, TḲ,) He threw it down, or pulled it down, [or rased it,] to the ground; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) namely, a building. (Ṣ, O.)
And DaEoDaEahu Ald-ahoru Time, or fortune, lowered, humbled, or abased him; (Ṣ, O;) and so taDaEoDaEa↓ bihi Ald-ahoru. (TA.) [See also DaEoDaEapN below.]
R. Q. 2. taDaEoDaEato OarokaAnuhu, referring to a building, i. q. Ait-aDaEato, (Ṣ,) i. e. [Its angles, or corners, or its sides,] sank down; and became in a state of ruin. (PṢ.)

And tDEDE said of a man, (Ṣ, O,) He was, or became, lowly, humble, submissive, or abased; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) [or he lowered, humbled, or abased, himself;] liMxara [to another], (Ṣ,) or liganiI-K [to a rich person]. (O.) Hence, (Ṣ,) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
watajal-udiI lilX-aAmitiyna Ouriyhumu
Oan-iI lirayobi Ald-ahori laA OataDaEoDaEu
[And my constraining myself to behave with hardiness to those who rejoice at my misfortune: I show them that I will not humble myself to the evil accidents of time]. (Ṣ,* O.)
And He became poor: (O, Ḳ:) as though from DaE-a: (O:) and tSESE is a dial. var. thereof, on the authority of Aboo-Saʼeed. (TA.)
And He became weak, and light in his body, by reason of disease, or of grief. (TA.)
And tDEDE maAluhu His property became little. (TA.)
See also R. Q. 1.
DaEo: see the first paragraph above.
DaEoDaEN: see DaEoDaAEN.
DaEoDaEapN inf. n. of DaEoDaEahu [q. v.]. (TḲ.)

And [as though inf. n. of DuEoDiEa] Lowliness, humility, or submissiveness: (TA, and Ḥam p. 369:) [as used in the present day, a state of depression; languor; weakness; and poverty:] and hardship, or adversity. (TA.)
DaEoDaAEN Weak: applied in this sense to anything. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And A man without judgment, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and without prudence, or precaution, or discretion; (O, Ḳ;) and DaEoDaEN↓ signifies the same, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) being a contraction of the former word. (Ṣ, O.)
mutaDaEoDiEN [the part. n. of R. Q. 2, q. v.,] is used by the Arabs as meaning A poor man. (O.)

hom.sense:
1. DaEufa, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and DaEafa, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter on the authority of Yoo, (O,) or of Lḥ, (L,)
aor. of each _u, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DuEofN and DaEofN (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ) [and app. DaEafN (q. v. infrà) or this is a simple subst.] and DaEaAfapN and DaEaAfiyapN, (Ḳ,) all of which are inf. ns. of the former verb, (TA,) or the first, which is of the dial. of Kureysh, is of the former verb, and the second, which is of the dial. of Temeem, is of the latter verb, (Mṣb,) He, or it, was, or became, weak, feeble, faint, frail, infirm, or unsound; DuEofN and DaEofN being the contr. of quw-apN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of SiH-apN; (Mṣb;) and both of them may be used alike, in every relation; or, accord. to the people of El-Basrah, both are so used; so says Az; (TA;) but some say that the former is used in relation to the body, and the latter in relation to the judgment or opinion. (O, Mṣb, Ḳ: but this is omitted in my copy of the TA.)

DaEufa Eani AlX-aIoCi means He lacked strength, or power, or ability, to do or accomplish, or to bear, the thing; [he was weak so as to be disabled, or incapacitated, from doing, or accomplishing, or from bearing, the thing;] syn. Eajaza Eanohu, (Mṣb in art. Ejz,) or Eajaza Eani QHotimaAlihi. (Mṣb in the present art.)
[See also DaEofN below.]
DaEufa also signifies It (a thing) exceeded; syn. zaAda. (L, TA.)

And you say, DaEafotu Alqawoma (Lth, O, Ḳ,*) aor. _u {yaDoEufu}, (O,) or _a, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. DaEofN; (O;) [and app. DaEufotu Ealayohimo, like as you say zidotu Ealayohimo;] I exceeded the people, or party, in number, so that I and my companions had double, or several-fold, the number that they had. (Lth, O, Ḳ.*)
See also 3.
2. DE-fhu, inf. n. taDoEiyfN: see 4: and see also AlmuDaE-afu.

Also He reckoned, or esteemed, him DaEiyf [i. e. weak,, &c.]; (O, Ḳ;) and so AstDEfhu↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and tDE-fhu↓: (O, Ḳ:) or AstDEfhu↓ signifies he found him to be so; (TA;) or he asserted him to be (jaEalahu) so; (Mṣb;) or, as also tDE-fhu↓, he [esteemed him to be so, and therefore] behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently, towards him, in respect of worldly things, because of [his] poverty, and meanness of condition. (IAth, TA.) galabaniI Oaholu Alkuwfapi OasotaEomilu Ealayohimu AlmuWomina fayuDaE-afu waOasotaEomilu Ealayohimu AlqawiI-a fayufaj-aru, [The people of El-Koofeh have overcome me: I employ as governor over them the believer, and he is esteemed weak; and I employ as governor over them the strong, and he is charged with unrighteousness:] is a saying mentioned in a trad. of ʼOmar. (TA.)

And He attributed, or ascribed, (O, Ḳ,) to him, i. e. a man, (O,) or ‡ to it, i. e. a tradition, [&c.,] DaEof [meaning weakness, app., in the case of a man, of judgment, and in the case of a tradition, &c., of authority]. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
And He doubled it, or made it double, covering one part of it with another part. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph {3}, in two places.

entry.sense: 3. DAEfhu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. muDaAEafapN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and DE-fhu↓, (Ṣ Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoEiyfN; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and ADEfhu↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDoEaAfN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) all signify the same; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. He doubled it, or made it double, or two-fold; (O, Ḳ;) [and trebled it, or made it treble, or three-fold; and redoubled it, or made it several-fold, or manyfold; i. e. multiplied it; for] Kh says, Alt-aDoEiyfu signifies the adding to a thing so as to make it double, or two-fold; or more [i. e. treble, or threefold; and several-fold, or many-fold]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb;) and so AlUiDoEaAfu, and AlmuDaAEafapu; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and DaEafahu↓, without teshdeed, signifies the same as DAEfhu. (Ḥam p. 257.) The saying, in the Ḳur [xxxiii. 30], yuDaAEafo lahaA AlEacaAbu DiEofayoni, (Mgh, O, Ḳ,) in which AA read yuDaE-afo↓, (TA,) accord. to AO, (Mgh, O,) means, The punishment shall be made to her three punishments; (Mgh, O, Ḳ;) for, he says, she is to be punished once; and when the punishment is doubled twofold, [or is repeated twice,] the one becomes three: (TA:) he adds, (O,) and the tropical meaning of yuDaAEafo (majaAzu yuDaAEafo [for which majAzN yuDaAEafu is erroneously put in the CK]) is two things' being added to a thing so that it becomes three: (O, Ḳ:) but Az disapproves this, saying that it is peculiar to the tropical and the common conventional speech, whereas the skilled grammarians state the meaning to be, she shall be punished with twice the like of the punishment of another; (Mgh;) [so that it may be rendered the punishment shall be doubled to her, made two-fold; and in like manner] Ibn-ʼArafeh explains it as meaning she shall have two shares of punishment. (O.) fayuDaAEifuhu lahu OaDoEaAfFA kaviyrapF [And He will multiply it to him many-fold, or, as some read, fayuDaAEifahu that He may multiply it,] is another phrase occurring in the Ḳur [ii. 246]. (O, TA.) And one says, OaDoEafotu↓ Alv-awaAba liloqawomi [I doubled, or multiplied, the recompense to the people, or party]. (Mṣb.) And OuDoEifa↓ Alqawomu The people, or party, had a doubling, or multiplying, [of their recompense, &c.,] made to them; (Mṣb;) [and so, app., OaDoEafuwA; (see muDoEifN;)] i. q. DuwEifa lahumo. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4. ADEfhu He, (God, Mṣb, or another, Ṣ,) or it, (disease, TA,) rendered him DaEiyf [i. e. weak,, &c.]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DE-fhu↓. (L, TA.)
And OaDoEafa, said of a man, He became one whose beast was weak. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
See also 3, first sentence, and last two sentences.
5: see 2, in two places.
[tDE-f app. signifies also He manifested weakness: see tDw-r.]

entry.sense: 6. tDAEf signifies SaAra DiEofa maA kaAna [i. e. It became double, or two-fold; and treble, or threefold; and several-fold, or many-fold]. (O, Ḳ.)
10: see 2, in two places.

DaEofN an inf. n. of 1, like DuEofN↓, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) [both, when used as simple substs., signifying Weakness, feebleness,, &c.,] but some say that the former is in the judgment or opinion, and the latter in the body; (O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and DaEafN↓ signifies the same, (IAạr, Ḳ, TA,) and is in the body and also in the judgment or opinion and the intellect. (TA.)

DaEofu Alt-aOoliyfi [Weakness of construction, in language,] is such a construction of the members of a sentence as is contrary to the [generally approved] rules of syntax; as when a pronoun is introduced before its noun with respect to the actual order of the words and the order of the sense [in a case in which the pronoun is affixed to the agent in a verbal proposition]; for instance, in the phrase, Daraba gulaAmuhu zayodFA [“His,” i. e. Zeyd's, “young man beat Zeyd”]. (KT.) When the pronoun is affixed to the objective complement, as in xaAfa rab-ahu Eumaru [“ʼOmar feared his Lord”] such introduction of it is common: (I’Aḳ p. 128:) and it is [universally] allowable when the pronoun is of the kind called Damiyru AlX-aOoni, as in Uin-ahu zayodN qaAYimN; or Damiyru rub-a, as in rub-ahu rajulFA laqiytuhu; or Damiyru niEoma, as in niEomahu rajulFA zayodN. (Kull p. 56.)
[In the CK, a signification belonging to DuEof is assigned to DaEof.]
DuEofN: see DaEofN.
mino DuEofK in the Ḳur xxx. 53 means Of sperm. (O, Ḳ, TA.) AA, reciting before the Prophet, said mino DaEofK; and was told by the latter to say mn DuEofK, [i. e.] with damm. (TA.)

DiEofu AlX-aIoCi signifies The like of the thing, (AO, Zj, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) that doubles it (yuDoEifuhu); (Zj, TA;) and DiEofaAhu, twice the like of it; (AO, Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and OaDoEaAfuhu, the likes of it: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) AlD-iEofu in the [proper] language of the Arabs means the like: this is the original signification: (Az, Mṣb:) and (Ḳ, TA, but in CK “or,”) then, by a later [and conventional] usage, (Az, Mṣb,) the like and more, the addition being unlimited: (Az, Mṣb, Ḳ:) one says, hecaA DiEofu hecaA i. e. This is the like of this: and hecaAni DiEofaAhu i. e. These two are twice the like of it: and it is allowable in the language of the Arabs to say, hecaA DiEofuhu meaning This is twice the like [i. e. the double] of it, and thrice the like [i. e. the treble] of it, [and more,] because the DiEof is an unlimited addition: (Az, Mṣb: [and the like is said in the O, on the authority of Az:]) and one says, laka DiEofuhu meaning Thou shalt have twice the like of it, (Zj, O, Ḳ,) using the sing. form, though the dual form is better, (Zj, O,) and meaning also thrice the like of it, and more without limit: (Ḳ:) and AlAivonaAni DiEofu AlwaAHidi [i. e. AlAvnAn is the double of AlwAHd]: (M and Ḳ in art. vnI:) and if one say in his will, OaEoTuwhu DiEofa naSiybi waladiI, twice the like of the share of his child is given to him; and if he say DiEofayohi, thrice the like thereof is given to him; so that if the share of the son be a hundred, he [the legatee] is given two hundred in the former case, and three hundred in the latter case; for the will is made to accord with the common conventional language, not with the niceties of the [proper] language: (Az, Mṣb: [and the like is said, but less fully, in the Mgh:]) the pl. is OaDoEaAfN only. (TA.)
UicFA laOacaqonaAka DiEofa AlHayaApi waDiEofa AlmamaAti, in the Ḳur [xvii. 77], means DiEofa AlEacaAbi Hay-FA wamay-itFA, (Ṣ,) or DiEofa EacaAbi AlHayaApi waDiEofa EacaAbi AlmumaAti, (O, Jel,) i. e. [In that case we would assuredly have made thee to taste] the like [or, as some explain it, the double] of the punishment of others in the present world and [the like or the double thereof] in the world to come: (Jel:) [Ṣgh adds, app. on the authority of Ibn-ʼArafeh,] the meaning is, the punishment of others should be made two-fold, or more, (yuDaAEaf,) to thee, because thou art a prophet. (O.) In the saying, faOuwlaAYika lahumo jazaMCu QlD-iEofi bimaA EamiluwA, in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 36], by AlD-iEofi is meant AlODoEaAfi [i. e. For these shall be the recompense of the likes for what they have done]; and it is most properly held to denote ten of the likes thereof, because of the saying in the Ḳur [vi. 161], “Whoso doth that which is good, for him shall be ten of the likes thereof.” (O.) In the saying, faMtihimo EacaAbFA DiEofFA, in the Ḳur [vii. 36], by DiEofFA is meant muDaAEafFA [i. e. Therefore do Thou recompense them with a doubled, or a double, punishment]: EacaAbN DiEofN meaning a punishment as though doubled, one part of it upon another. (TA.)

OaDoEaAfu AlkitaAbi means ‡ The interspaces of the lines, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) or of the margin, (Ṣ, O,) or and of the margins, (Ḳ, TA,) of the writing, or book: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) so in the saying, waq-aEa fulaAnN fiI OaDoEaAfi kitaAbihi ‡ [Such a one made an entry of a note or postil or the like, or entries of notes, &c., in the interspaces of the lines,, &c., of his writing, or book]: (Ṣ, O, TA:) and taDaAEiyfu↓ AlkitaAbi signifies the same as OaDoEaAfuhu. (TA.)

And OaDoEaAfu Aljasadi † The limbs, members, or organs, (OaEoDaMC,) of the body: (O, Ḳ:) or the bones thereof: (AA, Ḳ:) or the bones thereof having flesh upon them: (TA:) sing. DiEofN. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying of Ru-beh,
waQll-ehu bayona Alqalobi waAlOaDoEaAfi
† [And God is between the heart and the limbs,, &c.]. (TA.) And it is said of Yoonus, [the prophet Jonah,] kaAna fiI OaDoEaAfi AlHuwti ‡ [He was amid the members of the fish]. (TA.)

hom.sense: DaEafN: see DaEofN.
Also Garments, or pieces of cloth, made double (muDaE-FfapN↓). (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DaEofapN Weakness of heart, and littleness of intel-ligence. (TA.)
DaEafapN A party, or company, or small company, (XirocimapN,) of the Arabs. (TA.)
Also a pl. of DaEiyfN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, &c.)
DaEofaAnu: see DaEiyfN.
DaEuwfN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

DaEiyfN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [in an intensive sense] DaEuwfN↓ (Ibn-Buzurj, O, Ḳ) and DaEofaAnu↓ (Ḳ) Weak, feeble, faint, frail, infirm, or unsound: (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, O, Mṣb) DiEaAfN and DuEafaMCu and DaEafapN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which last is [said to be] the only instance of its kind except xabavapN pl. of xabiyvN [q. v.], (TA,) and DaEofaI, like jaroHaI pl. of jariyHN: (Mṣb:) fem. DaEuwfN↓ (Ibn-Burzurj, O, Ḳ) and DaEiyfapN; pl., applied to women, DaEiyfaAtN (Ḳ) and DaEaAYifu and DiEaAfN. (TA.) waxuliqa QloUinosaAnu DaEiyfFA (in the Ḳur [iv. 32], O) means [For man was created weak, or] subject to be inclined by his desire. (O, L, Ḳ.) And AlD-aEiyfaAni [The two weak ones] means the woman and the slave: hence the trad., Ait-aquwA Qll-eha fiI AlD-aEiyfayoni [Fear ye God in respect of the woman and the slave]. (TA.)

In the dial. of Himyer, Blind: and [it is said that] thus it signifies in the phrase lanaraAka fiynaA DaEiyfFA [Verily we see thee to be, among us, blind], (O, Ḳ,) in the Ḳur [xi. 93]: (O:) but Esh-Shiháb rejects this, in the 'Inayeh. (TA.)
[As a conventional term] in lexicology, applied to a word, [Of weak authority;] inferior to what is termed faSiyHN, but superior to what is termed munokarN. (Mz, 10th nwE.)
Applied to verse, or poetry, [Weak;] unsound, or infirm; syn. EaliylN: thus used by Kh. (TA.)
The saying of a man who had found a thing dropped on the ground (wajada luqaTapF), faEar-afotuhaA DaEiyfFA, means And I made it known in a suppressed, or low, [or weak,] voice. (Mgh in art. nfr.)
DaAEifN A cow having a young one in her belly; (IDrd, O;) as though she were made double thereby: (TA:) but IDrd says that this is not of high authority. (O.)
taDoEiyfN inf. n. of 2. (Ṣ, &c.)
taDaAEiyfu AlX-aIoCi means The doubles, or trebles, or multiples, of the thing; (maA DuE-ifa minohu;) in this sense, tDAEyf has no sing., like tabaAXiyru, &c. (TA.)
taDaAEiyfu AlkitaAbi: see DiEof, near the end.
As expl. by Lth, (O,) Alt-aDoEiyfu signifies HumolaAnu AlkiymiyaMCi [i. e. What is used as an alloy in chemistry or alchymy]. (O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: muDoEifN A man whose beast, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Mgh in art. kfO,) or whose camel, (O,) is weak, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) or untractable. (O.) Hence the saying of ʼOmar, AlmuDoEifu OamiyrN EalaI OaSoHaAbihi [He whose beast is weak, or untractable, is ruler over his companions]; (O, Ḳ;) i. e. in journeying; (O;) because they go his pace. (O, Ḳ.) And the saying, in a trad., yarud-u muXid-uhumo EalaI muDoEifihimo [expl. in art. Xd]. (Mgh in art. kfO.)

faOuwlaAYika humu QlomuDoEifuwna, in the Ḳur [xxx. 38], means These are they who shall have their recompense doubled, or multiplied: (Az, Bḍ, TA:) or those who double, or multiply, their recompense (Bḍ, Jel) and their possessions, (Bḍ,) by the blessing of their almsgiving: (Bḍ, Jel:*) but some read AlmuDoEafuwna. (Bḍ.)
AlmuDoEifu also signifies mano faXato DayoEatuhu wakavurato [He whose property has become wide-spread and abundant]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, L, Ḳ.)
OaroDN muDaE-afapN Land upon which a weak rain has fallen: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] maDoEuwfN↓ signifies a place upon which has fallen only a little, or weak, rain. (O in art. rk.)

AlmuDaE-afu One of the arrows used in the game of Almuyosir, that has no share, or portion, allotted to it; as though it were disabled from having a share (kaOan-ahu DuE-ifa↓ Eano Oano yakuwna lahu naSiybN): (TA:) the second of the arrows termed Algufolu, that have no notches, and to which is assigned [no portion and] no fine: these being added only to give additional weight to the collection of arrows from fear of occasioning suspicion [of foul play]. (Lḥ, M.) [See Als-afiyHu.]
See also DaEafN.

entry.sense: muDaE-ifN A man having manifold good deeds. (TA.)

maDoEuwfN, applied to a thing, (Ṣ,) or to a man, (O,) Rendered DaEiyf [i. e. weak,, &c.]: (AA, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) by rule it should be muDoEafN. (O, Ḳ.) A man weak in intellect: (IAạr, TA:) or weakhearted and having little intellect. (TA.)
See also OaroDN muDaE-afapN, above.
diroEN muDaAEafapN A coat of mail composed of double rings. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
muDaAEafN as a conventional term used by those who treat of inflection, Having a [radical] letter doubled. (TA.)
Oaholu Aljan-api kul-u DaEiyfK mutaDaE-afK [The meet for Paradise is every weak person who is esteemed weak]. (Ḳ,* TA. [In the CK, erroneously, mutaDaE-ifN: and in the Ḳ, Ahl Aljn-p is omitted.])
1. DaEaA He hid, or concealed, himself. (ISd, Ḳ.)

DaEapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally DaEowN, or DaEawN, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ,) the p being a substitute [for the w], because of the form of its pl. [and of the rel. n.]; or, as some say, the p is a substitute for an initial w, and it is mentioned also in art. wDE; (Ṣ;) A species of tree, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in the desert: or it is [a plant] like the [species of panic grass called] vumaAm: (TA:) accord. to Az, a species of vumaAm: (TA in art. vm:) or another plant: and some pronounce it DiEapN; but this is in AlHasab [or grounds of pretension to respect, &c.], and does not belong to the present art.: (TA:) the pl. is DaEawaAtN. (Ṣ, TA.) [Golius says, on the authority of Meyd, that it also signifies The reed of which writing-reeds are made.]
DaEawiI-N Of, or relating to, the DaEap above mentioned. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. Dagava AlX-aIoCa, aor _a, inf. n. DagovN, He collected together the thing: whence DigovN signifying “a handful of herbs, &c.” (Mṣb.) See also 2.
And [hence,] Dagava AlHadiyva, (A, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) ‡ He confused, or confounded, [or related in a confused manner,] the tradition, or story, or the like. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ)
And Dagava Alv-awoba ‡ He washed the garment, or piece of cloth, without cleansing it, (O, Ḳ, TA,) so that it remained in a dubious state. (TA.)

Dagava Als-anaAma, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ,) He felt the camel's hump in order to know whether it were fat or not: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and DagavahaA he felt her [i. e. a she-camel] for that purpose. (TA.)
Dagava, accord. to the Ḳ, [and the O, as on the authority of Fr,] is also said of a waral, meaning It uttered a cry: but this is correctly with b [i. e. Dagaba]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Dg-v Aln-abaAta He made the plants, or herbage, what are termed OaDoEaAv [pl. of DiEovN]. (A, TA.)

[Hence,] Dg-v raOosahu † He poured water upon his head, and then divided the hair with his fingers into separate handfuls, in order that the water might reach to the skin. (L, TA.) [But see what follows.] It is said in a trad. of ʼÁïsheh, kaAnato tuDag-ivu raOosahaA, (TA,) or taDogavu↓ rOshA, (so in the JM,) meaning She used to rub about the hair of her head with her hand, in washing, as though mixing it together, in order that the water with which she washed might enter into it. (TA.)
4. ADgv Alr-uWoyaA, said of a dreamer, ‡ He related the dream confusedly. (A, TA.)
8. ADTgv DigovFA He collected a handful of herbage, fresh and dry mixed together. (Ḳ.)
DagovN The state of a thing's being confused, one part with another. (TA.)

DigovN A handful of herbs, (AḤn, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) mixed together, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fresh and dry: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a handful of twigs of trees or shrubs; (Mgh,* Mṣb;) or of fruit-stalks of the raceme of a palm-tree: (Mgh, Mṣb:) originally, a number of twigs all having one root or stem: and afterwards applied to what is collected together: (Mṣb:) or a thing that one collects together, such as a bundle of [the species of trefoil called] raTobap; and of what has a stem, and grows tall: (Fr, TA:) or whatever is collected together, and grasped with the hand: (AHeyth, TA:) or a bundle of herbs mixed together; or of firewood: pl. OaDogaAvN. (TA.) In the Ḳur xxxviii. 43, it is said to mean A bundle of rushes (Oasal, so in the Mgh and the O, in my copy of the Mṣb Avl [which I think a mistranscription, on account of what follows]), a hundred in number, (O, Mṣb,) consisting of slender stalks without leaves, (Mgh, Mṣb,) whereof mats are made. (Mṣb.) See also a prov. cited and expl. voce UilaAlapN. Hence, in a trad., DigovaAni mino naArK, meaning ‡ Two bundles of lighted firewood. (TA.) And, in another trad., minohumu AlMxicu AlD-igova, meaning † Among them is he who obtains somewhat of worldly goods. (TA.)

Also † What is confused, and without truth, or reality, [of dreams, and] of news, or tidings, and of an affair. (Sh, TA.) OaDogaAvu OaHolaAmK, [occurring in the Ḳur xii. 44 and xxi. 5,] of which the sing. is Digovu HulomK, (Mṣb,) means ‡ Complications of dreams; (A;) or medleys of dreams, falsely resembling true dreams: (O, Mṣb:) or a dream of which the interpretation will not prove true, because of its confusedness: (ISh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a false dream; the pl. form being used to give emphasis to the meaning of unreality, or because the phrase comprehends various things: (Bḍ in xii. 44:) or OaDogaAvu Alr-uWoyaA means the terrors, or frightful things, of the dream. (Mujáhid, O, TA.) One says also, OataAnaA biOaDogaAvK mina AlOaxobaAri, meaning ‡ He brought us [various] sorts of news, or tidings. (TA.) DigovN means also † A deed that is of a mixed kind, not pure, or not sincere. (IAth and O, from a trad.) And kalaAmN DigovN † Speech in which is no good: pl. OaDogaAvN. (TA.)

DaguwvN, applied to a she-camel, i. q. DabuwvN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. Of which one doubts whether she be fat, and which one therefore feels with his hand; (Ṣ;) or of which one feels the hump, in order to know whether she be fat or not: pl. DugovN. (TA.) And A camel's hump of which one doubts whether it be fat or not. (Kr, TA.)
DagiyvapN A confused company of men. (O.)

DaAgivN One who hides himself in a thicket or the like, and frightens boys by a sound reiterated in his fauces: (Ṣ:) the author of the Ḳ, following Ṣgh in the TṢ and O, and Az in the T, says that this is a mistake, and that the word is correctly written with b [i. e. DaAgibN]; but IF and IM and others write it as in the Ṣ. (TA.)
taDogiyvN Rain that moistens the earth and the herbage. (Ḳ.)

1. DagaTahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDogaTu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. DagoTN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He pressed him; pushed him; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) squeezed him; (Mgh,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) against (UilaI, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, [and EalaI,]) a thing, (Ḳ,) or a wall, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the like, (Ṣ,) and the ground: (TA:) he straitened him: he overcame, subdued, or overpowered, him; or he constrained him. (TA.) It is said in a trad., latuDogaTun-a EalaI baAbi Aljan-api Ye shall assuredly be pressed, or pushed, against the gate of Paradise. (TA.) You say of a tight boot, DagaTa rijolahu [It compressed, or pinched, his foot]. (Ḳ in art. Hzq.) And you say also, DagaTa Ealayohi, and AiDotagaTa↓, (Lḥ, TA,) which latter, by rule, should be AiDoTagaTa, (TA,) † He treated him with hardness, severity, or rigour, with respect to a debt or the like. (Lḥ, TA.)

3. DAgTwA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DigaATN (IDrd, T, O, TA) and muDaAgaTapN; (IDrd, O;) and tDAgTwA↓; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) They pressed, pushed, crowded, or straitened, one another; syns. zaAHamuwA and AzdHmwA. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.) You say, taDaAgaTa↓ Aln-aAsu fiI AlAizodiHaAmi [The people pressed, or pushed, one another in crowding together]; and DigaATN is like taDaAguTN. (T, TA.)
6: see 3, in two places.

7. AnZgT [as quasi-pass. of 1, app. signifies He was, or became, pressed, pushed, or squeezed: and, accord. to a version of the Bible, as mentioned by Golius, in Num. xx. (or xxii.) 25, he pressed, or squeezed, himself, against (UilaI) a wall: and also,] † he (a man) was, or became, overcome, subdued, or overpowered; or constrained; syn. Ainoqahara. (TA.)
8: see 1, last sentence.
DagoTapN The pressure of the grave; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because it straitens the dead: (Mṣb:) its straitening. (Mgh.)

It is also expl. by En-Naḍr [ISh] as signifying mjAhrp [app. a mistake for mujaAhadapN, as meaning † The exertion of one's utmost power, ability, or endeavour, in contending with another: and in this sense it should perhaps be written DugoTapN↓]. (TA.)
See also DugoTapN, in two places.

DugoTapN ‡ Straitness; difficulty; distress; affliction; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DagoTapN↓. (TA.) You say, Aall-ehum-a QrofaEo Ean-aA hecihi AlD-ugoTapa [O God, withdraw, put away, or remove, from us this straitness,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

† Force, constraint, compulsion; (Mgh;) as also DagoTapN↓: (TA: [in which one of the syns. is written qabor, evidently a mistake for qahorN, one of the syns. of the former word in the Mgh:]) constraint, or compulsion, against the will of the object thereof. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) You say, Oaxacotu fulaAnFA DagoTapF † I treated such a one with hardness, severity, or rigour, to constrain him, or compel him, to do the thing against his will. (Ṣ.) And hence the trad. of Shureyh, kaAna laA yujiyzu AlD-ugoTapa † He used not to allow the constraint, or compulsion, of one's debtor, and the treating him with hardness, severity, or rigour: or one's saying, I will not give thee unless thou abate somewhat of my debt to thee: or one's having money owed to him by another, who disacknowledges it, and compounding with him for part of what is owed to him, then finding the voucher, and exacting from him the whole of the property after the compromise. (Mgh.)
See also DagoTapN.

hom.sense: DagiyTN A well having by the side of it another well, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and one of them becomes foul with black mud, (Aṣ, Ṣ, O,) or and one of them becomes choked up, and foul with black mud, (Ḳ,) so that its water becomes stinking, and it flows into the water of the sweet well, and corrupts it, so that no one drinks of it: (Aṣ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or a well that is dug by the side of another well, in consequence of which its water becomes little in quantity: or a well dug between two wells that have become choked up. (O.)

And A man weak in judgment, (Ḳ, TA,) that will not be roused to action with the people: (TA:) pl. DagoTaI, (Ḳ, TA,) [like maroDaI, &c.,] because it is as though it were [significant of suffering from] a disease. (TA.)

DaAgiTN A slitting in the arm-pit of a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and abundance of flesh [in that part, pressing against the side]: (Ṣ:) and i. q. Dab-N: (Ṣ, Ḳ) or a thing like a bag: (TA:) a tumour in the armpit of a camel, like a bag, straitening him: (Meyd: see muEar-akN:) or skin collected together: or the base of the callous protuberance upon the breast of a camel pressing against the place of the arm-pit, and marking, or scarring, and excoriating, it. (TA.) Accord. to IDrd, baEiyrN bihi DaAgiTN means A camel whose arm-pit comes in contact with his side so as to mark it, or scar it. (TA.)

‡ A watcher, keeper, or guardian; a confidential superintendent; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) over a person; so called because he straitens him; (Ṣ;) or over a thing. (Ḳ.) You say, Orosalahu DaAgiTFA EalaI fulaAnK ‡ He sent him as a watcher,, &c., over such a one. (Ṣ, TA.) And hence what is said in the trad. of Mo'ádh, (Ṣ, L,) when his wife asked him, on his return from collecting the poor-rates in El-Yemen, where was the present which he had brought for his wife, and he answered, (L,) kaAna EalaI-a DaAgiTN [There was over me a watcher], (Ṣ,) or kaAna maEiI DaAgiTN [There was with me a watcher], meaning God, who knows the secrets of men; or he meant, by DAgT, the trust committed to him by God, which he had taken upon himself; but his wife imagined that there was with him a watcher who straitened him, and prevented his taking to please her. (L.)

entry.sense: 1. Dagina, (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDoganu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaganN (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and DigonN, (AZ, TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or it, i. e. one's bosom, (Mṣb,) was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or, said of a man, his bosom was, or became, affected therewith; (AZ, TA;) Ealayohi against him. (Ṣ.) [See also DigonN below.]

And, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. ns. as above, (TA,) He inclined, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) Uilayohi towards him, (IAạr, TA,) and Ealayohi against him, (TA,) and UilaI Ald-unoyaA [towards the present world, or worldly things]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Daginati AlqanaApu, inf. n. DaganN, ‡ The spear-shaft was, or became, crooked. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. ns. as above, (TA,) He was, or became, affected with desire, or with yearning or longing of the soul. (Ḳ, TA.)

6. taDaAgunN The conceiving, or being affected with, mutual rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (KL, and Ḥar p. 43.) You say, tDAgnwA and ADTgnwA↓ They had, or held, in the heart, feelings of mutual rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8: see what next precedes {6}.
One says also, ADTgn EalaI fulaAnK DagiynapF He conceived, or concealed, [in his heart,] rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against such a one. (TA.)

And ADTgnhu He took it (i. e. a thing, and weapon, Ṣ) beneath his HiDon [or the part between his armpit and flank,, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he carried him (i. e. a child) in that part, or in his bosom. (TA.)

AlAiDoTigaAnu is also syn. with AlAiXotimaAlu, which is The putting [a portion of] the garment beneath [and within] the right arm, [app. from behind,] and the other end beneath the left arm, and drawing it [i. e. the garment] together with the left hand. (TA. [But see AiXotamala.])

hom.sense: DigonN [said by some to be an inf. n.: (see 1:)] Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DagiynapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or both signify vehement rancour, &c.; and enmity; and violent hatred: (TA:) the pl. of the former is OaDogaAnN; (MA, Mṣb;) and that of ↓the latter is DagaAYinu, (MA,) and DagiynN↓ may be a pl. of DagiynapN, [or rather a coll. gen. n.,] or the p may be elided by poetic license; or these two may be dial. vars., like Huq-N and Huq-apN [accord. to some], and bayaADN and bayaADapN. (TA.) One says, when he has sought to gain a person's good will, or approval, salalotu Digona fulaAnK and Dagiynatahu↓ [I drew forth the rancour,, &c., of such a one]. (TA.) And a woman who hates her husband is said to be caAtu DigonK EalaI zawojihaA [One who has a feeling of rancour,, &c., against her husband]. (TA.)

And Difficulty of disposition in a beast: so in the phrase caAtu DigonK [A beast (daAb-apN) having a difficult disposition]. (TA.) See also the phrase caAtu XagobK waDigonK, applied to a she-ass, in art. Xgb.
And Inclination. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says, DigoniI UilaI fulaAnK My inclination is towards such a one. (Ṣ.)

And Desire; or yearning or longing of the soul. (Ḳ, TA.) One says naAqapN caAtu DigonK meaning A she-camel yearning towards, or longing for, her home, or accustomed place, (Ṣ, TA,) and her mates. (Ṣ. [See a verse cited voce rifaAqN.]) And sometimes DigonN is thus used, metaphorically, in relation to women. (TA.)
Also A side; or a region, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN. (Ḳ.)
And The UiboT [i. e. foot, bottom, or lowest part,] of a mountain: thus correctly, as in the “Nawádir:” in the copies of the Ḳ, Aljamal is erroneously put for Aljabal. (TA.)

entry.sense: And qanaApN DaginapN ‡ A crooked spear-shaft. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also DaAginN.
DaguwnN A horse, and a mare, that runs like him who reverts from the state in which he was, or from the course that he was following. (AO, TA. [See also DaAginN.])
DagiynN: see DigonN.
DagiynapN: see DigonN, in three places.
AlD-agiyniI-u The lion: (Ḳ, TA:) as though a rel. n. from AlD-agiynapu: because he is very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful. (TA.)
DaAginN: see DaginN.
Also A horse that will not exert his power of running unless beaten; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and so DaginN↓. (Ṣ,* TA. [See also DaguwnN.])
muDaAginN One who treats, or regards, his brother with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, or with enmity, being so regarded, or treated, by him; as also muDoTaginN↓. (TA.)
muDoTaginN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. Daf-ahu, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yaDofufu}, inf. n. Daf-N, (O,) He collected it together. (O; Ḳ,)
And Daf-a, [app. for Daf-a OaSaAbiEahu,] (Fr, O, Ḳ;) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Fr, O,) said of one warming himself, He closed his fingers together and put them near to the fire. (Fr, O, Ḳ.)

And Daf-a Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He milked the camel with the whole hand; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) because of the largeness of the dug; mentioned by Az, on the authority of Ks; (TA;) a dial. var. of Dab-ahaA: (Ṣ, O:) or, accord. to Fr, the doing thus is termed AlD-af-u; but AlD-ab-u signifies “the putting one's thumb upon the teat and then turning his fingers over the thumb and the teat together:” or, as is said on other authority, AlD-af-u signifies the clasping the two teats together with the hand when milking: [but this is also said to be the meaning of AlD-ab-u:] or, as Lḥ says, the grasping the teat with all one's fingers. (TA.)

Daf-a Alqawomu EalaI AlT-aEaAmi, or AlmaMCi, [aor. app. _i or _a or both,] inf. n. Daf-N and DafafN, [see the latter of these below,] The people, or party, pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together upon the food, or the water. (TḲ.) [See also what next follows {6}.]

entry.sense: 6. tDAf-wA Ealayohi They multiplied, or became numerous, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and collected themselves together, (O, Ḳ,) [and, accord. to an explanation of the part. n., by Lḥ, pushed, pressed, crowded, or thronged, together,] upon it, or at it; namely water, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,), &c.; (O, Ḳ;) like tSAf-wA. (TA.)
And tDAfwA signifies also, accord. to the O and Ḳ, xaf-ato OaHowaAluhumo; but correctly, as in the “Nawádir” of AZ, OamowaAluhumo [i. e. Their possessions became scanty]. (TA.)

hom.sense: Daf-N Narrow, or strait, and hard: so in the phrase rajulN Daf-u AlHaAli [A man whose state, or condition, is narrow, or strait, and hard]: (AZ, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) and one says also rjl Dafafu↓ AlHaAli and qawomN DafafuwA AlHaAli; but idghám is more proper. (Sb, TA.)
XaApN Daf-apu AlX-uxobi A ewe, or goat, whose stream of milk from the udder is wide. (AA, O, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Duf-N A little thing resembling the tick, of the colour of ashes and dust, the sting, or bite, of which causes the skin to break forth with the eruption termed XarFI [q. v.]: (Aboo-Málik, O, Ḳ:) pl. DifafapN, like qiradapN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: Daf-apN A single act of pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging, together upon water. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See DafafN])

daxalotu fiI Daf-api Alqawomi and DafoDafatihimo↓ (O, Ḳ *) are phrases mentioned by Aṣ (O, TA) and Lth (TA) as meaning I entered among the company, or collective body, of the people, or party. (O, Ḳ.*)

And Daf-apN signifies also The first dufoEap [i. e. rush, or quantity that pours forth at once or that is poured forth at once], or dafoEap [i. e. single act of pouring], (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) of water. (Ḳ.)
See also the next paragraph, in five places.

entry.sense: Dif-apN (T, Ṣ, O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Daf-apN↓ (T, O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) The side of a river (T, Ṣ, O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and of a well: (Mṣb:) Dif-ataAhu signifying its (a river's) two sides: (Ṣ:) and Daf-ataA↓ AlwaAdiI, or AlHayozuwmi, and Dif-ataAhu, the two sides of the valley, or of the Hyzwm [i. e. breast, or chest,, &c.]: (IAạr, Ḳ:) and Daf-apu↓ AlbaHori [or Dif-atuhu] the shore of the sea: (Ḳ:) and the dual of Daf-apN↓ [or Dif-apN?] occurs in a saying of ʼAlee metaphorically used as meaning † the two sides of the eyelids: (TA:) the pl. of Dif-apN is DifafN, (Mṣb,) or DifaAf; (TA;) and that of Daf-apN↓ is Daf-aAtN. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: DafafN The pushing, pressing, crowding, or thronging, together, of people, at, or upon, water [to drink thereof or to water their beasts]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ. [See also 1, last explanation.]) And Numerousness of the persons composing a family, or household. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Lḥ, visitors and friends that come time after time; and one's household, or family: or, as some say, i. q. HaXamN [i. e. one's dependents,, &c.]. (TA.) And The taking of food with other people: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:*) thus in a trad. in which it is said of the Prophet, maA XabiEa mino xubozK walaHomK Uil-aA EalaI DafafK [He did not satiate himself with the eating of bread and flesh-meat except in a case of taking thereof with others], as expl. by a man of the desert in answer to a question put to him by Málik Ibn-Deenár: (Ṣ, O: but in the latter, lamo yaXobaEo:) or the case of the eaters' being too many for the food: (Th, O, Ḳ:) [or,] accord. to Kh, (Ṣ, O,) numerousness of the hands upon the food: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) [or,] accord. to Aṣ, the case of the property's being little, and the devourers thereof many. (Ṣ, O.) [See also HafafN.] Accord. to AZ, (Ṣ, O,) Straitness, and hardness, or hardship: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) accord. to Fr, (Ṣ, O,) want. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See two exs. voce HafafN.] Also Weakness. (Fr, O, Ḳ.) And Haste (Fr, Ṣ, O, Mṣb) in an affair: (Mṣb:) so in the saying, laqiytuhu EalaI DafafK [I met him, or found him, in a state of haste]. (Fr, Ṣ, O.) And A quantity less than will fill the measure, and less than anything that is filled. (Sh, O, Ḳ.) And Food, or the eating, less than satiates. (TA.)
See also Daf-N.

entry.sense: DfAf [thus written without any syll. sign] The quality denoted by the epithet DafuwfN applied to a she-camel or a ewe or goat. (TA.)

DafuwfN Having much milk, not to be milked save with the whole hand; (O, Ḳ;*) applied to a camel, (O, Ḳ,) and to a ewe or goat: so in a verse cited voce SuwfN, as some relate it; but as others relate it, the word is Safuwf, with S. (TA.)
And [hence, app.,] EayonN DafuwfN † A source abounding with water. (TA.)

fulaAnN mino lafiyfinaA waDafiyfinaA, (O, TA,) in the Ḳ huwa mino DafiyfinaA walafiyfinaA, but the former is the right order, (TA,) a saying mentioned by Aboo-Saʼeed, (O, TA,) means Such a one is of those whom we associate with us, and those whom we congregate with us, when events befall us. (O, Ḳ,* TA.)
DafaAfapN, (O, Ḳ,) without teshdeed, (O,) like saHaAbapN, (Ḳ,) Devoid of intellect, or intelligence. (O, Ḳ.)
DafoDafapN: see Daf-apN.

maMCN maDofuwfN A water that is thronged [so that it has become little in quantity]; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) like maXofuwhN; (Ṣ, O;) to which many men and cattle have come: (Lḥ, TA:) occurring in a verse cited voce mudaArapN, in art. dwr: (Ṣ, O, TA:) in that verse, Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee, instead of AlmaDofuwf, read AlmaZofuwf; which means [the same, (Ḳ in art. Zf,) or] “occupied.” (IB, TA.)
[Hence,] rajulN maDofuwfN, ‡ A man exhausted of what he possessed [in consequence of much begging]; like mavomuwdN: (Ṣ, O, TA:) [see also maXofuwhN:] some say maDofuwfN Ealayohi. (TA.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. DafodaEa, said of water, It had in it DafaAdiE [or frogs]. (O, Ḳ.)
And, said of a man, He shrank, or became contracted; syn. taqab-aDa: or he voided his excrement, or ordure; or thin excrement; syn. salaHa: or he emitted wind from the anus, with a sound. (TA.)

entry.sense: DifodiEN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DafodaEN and DufodaEN (Ḳ) and DifodaEN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) this last said by some, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) but most rare, or rejected, (Ḳ,) disallowed by Kh and a number of others, (Mṣb,) [for] accord. to Kh [and others] there are only four words of the measure fiEolalN in the language, which are dirohamN and hijoraEN and hibolaEN and the proper name qiloEamN, (Ṣ, O,) [The frog; and app. also the water-toad;] a certain reptile (daAb-ap) of the rivers, (Ḳ, TA,) generated in the river, (TA,) the flesh of which, cooked with oliveoil, is [said to be] an antidote to the poison of venomous creatures, (Ḳ, TA,) when put upon the place of the sting, or bite: (TA:) and [a certain reptile] of the land, (Ḳ, TA,) [app. the landtoad,] that lives, or grows, in caverns and caves, (TA,) the fat of which is [said to be] wonderful for the extraction of teeth (Ḳ, TA) without fatigue, and of the skin of which, tanned, the skull-cap that renders invisible (TaAqiy-apu AlUixofaMCi [a vulgar term]) is made, as is said by the performers of legerdemain; and the flesh of this species is said to be poisonous: (TA;) the fem., (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) or the n. un., (Ḳ,) is with p {DifodiEapN}: and the pl. is DafaAdiEu (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) [and DafaAdK; in the Mṣb and Ḳ, DafaAdiI; in the O, correctly, AlD-afaAdiI is said to be a var. of AlD-afaAdiEu, like Alv-aEaAliI and AlOaraAniI of Alv-aEaAlibu and AlOaraAnibu].
naq-ato DafaAdiEu baTonihi [lit. The frogs of his belly croaked] means † he was, or became, hungry; (O, Ḳ;) like naq-ato EaSaAfiyru baTonihi. (O.)

AlD-ifodiEu AlOaw-alu is a name of † The bright star [α] on the mouth of Piscis Australis; (Ḳzw, Descr. of Aquarius;) also called famu AlHuwti: (Idem, Descr. of Piscis Australis:) and AlD-ifodiEu Alv-aAniI is the name of † The star on the southern fork of the tail of Cetus. (Idem.)

And AlD-ifodiEu, (O, Ḳ,) thus only, (TA,) † A certain bone [or horny substance, which we, in like manner, call “the frog,”] in the interior of the horse's hoof, (O, Ḳ,) in the sole thereof. (O.) [See also nasorN.]
muDafodiEaAtN Waters abounding with DafaAdiE [or frogs]. (Ṣ, O.)

hom.sense: 1. Dafara, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yaDofiru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaforN, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) He plaited, braided, or interwove, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) hair, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,), &c., (Ṣ,) or the like, (TA,) or a [lock of hair, such as is called] cuWaAbap, and a [girth of thongs such as is called] nisoE, (A,) in a wide form; (Ṣ, Mgh;) as also Df-r↓, inf. n. taDofiyrN: (Ṣ, TA:) he made hair into DafaAYir, [pl. of DafiyrapN,] each Dafiyrap consisting of three or more distinct portions. (Mṣb.)
He twisted a rope or cord. (Ḳ.)
Dafarato XaEarahaA, (Ṣ, TA,) aor. _i {yaDofiru}, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) said of a woman, (Ṣ, TA.) She gathered together her hair. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And Dafara, from the same verb in the first of the senses expl. above, ‡ He made, or constructed, a [dam of the kind called] Dafiyrap. (IAạr, TA.)

DaforN also signifies † The building with stones without [the cement called] kilos and without clay. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, Dafara AlHijaArapa Hawola bayotihi † [He built the stones around his house, or tent, without mortar or clay]. (TA.)

Dafara AlbaEiyra AlElafa, (A,) inf. n. DaforN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He put the fodder into the mouth of the camel, (A, Ḳ,*) against his will. (A.) And Dafara Alfarasa lijaAmahu, (A,) or Dafara Ald-aAb-apa, aor. _i {yaDofiru}, inf. n. DaforN, (TA,) ‡ He put the bit into the mouth of the horse, (A,) or of the beast. (TA.)

Also Dafara, aor. _i {yaDofiru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DaforN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He ran; syn. EadaA and saEaI: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he hastened, or went quickly: or he bounded, or sprang: (TA:) he leaped (Aṣ, Ḳ) in his running. (Aṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the preceding paragraph {1}, first sentence.
3. DAfrhu He aided him. (A, Mṣb.) [See also 6.]
6. tDAfrwA They leagued together, and aided one another, (Ibn-Buzurj, Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) EalaI AlOamori to do the thing, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,) and EalaI fulaAnK against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj.)
7. AnDfr AlHabolaAni The two ropes became twisted together. (Ṣ.)

DaforN A camel's girth, of plaited [goats'] hair; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also DafaArN↓: (Ḳ:) the girth of a camel's saddle: (Ṣ:) a wide girth of a camel's saddle; as also DafiyrapN↓: pl. [of mult.] (of the first, TA) DufuwrN (Ḳ, TA) and [of pauc.] OaDofaArN; (TA;) and (of the second, TA) DufurN. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also DafiyrapN, in three places.

Also † A great quantity of sand that has become collected together: or a quantity of sand that has become accumulated, part upon part; (Ḳ;) and (Ḳ) so DafirapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of the former] DufuwrN; (Ḳ;) and [coll. gen. n.] of the latter DafirN↓: (Ṣ:) or a long, broad, Hiqof [generally expl. as meaning a winding tract] of sand; by some pronounced DafarN↓: (Lth, TA:) [or] a Hiqof of sand is termed DafiyrapN↓. (Ṣ.)
DafarN: see the last preceding sentence.

hom.sense: DafirN and [its n. un.] DafirapN: see DaforN.

kinaAnapN DafirapN [in the TA Dfyrp, evidently a mistranscription,] i. q. mumotaliYapN [i. e. A full quiver]. (Ṣ, O. [Freytag writes kinAnpu DafirapN, and explains it as meaning “Gens Cinanah impleta est:” but in my copies of the Ṣ and in the O, it is kinaAnapN.])

entry.sense: DafaArN: see DaforN, first sentence.
DafiyrN A rope of [goats'] hair, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) twisted: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)
And † The shore, or side, of the sea or of a great river; (O, Ḳ,* TA;;) as also DafiyrapN↓. (TA.)

DafayrapN (Aṣ, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DaforN↓, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) the latter an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly so termed], (Mgh,) A single lock of hair: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and (Mṣb) a [lock of hair such as is termed] cuWaAbap, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or jamiyrap and gadiyrap, of a woman: (Aṣ, TA:) or a plaited, braided, or interwoven, cWAbp: (A, TA;) or [a plait of hair] consisting of three, or more, distinct portions: (Mṣb:) or i. q. EaqiySapN [q. v.]: one says lahaA DafiyrataAni, and DaforaAni↓, meaning EaqiySataAni: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ:) or the DafiyrataAni pertain to a man, not to a woman; [though such is not the case accord. to modern usage;] and gadaAYir, [pl. of gadiyrapN,] to women; and these are maDofuwrap [i. e. plaited]: (AZ, TA:) the pl. of DafiyrapN is DafaAYiru (A, Mṣb) and DufurN; (Mṣb;) and the pl. of DaforN↓ is DufuwrN. (A.)
See also DaforN, in two places.
DafiyrapN also signifies ‡ A dam, (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) extending in an oblong form upon the ground, having in it wood and stones. (IAạr, TA.)
And † A plain, or soft, tract of land, oblong, producing herbage or the like, extending [to the distance of the journey of] a day, or two days. (TA.)
See also DafiyrN.
AlD-aAfiru fiI AlHaj-i He who twists, or plaits, (yaEoqiSu,) his hair during the performance of the pilgrimage. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. DafaA, aor. yaDofuw, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. DafowN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Dafuw-N, (Mṣb,) It (a thing, Ṣ, and a garment, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, complete, full, ample, or without deficiency. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)

And It was, or became, much in quantity; (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA;) said of property, or property consisting in cattle, (Ṣ, TA,) and of hair, and of wool. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, Dafato Ealayohi Aln-iEomapu, i. q. raf-ato [i. e. Wealth became abundantly bestowed upon him]. (M in art. rf.) And DafaA AlEayoXu, meaning Ait-asaEa [i. e. The means of subsistence became ample]. (Mṣb.)
And DafaA AlHawoDu, (TA,) inf. n. DafowN, (Ḳ, TA,) The watering-trough overflowed (Ḳ,* TA) by reason of its fulness. (TA.)
DafiIa He (a man) became poor: mentioned by Az in art. Dyq. (TA.)

entry.sense: DafFA A side: and DafawaAhu his, or its, two sides. (Ḳ.) [Daf-apN and Dif-apN, also, have a similar meaning.]
DafowN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.: and as a simple subst.,] Wealth, or prosperity, and ampleness [of circumstances]. (TA.) [See also what next follows.]

Dafowapu AlEayoXi An easy and a plentiful state, or condition, of life. (Ḳ, TA.) One says, fulaAnN fiI DafowapK mino EayoXihi [Such a one is in an easy and a plentiful state, or condition, in respect of his means of subsistence]. (Ṣ.)

vawobN DaAfK A garment that is complete, full, ample, or without deficiency. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.*) And farasN DaAfiI Als-abiyb A horse full, or ample, in the sbyb [or hair of the forelock or of the mane or of the tail]. (TA.) And rajulN DaAfiI Alr-aOosi A man having much hair of the head. (Ṣ.) And diym-pN DaAfyapN A lasting, or continuous, or continuous and still, rain, in consequence of which the land becomes abundant with herbage. (TA.) And huwa DaAfiI AlfaDoli ‡ [He is abundant in excellence]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. Dalalotu, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) third pers. Dal-a, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yaDolilu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DalaAlN and DalaAlapN; (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb;) and Dalilotu, (Ṣ, Mgh,* O, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) third pers. as above; (Mgh;) the former of the dial. of Nejd, and the more chaste; the latter of the dial. of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and of El-Ḥijáz, and Kr has mentioned Dililotu for Dalilotu as heard from the tribe of Temeem; (TA;) I erred, strayed, or went astray; (Mgh, Mṣb;) deviated from the right way or course, or from that which was right; missed, or lost, the right way; or lost my way; DalaAlN and DalaAlapN signifying the contr. of raXaAdN, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and hudFI. (Ḳ, TA.) [See DalaAlN below.] Hence, in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 49], qulo Uino Dalalotu fiUin-amaA OaDil-u EalaI nafosiI [Say thou, If I err, I shall err only against myself, i. e., to my own hurt]. (O, Mṣb. [See also x. 108 and xvii. 16 of the Ḳur.]) One says also, Dal-a DalaAluhu [app. His error became error indeed; a phrase similar to jad-a jid-uhu, q. v.: or his erring passed away; see 4, latter part]. (TA.) And Dal-a Eani AlqaSodi He deviated from the right way or course. (TA.) And the verb is trans. as well as intrans.: you say, Dal-a AlT-ariyqa, and Dal-a Eanohu,, aor. _i {yaDolilu} and _a {yaDolalu}, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. ns. as above, meaning He erred, strayed, or went astray, from the road, or way; (Mṣb;) he did not find the way to the road: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and of anything stationary, if you miss the place thereof, you say Dalalotuhu and Dalilotuhu: (Az, Mṣb:) or you say, Dalilotu AlT-ariyqa, (Ḳ,) or Dalilotu Almasojida, and Ald-aAra, (ISk, Ṣ, O,) [I missed, or lost, the right way to the road, or the mosque, and the house,] when you know not the place thereof: (ISk, Ṣ, O:) and in like manner, anything stationary, to which one does not find the way: (ISk, Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and AA says the like: but that one says of a thing that falls from his hand, and a thing that quits its place, OaDolalotuhu↓, (IB, TA,) which means I lost it, and knew not its place; meaning, for instance, a horse, or she-camel, or the like: (Az, Mṣb:) [thus] one says, OaDolalotu biEiyriI [I lost my camel, and knew not his place,] (AA, ISk, Ṣ, IB, O) when his shank has been tied up to his arm and one does not find the way to him, and when he has been left loose and has gone away whither one knows not: (AA, IB, TA:) but Yoo differs from others respecting this case; for, accord. to him, one says, ADl- fulaAnN baEiyrahu and also Dal-ahu, in the same sense; (O, TA;) and the like is said in the Ḳ: (TA:) and it is also said in the Bári' that when you seek an animal and miss its place and find not the way to it, it is regarded as in the category of stationary things, and therefore you say Dalilotuhu. (Mṣb.)
Dal-a signifies also He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (Ibn-Es-Seed, TA.)

Also, aor. _i {yaDolilu} (Ṣ, O, Ḳ) and _a, (Ḳ,) the pret. being like zal-a and mal-a, (TA,) inf. n. DalaAl, It (a thing, Ṣ, O, TA) became lost; [as though it went astray;] it perished, came to nought, or passed away. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA.) Thus in the phrase Dal-a Ean-iI kacaA Such a thing became lost from me. (Mgh.) One says to him from whom pieces of money have dropped, qado Dal-ato Eanoka [They have become lost from thee]. (TA.) And to him who has done a deed from which no profit has resulted, you say, qad Dal-a saEoyuka ‡ [Thy labour has been lost]: the like occurs in the Ḳur xviii. 104, meaning DaAEa. (TA, in two places.)

And ‡ He (a man, TA) died, and became dust and bones. (Ḳ, TA.) In this sense the verb is used in the Ḳur xxxii. 9: but some there read, in the place of DalalonaA, SalilonaA [q. v.], with S: (TA:) or the verb in that instance has the meaning here next following. (Ṣ.)

And † He, or it, (a man, Ṣ, TA, or a camel, Mṣb, and a thing, TA,) was, or became, unperceived or imperceptible, unapparent, latent, hidden or concealed, or absent, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the phrase, Dal-a AlmaMCu fiI All-abani ‡ [The water became unperceived, or concealed, in the milk]. (TA.) One says of a road to which he has not been able to find the way, Dal-a Ean-iI [It has become hidden from me]. (Ḳ, TA.)
And hence also the saying of a man, as is related in a trad., (Ṣ, O, TA,) after his having charged his sons by saying to them, “When I die, burn ye me; and when I shall have become ashes, pound me; then scatter me in the water:” (O, TA:) laEal-iI OaDil-u Qll-eh (Ṣ, O, TA) i. e. † May-be, I shall be unperceived by God, or concealed from Him: (Ṣ:) or may-be, I shall be hidden, or absent, from God's punishment: (O, TA:) or, as El-'Otbee says, may-be, I shall escape God, and my place will be hidden from Him. (TA.) And Dal-a said of one forgetting means † His memory became absent from him. (O, Mṣb, TA.) Oano taDil-a UiHodaAhumaA, or Uino taDil-a, in the Ḳur [ii. 282], accord. to different readers, (TA,) in which instance Oano and Uino are syn., (Mughnee, [see Oano, in p. 106, cols. 1 and 2,]) means If one of them twain [referring to women] be absent from her memory: or if the memory of one of them twain be absent from her: [or if one of them twain err in her memory:] or, accord. to Zj, the meaning of the verb in this case is that which next follows. (TA.)

Dalilotu AlX-aIoCa also signifies † I forgot the thing: whence one says of a woman, Dal-ato Oay-aAma HayoDihaA † [She forgot the days of her menstruation]; and so OaDal-atohaA↓: (Mgh:) or Dal-a fulaAnFA † He was made, or caused, to forget such a one. (Ḳ. [In the CK, Aunosiyohi is erroneously put for Ounosiyahu.]) It is said that laA yaDil-u rab-iI, in the Ḳur xx. 54, means † My Lord will not be unmindful: or nothing will escape Him. (TA.)

And one says, Dal-aniI fulaAnN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or Dal-aniI fulaAnN falamo Oaqodaro Ealayohi, (O,) meaning Such a one went away from me, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and I was unable to compass him [or to find him]: so in the Bári'. (Mṣb.)
Dul-a, as a verb of wonder: see Dul-N.

entry.sense: 2. Dlalhu, (Ṣ, MA, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoliylN and taDolaAlN, (Ḳ,) He, or it, made, or caused, him to pursue a course that led to error, or deviation from the right way: (Ḳ: [see also 4:]) he, or it, led him astray; seduced him: (MA:) [or] he attributed, or imputed, to him error, or deviation from the right way. (Ṣ, MA, O.) Dul-ila saEoyuhumo, a phrase used by a poet, means Error, or deviation from the right way, was attributed to their labour; because they did not reach their goal. (Ḥam p. 771.)
[Hence,] one says, Dal-ilo maAlaka Send forth, or set free, thy cattle to pasture, or to pasture where they please, by themselves. (O.)
See also the next paragraph {4}.

4. ADl-hu, inf. n. UiDolaAlN, He, or it, made him, or caused him, to err, stray, or go astray; to deviate from the right way or course, or from that which was right; to miss, or lose, the right way; or to lose his way. (Az, TA.)
