DaniykN: see DanokN.
Also Weak in his body, and in his intellect, (AZ, O, Ḳ,) and in his judgment, and in his soul. (Ḳ,)
And A servant who works for his bread. (AZ, O, Ḳ.)
And i. q. maqoTuwEN [Cut off;, &c.]. (AA, O, Ḳ.)

DunoOakN Hard, and firm and compact in flesh; (Lḥ, O, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (Lḥ, O;) as also DanoOakN: (Ḳ:) fem. DunoOakapN; (Lḥ, O, Ḳ;) applied to a woman. (Lḥ, O.) And, applied to a she-camel, Great, (Ḳ, TA,) and compact in make: (TA:) as also with p {DunoOakapN}. (Ḳ.)
muDonakN, (TA,) or mutaDan-ikN↓, (O,) Affected with a constant, or chronic, pervading disease; or emaciated by disease so as to be at the point of death. (O, TA.)
maDonuwkN Affected with the malady termed DunaAk [q. v.]. (Ṣ, O,)
mutaDan-ikN: see muDonakN.
1. Danati AlmaroOapu, inf. n. DanaMCN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and DanFA, (M, Ḳ,) The woman had many children; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also Daniyat: (Ḳ:) and so with C. (Ṣ.)
And DanaA naSiybuhu His share, or portion, became redundant; it increased, or augmented. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
DanowN and DinowN Children, or offspring; (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like DanoCN and DinoCN; as also DunFA↓, accord. to IAạr. (TA.)
DunFA: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. DaniIa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDonaIu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. DanFI; (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and ADTnI↓ signifies the same; He was, or became, slender, and small in body: and hence, (Ḥam p. 112,) he was, or became, diseased, disordered, or sick; (Ṣ, and Ḥam ibid.;) because disease occasions leanness, or emaciation: (Ḥam:) or he was, or became, lean, or emaciated: (so accord. to the explanation of the inf. n. in the Mgh:) or he was, or became, affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he was at the point of death, (Mṣb,) or such as infected, or pervaded, him, and so that, whenever he thought himself to be recovering, he relapsed. (Ḳ.)
[See also 1 in art. Dnw.]

entry.sense: 3. muDaAnaApN i. q. muEaAnaApN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, KL,) both signifying The suffering, or enduring, [or contending with,], the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, of a thing; as also muqaAsaApN. (KL.)

hom.sense: 4. ADnAhu, said of a disease, disorder, or sickness, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It rendered him such as is termed DanFI or DanK: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) rendered him lean, or emaciated: (Mgh:) or oppressed him; burdened him heavily; overburdened him; or overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (Ṣ, TA.)
And OaDonaI He kept to the bed by reason of what is termed DanFI [i. e. leanness, or emaciation; or disease, disorder, or sickness, or such as was of long continuance,, &c.: see 1]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tDn-I He (a man) feigned himself diseased, disordered, or sick. (TA.)
8. ADTnI: see 1.
See also 8 in art. DnO.
DanFI: inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, M, &c.)

Also, [in some copies of the Ḳ erroneously written DaniI-N,] and DanK↓; (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the former applied alike to a man (Fr, IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb) and to a woman (IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb) and to two persons (Mṣb) and to a pl. number, (Fr, IAạr, T, Ṣ, Mṣb,) because originally an inf. n., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) for cuw DanFI and caAtu DanFI [&c.]; (Mṣb;) or some do not dualize it nor pluralize it, because it is [originally] an inf. n., and others dualize it and pluralize it; (M;) but DanK↓ has a fem. (Mṣb) and a dual and a pl., (Ṣ,) its fem. being DaniyapN (Mṣb, TA) [and its dual DaniyaAni] and the pl. is OaDonaMCN; (TA;) [Slender, and small in body: and hence, (see 1,)] diseased, disordered, or sick: (Ṣ:) [or lean, or emaciated: (see again 1:)] or affected with a disease, disorder, or sickness, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of long continuance, and settled, (M,) or constant, so that he is at the point of death, (Mṣb,) or such as infects, or pervades, him, and so that, whenever he thinks himself to be recovering, he relapses. (Ḳ.) You say, tarakotuhu DanFI and DaniyFA↓ [I left him lean, or diseased,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
DinFI, [written in the TA DnA, but the final radical is I,] with kesr, accord to IAạr, signifies Pains that cause fear. (TA.)
DanaMCN, like salaAmN [in measure, The state of such as is termed DanFI or DanK], a subst. from DaniIa. (Mṣb.)

3. muDaAhaOapN is syn. with muDaAhaApN, (Ḳ, TA, [the w before AlmuDAhApu in the CK should be erased,]) i. q. muXaAkalapN: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, TA:) you say, DaAhaOotuhu and DaAhayotuhu, (ʼEyn, Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,* TA,) i. e. I resembled him; syn. XaAbahotuhu: (ʼEyn, TA:) [or I conformed with him:] or DaAhaOahu, inf. n. as above, signifies he imitated him; syn. EaAraDahu and baAraAhu; and one says also, DaAhayotuhu, inf. n. muDaAhaApN: (Mṣb:) the verb is read both with and without C in the Ḳur [ix. 30]. (O, Mṣb, TA.)

DaAhaA bihi, (AʼObeyd, TA,) [or DaAhaOahu, like DaAhaAhu, mentioned in art. DhI,] inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) He (a man) was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently,, &c., with him, or to him. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,* TA.)
Q. Q. 1. Q. Q. 1. or Q. 1. DahoyaOa: see art. DhyO.
DahoyaON and DahoyaOapN: see art. DhyO.

hom.sense: 1. Dahabahu biAln-aAri, aor. _a {yaDohabu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. DahobN, (TḲ,) He altered it, (Ḳ, TA,) and changed its colour, (TA,) by means of fire. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also 2.]

Dahaba said of a man, (O, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yaDohabu}, (TA,) inf. n. DuhuwbN, (O, Ḳ,) ‡ He failed of fulfilling his promise (Oaxolafa), and was weak, and not like a man: (O, Ḳ, TA:) as though likened to meat not thoroughly cooked. (TA. [See 2.])

And Dahobu Alqawomi signifies AixotilaATuhumo [i. e. The people's being mixed, or confused]: (JK, O:) or OaxolaATuhumo [i. e. DahobN↓ is a subst., signifying a medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of people]. (So in the Ḳ. [But I think that this explanation is a mistranscription.]) [Or it signifies The people's multiplying themselves, and hastening: for] it is said in the “Nawádir” that Dahaba Alqawomu and DahabuwA and hulabuwA and OunabuwA and HuT-abuwA all denote AlUikovaAr and AlUisoraAE: so in the T in art. hDb. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Dh-b, inf. n. taDohiybN, He roasted (Lth, Ḳ, TA) flesh-meat (Lth, TA) upon heated stones: (Lth, Ḳ, TA:) or he roasted, (Ḳ,) or put into the fire, (AA, TA,) but did not cook thoroughly, (AA, Ḳ, TA,) flesh-meat. (AA, TA.)
And, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, O,) He exposed a bow, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and a spear, (Ṣ, O,) to the fire, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) on the occasion of straightening it, (Ṣ, O,) or to straighten it. (Ḳ.) [See also 1.]
And He collected together the fire; (JK;) and so DahoDaba↓. (JK, O, Ḳ.)
3. muDaAhabapN signifies Mutual reviling or vilifying; (Ḳ;) the addressing each other with bad words. (TA.)

Q. 1. DahoDaba: see 2, last sentence. [Mentioned in this art., as though Q. Q., contr. to the rule generally observed with respect to words of four radical letters of which the first and third are identical but not the second and fourth.]
DahobN: see the first paragraph {1}.
qawosN DahobaMCu A bow upon which the fire has taken effect [so as to alter its colour]: (O, Ḳ:) like DaboHaMCu. (TA.)

DayohabN i. q. SayohabN, meaning A place where flesh-meat is roasted [on the ground heated by the sun]; (Ḳ; [in the CK, limaXowiI-i All-Hmi is erroneously put for limaXowaI All-aHomi;]) accord. to Lth, any [high ground such as is called] quf-, or rugged ground, or place on a mountain, upon which the sun shines with such heat that flesh-meat will roast upon it: but Az says that what Lth means is SayohabN only, with the unpointed S; (O,* TA;) and if so, the meaning assigned here in the Ḳ is not correct. (TA.)

muDah-abN Flesh-meat roasted, but not thoroughly cooked: (Ṣ, A, O:) accord. to El-Mufaddal, flesh-meat cut in pieces; (O;) and thus in the Ḳ; (TA;) but IF says that this is nought, unless it be cut in pieces roasted: (O:) it is at variance with what is said by the leading authorities, for they say that it means flesh-meat roasted upon heated stones: or roasted upon the fire, but not thoroughly cooked: (TA:) or cooked in a fryingpan. (TA in art. ErS.) Imra-el-Ḳeys says,
namuX-u biOaEoraAfi AljiyaAdi Oakuf-anaA
UicaA naHonu qumonaA Eano XiwaMCK muDah-abi
[We wipe our hands with the manes of the swift horses when we rise from eating roast meat not thoroughly cooked]. (Ṣ, O.)

1. Dahadahu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _?, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. DahodN; (L;) and ADThdhu↓, (as in the L, and in some copies of the Ḳ,) or ADhdhu↓; (as in other copies of the Ḳ;) He overpowered him; subdued him; oppressed him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) he treated him wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (L;) as also ADhd↓ bihi: (L, Ḳ:) he constrained him. (Ṣ, L.) kaAna laAyujiyzu QloUiDoTihaAda↓, occurring in a trad., means He used not to allow constraint, or compulsion, or force, in a sale, and in an oath, &c. (L.)
4: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.
8: see the preceding paragraph {1}, in two places.
DuhodapN Force; constraint; compulsion. (L.)
huwa DuhodapN likul-i OaHadK means He is one who may be overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, by every one who desires to make him so. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

DahoyadN Hardy, strong, robust: (L, Ḳ:) applied to a man: (L:) [said to be] the only word of the measure faEoyalN (Ḳ) in the language of the Arabs; but Kh asserts it to be a forged word: (TA:) DahoyaON and EavoyarN are also mentioned as of this measure; [but the latter is disallowed in the Ṣ and O, voce EivoyarN;] and madoyanu and maroyamu [which, however, are foreign proper names]. (MF.)
maDohuwdN and muDoTahadN↓ A man (L) overpowered; subdued; oppressed; (Ṣ, L;) abased; (L;) constrained. (Ṣ, L.)
muDoTahadN: see what next precedes.
AlmuDoTahidu The lion. (Ḳ.)
Q. 1. DahoDaba: see 2 in art. Dhb.

DahowapN A birokap of water; [i. e. a wateringtrough, or tank, or the like, of water; or a basin, pool, pond, or lake, of water; or a place where water remains and collects, or collects and stagnates;] (M, Ḳ;) as though formed by transposition from wahoDapN, which signifies a depressed piece of ground: (TA:) pl. OaDohaMCN. (M, Ḳ.)
DahowaMCu A woman whose breasts have not become prominent, or protuberant. (Lth, Ḳ.) [See also DahoyaMCu, in the next art.]
1. Dahiyato, aor. _a {yaDohaIu}, inf. n. DahFI, She was, or became, such as is termed DahoyaMC. (Ḳ.)

3. DAhAhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muDaAhaApN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He resembled, or conformed with, him, or it; syn. XaAkalahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like DaAhaOahu [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and, like the latter, he imitated him. (Mṣb, TA.*) It is said in a trad., OaXad-u Aln-aAsi EacaAbFA yawoma AlqiyaAmapi Al-aciyn yuDaAhuwna xaloqa Qll-ehi i. e. [The most severely punished of mankind on the day of resurrection will be] those who imitate by what they make [the creation of God]; meaning the sculptors or limners or the like. (Mṣb.)
Also, [or DaAhaI bihi, like DaAhaOa bh, q. v.,] He was, or became, gentle, tender, or courteous, or he acted, or behaved, gently,, &c., with him, or to him; namely, a man, and other than a man. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. ADhI He married, i. e. took to wife, a woman such as is termed DahoyaMC. (AA, Ḳ.)
And He pastured his camels upon the species of tree called DahoyaMC. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DahoyFA: see the next paragraph, in four places.

hom.sense: DahoyaMCu A woman that does not menstruate: pl. DuhoIN; which necessarily implies that the former is [as above, i. e.] with the long A: but AA mentions DahoyaApN↓ and DahoyaAhN↓, with p and with h, as having this meaning; which necessarily implies that DhyA is with the short A [i. e., accord. to a general rule, DahoyFA↓, with tenween, like DahoyaON, q. v. in art. DhyO, though (accord. to a general rule) this should be regarded as a masc. epithet]: (Ṣ) or DahoyaMCu, and also with the short A [app. DahoyFA↓, as above, not DahoyaA, or, as I rather incline to think, DahoyaON (which is mentioned in art. DhyO) may be here meant], signify a woman that does not menstruate nor become pregnant; (Ḳ, TA;) so that she is as though she resembled a man: (TA: [see 3:]) or that menstruates but does not become pregnant: (Ḳ, TA:) or that does not bring forth, though she menstruate: (TA:) or whose breasts do not grow forth; (Ḳ, TA;) and when this is the case, she does not menstruate: or the former signifies that does not menstruate, being pregnant. (TA.)

And † Land that does not give growth to anything; as also with the short A [i. e. DahoyFA↓ or DahoyaON]. (Ḳ. [In the TA this meaning is restricted, app. without reason, to the form with the short A.])

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with the short A [i. e. DahoyFA↓ or DahoyaON], (Ḳ,) A species of tree (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the kind called EiDaAh, (Ḳ,) having a baramap [q. v.] and a pod (Eul-afap) [which succeeds the baramap], and many thorns. (TA. [For further descriptions thereof, see DahoyaON, in art. DhyO.])

entry.sense: DahoyaApN and DahoyaAhN: see the next preceding paragraph.

DahiI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure faEiylN, (Ṣ,) The like of another [thing or person]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one says, hecaA DahiI-u hecaA This is the like of this: (Ṣ:) or huwa Dahiy-uka He is the like of thee. (Ḳ.)

Q. 1. [Accord. to the O and Ḳ, Q. Q. 1, being mentioned therein in art. DhO.] DahoyaOa Oamorahu He fell short of doing what he ought to have done in his affair, (mar-aDahu, O, Ḳ,) and did not decide it, (lamo yaSorimohu, O,) or and did not perform it firmly, or soundly: (Ḳ:) like rahoyaOa. (TA.)

hom.sense: Also A woman that does not menstruate: and that has neither milk nor breast: as also DahoyaOapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter is an epithet applied to a woman in these two senses: (O: [in which the former word, without p, is not mentioned:]) Seer says, in his Expos. of “the Book” of Sb, that DahoyaON, like DahoyaMCu [which belongs to art. DhI], is a subst. as well as an epithet, signifying a woman whose breast has not grown forth: and one who has not menstruated:

and also † A land that has not given growth to anything: (MF, TA:) or DahoyaOapN↓ signifies as above: and also † a desert (falaApN) having in it no water: (O, Ḳ, TA:) or that does not give growth to anything; app. because it has no water. (TA.) [Accord. to those who hold the I to be augmentative,] a woman is thus termed because she resembles men (liOan-ahaA DaAhaOati Alr-ijaAla). (O, TA.)

entry.sense: DahoyaOapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
R. Q. 1. DawoDawoA, [inf. n. DawoDaApN and DawoDaMCN, (see the next paragraph,)] They cried out, shouted, or clamoured; first pers. sing. DawoDayotu, the [second] w being changed into I. (Ṣ, TA.)

Daw-apN [in the CK erroneously written DawAp] A crying out, shouting, or clamouring; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) so says Aṣ, and AZ says the like; (Ṣ;) as also DawoDaApN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and DawoDaMCN↓, (TA in art. DwD, [these two there mentioned as inf. ns., on the authority of IḲṭṭ,]) and DawoDFI↓. (Ḳ in art. DwD.) One says, samiEotu Daw-apa Alqawomi [I heard the crying out, shouting, or clamouring, of the people, or party]. (Aṣ, AZ, Ṣ.)
DawoDFI and DawoDaMCu and DawoDaApN; see the next preceding paragraph.
DuwaADK Large, big, or bulky; thick; or large in body; syn. DaxomN, (Ḳ, TA,) and EaZymN. (TA.)
DuwaADiyapN: see what next follows.
DuwayoDiyapN, (Ḳ, TA,) in the dim. form, (TA,) A calamity, or misfortune; (Ḳ, TA,) because of its greatness; (TA;) as also DuwaADiyapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A stallion [camel] excited by lust. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
1: see 4, in two places.

hom.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {4}, in two places.

One says also, Daw-aOotu Eanohu [meaning I brought to light, made visible, discovered, or revealed, him, or it]. (M, TA.) A sheep, or goat, belonging to an Arab of the desert strayed; whereupon he said, Aall-ehum-a Daw-iYo Eanohu [O God, bring it to light, or discover it]. (A, TA.)
Accord. to Lth, but he is the only authority for it known by AM, (TA,) Daw-aOa Eani AlOamori, inf. n. taDowiYapN, means He declined, or turned away, from the affair. (Ḳ, TA.)

4. ADMC, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a thing, (M,) [as, for instance,] of the moon, (Mṣb,) or ADMCt, said of fire (Aln-aAr,), (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, O,) inf. n. UiDaMCN; (Mṣb;) and DaMCa↓, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or DaMCat, (Ṣ, O,) aor. yaDuwoCu, (M,) or taDuwoCu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. DawoCN (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DuwoCN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) but the former verb is preferred; (TA;) It gave light, was light or bright, shone, or shone brightly. (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.) [See also an ex. of ↓the latter verb in a verse cited voce OufuqN; and cited here in the TA.] And OaDaOotu lahu [I gave light to him]. (M.)

The former verb is also trans.: you say, OaDaMCatohu Aln-aAru [The fire made it to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (Ṣ, O:) and OaDaOotuhu and Daw-aOotuhu↓ [I made it to give light, to be light or bright, to shine, or to shine brightly]: (M, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) and OaDaOotu bihi Albayota and Daw-aOotuhu↓ bihi [I lighted, or illumined, with it (i. e. with a lamp or the like) the house, or chamber, or tent]. (M.)

[Hence,] ADMC bibawolihi ‡ He ejected his urine [so as to make its drops to glisten]; or emitted it and then stopped it; syn. Hacafa bihi; (Ḳ, TA;) or xacafa bihi; (so in a copy of the M, as on the authority of Kr;) or, as in the A, OacoraEa bihi. (TA.)
And they said maA OaDowaOahu [How light, or bright, is it!]. (Ṣ voce OaZolama [q. v.].)
And ADMC signifies also OaSaAba DawoCFA [He saw (lit. lighted on, or found,) light, or brightness]. (T voce OaZolama [q. v.])

entry.sense: 5. tDw-O He stood in the dark to see people by the light of their fire, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) without their seeing him. (AZ, TA.) And tDw-A QmoraOapF [He stood in the dark to see a woman by the light of her fire, without her seeing him]. (TA.)

10. AisotaDaOutu bihi [I sought to obtain light by means of it; I made use of it for light]. (M, Ḳ.) laA tasotaDiyWuwA binaAri Oaholi AlX-iroki [lit. Seek not ye to obtain light by means of the fire of the people of belief in a plurality of gods], (O, Ḳ,) a saying of the Prophet, (O,) means ‡ seek not ye counsel, or advice, of the believers in a plurality of gods, in affairs: (O, Ḳ:) because he whose affair is confused and dubious to him is as though he were in darkness. (O.)

DawoCN and DuwoCN↓ and DiyaMCN↓ (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) and DiwaMCN↓, (M, Ḳ,) the last of which is [erroneously] written in the L DawaMCN, (TA,) signify the same, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ,) i. e. Light, syn. nuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) accord. to the leading lexicologists; but see what follows: (TA:) and DawoCN is an inf. n. of DaMCa, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so is DuwoCN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst. from DaMCa, and so is DiyaMCN↓, which is also, sometimes, written DiYaMCN↓, from OaDaMCa as syn. with DaMCa: (Mṣb:) the pl. of DawoCN (M, TA) and DuwoCN↓ (M) is OaDowaMCN; and DiyaMCN↓ is sometimes a pl., (M, TA,) as Zj states it to be: (TA:) some say that DawoCN has a more intensive signification than nuwrN, and that hence God has likened his direction [the Ḳur-án] to Aln-uwr rather than to AlD-awoC; because if it were otherwise, no one had erred: and that hence, also, [in the Ḳur x. 5,] the sun is termed DiyaMC↓; and the moon, nuwrN: it is also said that DawoCN signifies the rays that are diffused by what is termed nuwrN: the ḳádee Zekereeyà affirms that these two words are syn. by their original application, but that DawoCN is more forcible accord. to usage: and some say that AlD-awoCu signifies that [light] which subsists by itself, as [that of] the sun, and fire; and Aln-uwru, to that which subsists by some other thing [as does the light of the moon]. (MF, TA.)
DuwoCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.
DiwaMCN: see DawoCN.
DiyaMCN and DiYaMCN: see DawoCN, in five places.
2. Dw-H: see 2, in two places, in art. DyH.
DaAdN The name of one of the letters of the alphabet. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See the letter D.
1. DaArahu, aor. yaDuwru: see DaArahu, aor. yaDiyru, in art. Dyr.

5. tDw-r He writhed by reason of the pain of beating, (M, A, Ḳ,) or of hunger: (Ḳ:) he cried out and writhed on being beaten, (Lth, Ṣ, A,) or by reason of vehement hunger: (Ṣ, A:)
he writhed and cried out and turned over, by reason of the vehemence of fever: (TA:) he manifested harm, injury, or hurt, that he suffered; and was in a state of agitation: (IAmb, TA:) he manifested weakness: (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, in TA: [but for taDoEiyfN, as the explanation of the inf. n., in the TA, I read taDaE-ufN:]) he (a wolf, and a dog, and a lion, and a fox,) cried out (M, Ḳ) with hunger. (M.)

hom.sense: 1. DaAzahu Haq-ahu, aor. yaDuwzuhu, i. q. DaAzahu, aor. yaDiyzuhu: see art. Dyz. (Ḳ.) You say also DaAzaniI, aor. yaDuwzuniI, meaning naqaSaniI [He made me to suffer loss]. (Kr, M, TA.)
And DaAza, aor. yaDuwzu is also [intrans.] like DaOaza, q. v. (TA in art. DOz.)

entry.sense: qisomapN DuwzaI i. q. DiyzaI: see art. Dyz. (M, TA.*)

dictScrap.label: For words mentioned in the Ḳ under this head, see art. Dw.

hom.sense: 1. DaAEahu, (aor. yaDuwEuhu, Ṣ, O,) inf. n. DawoEN, He, or it, put it, or him, into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) as also Dw-Ehu↓, inf. n. taDowiyEN: (TA:) and disquieted, or disturbed, him, or it: and frightened him: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) and some say, roused, or excited, him: and Dw-Ehu↓, also, has the last but one, or the last, of these meanings. (TA.) One says, laA yaDuwEan-aka maA tasomaEu minohaA i. e. [By no means let that which thou hearest from her move thee, or disquiet thee, or frighten thee; or] do not thou be moved by what thou hearest from her; or do not thou care for it, or regard it. (TA.) And DaAEahu Oamoru kacaA wakacaA Such and such things frightened him. (AA, TA.)
And, said of the wind, It made it to incline; namely, a branch: (Ḳ:) and it (the wind) bore heavily upon it. (TA. [The object of the verb in this sense is not there mentioned.])

And i. q. XaAqahu [He, or it, excited his desire]: (so in the O, on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád:) or i. q. XaAq-ahu [he acted with him contrariously, or adversely, and inimically;, &c.]. (So in copies of the Ḳ.)
And DAE AlUibila, (O,) or Ald-aAb-apa, (Ḳ,) said of journeying It rendered lean, or emaciated, (O, Ḳ,) the camels, (O,) or the beast. (Ḳ.)

And DAE faroxahu, (IAạr, O, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (IAạr, O,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) It (a bird) fed its young one with its bill. (IAạr, O, Ḳ.) When you command the bird to do so, you say DuEo DuEo. (IAạr, O.)
DaAEa is also intrans.: see 5, in two places.

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
4. maA OaDowaEahu, said of odour, means How sweet [or fragrant] is it! (Ḥar p. 670.)

hom.sense: 5. tDw-E said of the wind, It became in motion. (TA.) And tDw-Et raAYiHapu AlT-iybi The odour of the perfume diffused itself, or became diffused. (O.) And tDw-E Almisoku, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also tDy-E; (Ṣ;) or tDw-E AlX-aIoCu; (Mṣb,) and DAE↓, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb; Ḳ,) aor. yaDuwEu, (O, Mṣb) inf. n. DawoEN; (Mṣb;) and DAE, aor. yaDiyEu; (Ḥar p. 670;) The musk, being put in motion, diffused its odour, or fragrance; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) or the thing diffused its odour: (Mṣb:) so in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys cited voce ray-aA, in art. rwI: [in which, in the place of taDaw-aEa, some read yaD-aw-aEu, for yataDaw-aEu:] (TA:) and in like manner one says of a stinking thing. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And tDw-E misokFA [It diffused the odour, or fragrance, of musk]. (Ṣ, O.)
And tDw-E minohu raAYiHapF He snuffed, or scented, or smelt, from him, or it, an odour. (TA.)
Also, said of the [bird called] DuwaE, It cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying. (AḤát, O.)

And, (O,) said of a child, (Ḳ,) He writhed, (Ḳ,) or cried out and writhed, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) in weeping; (Ḳ,* TA; in the former, mina AlbukaMCi; but correctly, fiI AlbkMCi; TA;) as also DAE↓, (Lth, O, Ḳ,) aor. yaDuwEu, (Lth, O,) inf. n. DawoEN: (TA:) both signify he cried, or uttered a loud cry or crying, in weeping; as one does when beaten: or the former, mostly said of a child, signifies he writhed in weeping with vehemence, and raising the voice; as expl. by Lth: (TA:) or it signifies also he (a child) wept vehemently: (O:) and, said of a young bird, it writhed, or cried out and writhed; (O, Ḳ;) as when said of a child; and so AnDAE↓, said of both: (Ḳ:) or AnDAE↓, said of a young bird, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) as also tDw-E, (O, Ḳ,) signifies it spread its wings to its mother in order that she might feed it with her bill. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 7. AnDAE: see the next preceding sentence {5}, in two places.
Also He was frightened at a thing, and cried out at it, or uttered a loud cry or crying by reason of it. (TA.)

DuwaEN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DiwaEN (AHeyth, O, Ḳ) A certain night-bird, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [a species of owl, i. e.,] of the kind termed haAm: (Ṣ, O, Mṣb:) or [a male owl;] the male of the buwm; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) accord. to El-Mufaddal: (Ṣ, O:) said by ADk to be a bird that utters a scream when it perceives the daybreak: (O:) or the karawaAn [a name now given to the stonecurlew, or charadrius œdicnemus]: (Ḳ:) or a certain black bird, resembling the guraAb [or crow], (Et-Táïfee, O, Ḳ,) smaller than this, but red in its wings, these being of a roseate colour: so says AḤát, on the authority of Et-Táïfee: accord. to others, he says, it is a small bird, less than the dux-al and the Hum-ar; (O;) and in like manner says Th: (TA:) also that the DuwaEap↓ [which may be the fem. or a n. un.] is of a colour inclining to yellow, dusky and blackish externally, and yellow and ash-coloured within, short in the neck and tail, smaller than the sparrow; and that it is thus called because of the cry that it utters at the commencement of daybreak: accord. to El-Hanashee, the DuwaE is a bird such as is termed Oabogav [q. v.], resembling the domestic hen, (O,) the flesh of which is good: (O, Ḳ:) but he adds that it has been said by some to be not a bird: and in another place of the book he says that the DuwaEap↓ is black, like the guraAb, a little larger than the Dujorap, red in the xawaAfiq: (O: [but AlxawaAfiq is an obvious mistranscription for AlxawaAfiI: see xaAfiyapN:)] the pl. is OaDowaAEN [a pl. of pauc.] and DiyEaAnN. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
DuwaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
DuwaAEN The cry of the bird called DuwaE. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

DawaAYiEu, applied to camels, (O, Ḳ,) and to other beasts, (O,) Lean, and lank in the belly: (O, Ḳ:) or emaciated: (TA:) app. from DaAEa said of journeying, meaning “it rendered lean, or emaciated: (O:) by rule it should be DaAYiEapN. (TA.)
AlD-aw-aAEu, like Xad-aAd, [in the O erroneously written AlDuwaAEu,] The fox. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
maDuwEN pass. part. n. of DaAEahu. (O, TA.)
1. DaAfa Eanohu, inf. n. DawofN: see 1 in art Dyf.
maDuwfN: see art. Dyf.
maDuwfapN: see art. Dyf.
1. DaAma, aor. yaDuwmu, inf. n. DawomN, a dial. var. of DaAma, aor. yaDiymu, inf. n. DayomN: (Ḳ:) Dumotuhu, like Dimotuhu, signifying Zalamotuhu [I wronged him,, &c.]. (M, TA.)
5: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
DawonN The UinofaHap [i. e. runnet, or runnet-bag, of a hid, or lamb]. (Ḳ.)

DaAnapN A nose-ring of brass (burapN M, Ḳ, mino SuforK M) for a camel: (Ḳ:) or a [camel's nose-ring such as is termed] xizaAmap; accord. to Sh: mentioned in the Ḳ in art. DOn; but this is its proper place, for it is without. (TA.)
DawonapN A young female child. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, AlZ-aboyapu is put for AlS-abiy-apu.])

DayowanN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of the measure fayoEalN, not faEowalN, because the former is the more common, (IB, TA,)
extr. [in respect of rule], preserving its original form, (M,) without UidogaAm [i. e. not having its w incorporated into the I so as to become Day-anN, as it should by rule,] because it is a primitive noun, (Ṣ,) like Hayowapu, which is a proper name of a man, (Ṣ, M,) but more extr. because that is allowable in a proper name which is not allowable in another kind of word, (M,) [A he-cat;] i. q. sin-aworN [q. v.]; (M:) the male sin-awor: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a certain small beast resembling the sin-awor: (M:) pl. DayaAwinu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the w is unaltered because it is so in the sing.: (Ṣ, TA:) Sb says, the dim. is Duyay-inN↓, like Ousay-idN [dim. of Oasowadu], but he who says OusayowidN may say DuyayowinN↓. (Ṣ.)
Duyay-inN and DuyayowinN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. DawiIa, aor. yaDowaI, inf. n. DawFI, He (a child, Mṣb) was, or became, lean, or emaciated, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and small in body: (Mṣb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally. (M, Ḳ.) [See also 4.]

DawaI Uilayohi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yaDowiI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. DuwiI-N (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and DaI-N, (M, Ḳ,) He adjoined himself, got him or got himself, betook him or betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to him; syn. AinoDam-a; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also AnDwI↓; (Ḥar p. 73;) and he had recourse, or betook himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.)

And DawaI UilaI-a minohu xayorN, inf. n. DaI-N and DuwiI-N, i. q. saAla [i. e. Bounty flowed to me from him]: (M, TA:) accord. to the copies of the Ḳ, DwI AlI xabarihi sOl; which is wrong. (TA. [In my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, AlI xayorh saOla.])
And DawaI signifies also It came by night: (M, Ḳ:) you say, DawaI UilayonaA xabaruhu The news, or tidings, of him, or it, came to us by night. (M, TA.)
DuwiIa, said of a camel, He was, or became, affected with the tumours termed DawFI, (Lth, TA,) or with what is termed DawaApN [q. v.]. (M.)
4. ADwI He (a man, TA) was, or became, slender (Ḳ, TA) in his body. (TA. [See also DawiIa.]) And ADwI Alqawomu The people's cattle became lean, or emaciated; like ASwI Alqwm. (IḲṭṭ, TA in art. SwI.)

And He (a man) had offspring such as is termed DaAwiI- born to him: and in like manner ADwt is said of a woman [as meaning she brought forth such offspring]; (M;) or she brought forth a boy such as is so termed. (Ḳ.) AigotaribuwA walaA tuDowuwA, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) occurring in a trad., (Ṣ,) means Marry ye among women that are remote in respect of relationship, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,*) and not among the relations of your paternal uncles, (Ṣ,) or and not among your near relations, lest your offspring be such as is termed DaAwiI-: (M, Mṣb:) for the Arabs assert that a man's offspring from his near relation is meagre, though generous, of the nature of his people. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

ADwAhu He rendered it weak. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ *) You say, ADwI AlOamora ‡ He rendered the affair weak; (Ṣ, TA;) did not render it firm, or sound; or did not perform it in a firm, or sound, manner. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And ADwAhu Haq-ahu † He curtailed him, or defrauded him, of his right, or due. (IAạr, M, Ḳ.*)
ADwAhu All-ayolu Uilayohi The night made him to have recourse, or to betake himself, to him for protection, or refuge. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, second sentence.

hom.sense: DawFI inf. n. of DawiIa [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, &c.)
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: DawaApN [mentioned in the TA as from the Ḳ, but not in the CK, and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ inserted in the margin,] A ganglion (gudadapN, M, or gud-apN, Ḳ, TA) beneath the lobe of the ear, above the nakafap [q. v.]: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or, accord. to Az, [a thing] resembling a gud-ap. (TA.) And A tumour occurring in the fauces of camels and other animals: pl. DawFI↓: (M:) or this latter [is properly termed a coll. gen. n., of which DawaApN is the n. un., and] signifies tumours accidental to the camel, in his head, having an overpowering effect upon his eyes, and rendering it difficult to attach to him the [halter called] xiTaAm; and sometimes it is in the side of the mouth. (Lth, TA.) And (M, TA) A siloEap [or ganglion] (Ṣ, M, TA) in a camel, (Ṣ,) or in any part of the body. (M, TA.)
Also A certain thing, or small thing, (hanapN,) that comes forth from the she-camel's vulva before the coming forth of the fœtus. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: DaAwK: see the next paragraph.
Also Coming by night; syn. TaAriqN [which Golius here explains as meaning “Lucifer,” and supposes to be for DaAwiYN]. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DaAwiI-N, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure faAEuwlN, [originally DaAwuwIN,] (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and DaAwK↓, (Mṣb, TA,) applied to a boy, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and with p {DaAwiy-apN} applied to a girl, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Lean, or emaciated, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and small in body: (Mṣb:) or slender in the bones, and spare of body, naturally: (M, Ḳ:) and likewise applied to any species of animal: (M:) accord. to the T, the offspring of an incestuous union. (TA.) AlD-aAwiI-u, (T, TA,) not without teshdeed, as the text of the Ḳ implies it to be, (TA,) was the name of A certain horse, (T, Ḳ, TA,) belonging to Ghanee. (T, TA.)
Also the former, disordered, or diseased, and near to dying: [so I render HaAriDN, q. v.:] and weak; in a bad, or corrupt, state. (TA.)
fiyhi DaAwiy-apN In him is leanness or emaciation [&c.]: (Ṣ:) i. q. DawFI [the inf. n. of DawiIa, used as a subst.]. (TA.)
maDowiI-N, applied to a camel, part. n. of DuwiIa [q. v.]. (Lth, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. DaAHa All-abana: see 2, in two places.
DaAHati AlbilaAdu The tracts of land became vacant, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of drought. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. Dy-H All-abana, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoyiyHN, (Ṣ,) He mixed the milk with water, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) so that it became DayoH; (Ṣ;) as also Daw-aHahu, as heard by Az from an Arab of the desert; (TA;) and DaAHahu↓, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. DayoHN, but this last is said by IDrd to be obsolete: (O:) or DaAHahu↓, inf. n. DayoHN, he poured water into it, it being thick, and then stirred it about until it became of a uniform consistence. (T, TA.)
And Dy-Hhu He gave him to drink thin milk, mixed with water, such as is termed DayoH; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Dw-Hhu. (Ḳ.)
4. ADAH, said of the muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm] It became what is termed DayoH, and fit to be eaten. (O.)
5. tD-yH It (milk) became what is termed DayaAH; (Ḳ;) i. e. it was diluted with water, and stirred about until it became of a uniform consistence: and so any medicine, or poison. (TA.)
And He (a man) drank what is termed DayaAH. (Ḳ.)

DayoHN and DayaAHN↓ Thin milk, mixed (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA) with much water: the former expl. by Aṣ as meaning milk in which is much water: the latter expl. in the T as thick milk into which water is poured, and which is then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: also, both words, milk, whether it be fresh or such as is termed raAYib [q. v.], upon which water is poured until it has become thin: and DayaAHN↓ and muDay-aHN↓ any medicine or poison having water poured into it, and then stirred about until it becomes of a uniform consistence: or, accord. to Lth, only milk is termed DayaAH. (TA.) [See an ex. voce xaDaArN.]
DayoHN also signifies Honey. (O, Ḳ.)
And Ripe muqol [or fruit of the Theban palm]: (O, Ḳ: [see 4:]) this is of the dial. of El-Yemen, universally. (O.)
DiyHN i. q. DiH-N [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) ascribed by IDrd to the vulgar. (TA.)
Also an imitative sequent to ryH, (Ḳ,) [i. e.] a corroborative of ryH, (O,) in the phrase jaMCa biAlr-iyHi waAlD-iyHi [expl. voce DiH-N], and therefore having no meaning if used alone. (O,* TA.)
DaAHapN The sight: (O, Ḳ:) one says, maA Oajowada DaAHatahu [How good, or excellent, is his sight!]: (O:) or the eye. (Ḳ.)
DayoHapN A single drink, or draught, of thin milk, such as is termed DayoH. (TA.)
DayaAHN: see DayoHN, in two places.
muDay-aHN: see DayoHN.
EayoXN maDoyuwHN ‡ A turbid life; syn. mamocuwqN. (Fr, O, Ḳ, TA.)

mutaDay-iHN ‡ Coming to the watering-trough when most of the contents thereof has been drunk and there remains but little, mixed, (IAth,* O, Ḳ, TA,) and turbid; (IAth, TA;) this being likened to milk mixed with water: (TA:) or coming to water the last of the people. (AHeyth, TA.)

1. DaArahu, aor. yaDiyru, inf. n. DayorN; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also DaArahu, aor. yaDuwru, inf. n. DaworN; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) It (a thing, M, Ḳ) harmed, injured, hurt, mischiefed, or damaged, him; i. q. Dar-ahu, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or OaDar-a bihi. (Mṣb.) You say, hecaA mim-aA laA yaDiyruka [This is of the things that will not harm thee]: and lawo faEalotahu lamo yaDiroka [Hadst thou done it, it had not harmed thee]: and laA Dayora Ealayoka [No harm shall befall thee]. (A.) And maA yaDiyruka EalaI AlD-ab-i SiyodN i. q. maA yaDur-uka q. v. (A in art. Dr.) And Ks says that he had heard (from one of the people of El-' Áliyeh. TA) the phrase laA yanofaEuniI celika walaA yaDuwruniI [That will not benefit me, nor will it harm me]. (Ṣ, TA.) See also a reading of a phrase in a trad. cited in art. Dr. conj. 3.

1. DaAza, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaDiyzu, inf. n. DayozN, (TA,) He deviated from the right course; or acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) fiI AlHukomi in the judgment: (Ṣ:) like DaOaza. (TA in art. DOz.)

DaAzahu Haq-ahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He deprived him, or defrauded him, of a part, or the whole, of his right, or due: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) like DaAzahu, aor. yaDuwzuhu: (Ḳ:) he refused it to him, or withheld it from him: (AZ, M, TA:) and sometimes one says DaOazahu, aor. yaDoOazuhu, inf. n. DaOozN. (Ṣ, TA.)

qisomapN DiyzaI An unjust, (Ṣ, M,) or a defective, (Ḳ in art. DOz,) division: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) as also DuwzaI: (M:) DyzI in the Ḳur liii. 22 is read by all without hemz: (TA:) it is of the measure fuEolaI, like TuwbaI and HubolaI; but the D is with kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged; for there is not in the language an epithet of the measure fiEolaI; this being a measure of substantives, like AlX-iEoraI and Ald-ifolaI: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, it is not an epithet, but an inf. n., like cikoraI, as though the meaning were qisomapN caAtu jaworK: (Ḥar p. 524:) Fr says that some of the Arabs say DaOozaI, and DuWozaI: and AḤát mentions AZ's having heard the Arabs say DiYozaI, with hemz. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. DaAEa, aor. yaDiyEu, inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DayoEN and DiyEN, (Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb) perished, came to nought, passed away, or became lost. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of Saạd, Uin-iI OaxaAfu EalaI AlOaEonaAbi AlD-ayoEupa i. e. [Verily I fear, for the grapes,] their [lit. the] perishing, or becoming lost. (TA.)

And DAE, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. DayaAEN and DayoEapN, (TA,) It (a thing) was left; left, or let, alone; or neglected. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence, DAEt AlUibilu, and DAE AlEiyaAlu, The camels, and the family, or household, were left untended, and unminded; and were left alone, or neglected. (TA.)
DAE, aor. yaDiyEu, said of perfume, or sweet odour, i. q. DAE having for its aor. yaDuwEu. (Ḥar p. 670.) [See 5 in art. DwE: and see also 5 in the present art.]

entry.sense:
2. Dy-E AlX-aIoCa, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoyiyEN; (Ṣ;) and ADAEhu↓, (O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDaAEapN; (Ṣ;) both signify the same; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He made, or caused, the thing to perish, or become lost; he destroyed it, wasted it, or lost it. (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.) Hence, Day-aEuwA fulaAnFA is used by the vulgar as meaning They beheaded such a one with the sword. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlS-ayofa Day-aEoti All-abana [In the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk], in which the t is with kesr when the words are addressed to a male, or to a female, or to a pl. number, because originally addressed to a woman, the wife of a wealthy man, whom she disliked because of his being aged, wherefore he divorced her, and a poor man married her, and she sent to her first husband requesting a gift, and he answered her thus; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;*) AlSyf being in the accus. case as an adv. n.: so says Yaạḳoob: (Ṣ, O:) or El-Aswad Ibn-Hurmuz divorced his wife El-'Anood Esh-Shenneeyeh, (O, Ḳ,) of the BenooShenn, (TA,) preferring to her a beautiful and wealthy woman of his people; (O, Ḳ;*) then there occurred between them what led to their separation, and he sought to obtain [again] El-'Anood, and sent a message to her; but in replying to him she said,
OanoXaOota taTolubu waSolanaA
fiI AlS-ayofi Day-aEota All-abano
[Thou hast begun to seek our union: in the spring, or in the summer, thou losedst the milk]: (O,* Ḳ:) the t in this case being with fet-ḥ. (Ḳ. [See more in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 197-8, or in Ḥar p. 577; in both of which, however, and in the O, Dy-Et is with kesr in the latter case, as in the former.]) [One says also, Dy-E Eahodahu, meaning He broke his compact, contract, or covenant]. The phrase, in a trad., nahaI Eano UiDaAEapi↓ AlmaAli means He forbade the expending of wealth otherwise than in obedience to God, and the squandering thereof, and extravagance. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph {4}.

hom.sense: 4. ADAE AlX-aIoCa: see 2, first sentence, and last but one.

Also, [and app. Dy-Ehu↓ likewise, accord. to the Ḳ,] He left the thing; left it, or let it, alone; or neglected it. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, ADAE EiyaAlahu He neglected his family, or household; omitted taking good care of them, or being mindful of them. (TA.) wamaA kaAna Qll-ehu liyuDiEa UiymaAnakumo, in the Ḳur [ii. 138], means And God will not neglect [or make to be lost] your prayer. (TA.) OaDaAEuwA AlS-alaApa, in the same, [xix. 60,] means Who neglected, or omitted, prayer, (Bḍ, TA,) altogether: (TA:) or deferred it: (Bḍ:) or who performed it in other than its right time: but the first explanation is more suitable, for the unbelievers are meant thereby. (TA.)
ADAE [is also intrans., and] may signify He found his affair to be coming to nought. (Ḥam p. 33.)
And His estates (DiyaAEuhu) became wide-spread, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) and many, or numerous. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tDy-E, said of the wind, It blew: because it [often] destroys that upon which it blows: so says Er-Rághib. (TA. [But it may be from what here follows.])
Said of musk, It diffused its odour, or fragrance: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) a dial. var. of tDw-E: (Ṣ:) or an instance of substitution [of I for w]. (O.) [See also 1, last explanation.]
maAta DiyoEFA and DiyaEFA: see DayaAEN.

hom.sense: DayoEapN an inf. n. of 1. (Ṣ, &c.)
See DayaAEN, below, last sentence but one.
Also A single case, or occasion, of perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost; or of being left, left or let alone, or neglected. (TA.)
tarakotuhu biDayoEapK means I left him unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayaAEN.])

Also i. q. EaqaArN [meaning An estate consisting of land, or of land and a house, or of a house or land yielding a revenue, or of a house and palm-trees, or the like]; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and [particularly] land yielding a revenue; (Ḳ;) or with the people of the towns and villages and cultivated lands it signifies the property, of a man, consisting of palm-trees and grape-vines and land: but the Arabs [of the desert] know not the word in this sense: (Az, TA:) IF says, I do not reckon the application of this word as a name for the EaqaAr to be of the original language, but think it to be an innovation in speech; and I have heard it said that this is termed a DyEp because, when frequent attention to it is neglected, it perishes; and if it be so, this is an evidence of what we have said, that it is of the innovated speech: (O, TA:) the dim. is DuyayoEapN↓, for which one should not say DuwayoEapN: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the pl. is DiyaAEN and DiyaEN, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as though the latter were a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) and DayoEaAtN: (Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, the first of these pls. signifies places of alighting or abode or settlement; which are thus called because, when the paying frequent attention to them, or taking good care of them, and the keeping them, or putting them, in a good state, or state of repair, is neglected, they come to nought: and DayoEaAtN occurs in a trad. as meaning the means of subsistence. (TA.) And, (T, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as used by the Arabs [of the desert], who know not the word in any other sense than this, (T, O,) A craft, or handicraft, by which one gains his subsistence; a mode, or manner, of gain; or any habitual work or occupation of a man; (T, O, Mṣb, Ḳ)
as the sewing of skins or boots and the like; and the twisting of ropes; and the weaving, or plaiting, of palm-leaves; and the culture of palm-trees (Eamalu Aln-axoli); and the pasturing of camels; and the like thereof; (T, O;) including the sowing, or tilling, of land: (TA:) or the DayoEap of the Arabs was the management, or tending, of camels and of sheep and goats: and the term includes a man's craft, or handicraft, or means of gain: (Sh, O:) and his traffic: (Sh, O, Ḳ:) one says to a man, qumo UilaI DayoEatika [Arise to thy craft,, &c.]: (Sh, O:) and kul-u rajulK waDayoEatahu, [Every man should occupy himself with his proper craft,, &c.] (Mṣb.) OafoXaI Qll-ehu DayoEatahu, occurring in a trad., means God made or may God make, his means of subsistence to be abundant. (TA.) And one says, faXato DayoEatuhu, [or, more commonly, faXato Ealayohi DayoEatuhu, as in the TA in art. fXw, &c.,] which is said to mean His property was, or became, large, or abundant, [or wide-spread,] so that he was unable to collect it together: and [hence] his means of attaining his object [or his affairs (as in the TA in art. fXw)] became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin: (TA:) or he took to doing an affair that did not concern him: (TA, and Ḥam p. 33:) it is nearly like the saying Ait-asaEa Alxaroqu EalaI Alr-aAqiEi [expl. in art. xrq]. (Ḥam ibid.) And Uin-iI laOaraI DayoEapF laA yuSoliHuhaA Uil-aA DajoEapN [Verily I see property that nothing but a sleep will restore to a right state] a prov.; said by a pastor whose camels had dispersed themselves, and who, desiring to collect them together, and being unable to do so, sought aid of sleep. (O.)

entry.sense: maAta DiyEapF: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: DayaAEN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, &c.) [Hence] one says, maAta DayaAEFA, as also DiyaEFA↓, and DiyoEFA↓, and DiyEapN↓, He (a man, TA) died unsought-after, or unminded, or unmissed. (Ḳ, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce DayoEapN.])

Also A family, or household: (ISh, O, Ḳ:) or the meaning is EiyaAlN Duy-aEN, (Mgh, O, Ḳ,*) i. e. a family, or household, neglected, untended, and unminded; (TA;) or such as are exposed, or liable, to perish, (biEaraDi Oano yaDiyEa,) as young children, and those who are crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, who cannot manage their own affairs: (Mgh:) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that when a man died leaving such as are thus termed, (taraka DayaAEFA,) they were to be brought to the Prophet, (Mgh, O,) to be maintained by means of the government-treasury: (Mgh:) a prefixed noun is to be understood [i. e. it is for EiyaAla DayaAEK or the like]: (Mgh:) or it is an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]: (Mgh, O:) or, accord. to one relation of the trad., the word is DayoEapF↓ [which is likewise an inf. n., and in this case to be expl. in the same manner]: (Mgh:) if read DiyaAEFA, it would be pl. of DaAYiEN. (Mgh, O.)
Also A sort of perfume, or odoriferous substance. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: DuyayoEapN dim. of DayoEapN, q. v. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

DaAYEN Perishing, coming to nought, passing away, or becoming lost: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) [and being left; left, or let, alone; or neglected:] part. n. of 1: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. DiyaAEN (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Duy-aEN. (Mgh, O,* Mṣb, Ḳ.*) [See an ex. of the latter pl. in a verse cited voce daAna, in art. dyn. See also saAYiEN, in art. swE.]
And A man in a state of poverty: or having a family, or household, to sustain: or in a state of circumstances by means of which he is unable to subsist. (TA.)

fulaAnN yaOokulu fiI miEFI DaAYiEK means jaAYiEK [i. e. Such a one eats into a hungry, or an empty, gut]: and it was said to the daughters of El-Khuss, “What is the sharpest thing? (maA OaHad-u XaIoC;) and she answered, naAbN jaAYiEN yuloqiI fiI miEFI DaAYiEK [A hungry canine tooth that throws the food into an empty gut]. (Ṣ.)
OaDoyaEu means Oakovaru DayaAEFA: so in the saying, fulaAnN OaDoyaEu mino fulaAnK [Such a one is in a more perishing state than such a one]. (TA.)

hom.sense: muDiyEN act. part. n. of the trans. v. ADAE. (TA.) [See misoyaAEN, in art. swE.]
And part. n. of the intrans. v. ADAE; as such signifying One whose estates (DiyaAEuhu) are becoming wide-spread, and many, or numerous. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: maDiyEapN and maDoyaEapN i. q. DayaAEN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.]. (Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So in the saying, taraka EiyaAlahu bimaDiyEapK or bimaDoyaEapK [He left his family, or household, in a state of perishing,, &c.]. (Mgh.) So too in the saying, Als-aAriqu laA yuqoTaEu fiI maAlK bimaDiyEapK [The thief shall not suffer amputation of his hand in the case of his stealing property in a neglected state]. (Mgh.) And so in the saying, huwa bidaAri maDiyEapK (Ṣ,* O, Ḳ) and maDoyaEapK (O, Ḳ) [He is in a place (lit. an abode) of perdition,, &c.]: or as meaning in this saying, abandonment, and ignominy. (TA.) And huwa muqiymN bidaAri maDiyEapK or maDoyaEapK means [He is dwelling in the abode of indolence; or] his characteristic in his affairs is indolence. (Mṣb.)

Also, [or perhaps the latter only, as meaning A cause of perishing, &c., this latter being app. of the class of maboxalapN and majobanapN, &c.,] A desert, or waterless desert, that is cut off [from inhabited regions]: or, as expl. by IJ, a place in which a man perishes, or is lost. (Mṣb.)
muDay-iEN: see what follows.
rajulN miDoyaAEN lilomaAli i. q. muDay-iEN↓ lahu [i. e. A man who wastes, or squanders, wealth, or property]. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. DaAfa, (M, Ḳ,) [aor. yaDiyfu,] inf. n. DayofN; (TḲ;) and ADAf↓, (M,) and tDy-f↓, and Dy-f↓; (Ḳ;) He, or it, inclined, (M, Ḳ,) and approached, or drew near; Uilayohi [to him, or it]. (M.)

And DAft AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or DAft AlXms liloguruwbi, (O,) aor. taDiyfu, inf. n. DayofN; (M;) and tDy-ft↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) or tDy-ft llgrwb; (O;) and Dy-ft↓, (Ṣ, M, Mgh,) Dy-ft llgrwb; (O;) The sun inclined, (Ṣ, Mgh, O,) or drew near, (M,) to setting. (Ṣ, M, Mgh, O.)
And DAft said of a woman, aor. as above, She menstruated; (O, Ḳ;) because she who does so inclines, or declines, from a state of pureness to menstruation. (O, TA.)

And DAf Als-ahomu, (M,) or DAf Alshm Eani Alhadafi, (Ṣ, O,) The arrow turned aside from the butt: (Ṣ, M, O:) like SAf. (Ṣ, O.) And DAf Eani AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. DawofN [and DayofN], He, or it, turned away from the thing: like SAf, inf. n. SawofN [and SayofN]. (M in art. Dwf.)

Difotuhu, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. OaDiyfuhu, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. DiyaAfapN, (Ṣ,) or DayofN, (Mṣb,) or both; (M, O, Ḳ;) and taDay-afotuhu↓; (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ;) I alighted at his abode; (M, Mṣb;) and inclined to him: (M:) or I alighted at his abode (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) as a Dayof [or guest], (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or and became his Dayof [or guest]. (M, O, Mṣb. [See also 3.]) And DAf Alqawoma, and taDay-afahumo↓, He alighted at the abode of the people, or party, as a Dayof [or guest]. (Mgh.) And taDay-afotuhu↓ I came to him as a Dayof [or guest]. (L, TA.)
[Hence,] DAfhu Alham-u † Anxiety befell him. (Ṣ, M,* O. [See, again, 3.])
2. Dy-f, intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences.
As trans.: see 4, last sentence, in four places.

[Hence,] Day-afotuhu signifies also † I protected him, or defended him, from him who sought, or pursued, him: (Mṣb:) ‡ I rendered him safe, secure, or free from fear; and became at peace with him; thus used metaphorically. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. DAyfhu [app. signifies He straitened him: (see 6:) or, perhaps, he became his guest; like DaAfahu, &c.].
[Hence one says,] DAyfhu Alham-u ‡ [Anxiety straitened him: or, perhaps, befell him; like DaAfahu]. (TA.)
[And DAyfhu, inf. n. muDaAyafapN, signifies also It was, or became, correlative to it; as, for instance, fathership to sonship. See also the next paragraph {4}.]

hom.sense: 4. ADAf, intrans.: see 1, in three places.
Also, said of a man, He ran, and hastened, made haste, or sped, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ,) and fled, or turned away and fled: (Ḳ:) and said of a dog as meaning he ran away, or fled. (TA in art. jbn.)
And ADAf EalaI AlX-aIoCi i. q. OaXorafa Ealayohi [He looked upon, or viewed, the thing from above: or he was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of the thing:, &c.]. (O, Ḳ,* TA.)
tuDiyfu UilaI Sawoti AlfaHoli, said of a she-camel, means She hears with desire of going to him the voice, or sound, of the stallion. (M.)

And AlUiDaAfapu and Alt-aDaAyufu↓ signify Correlation, or reciprocal relation, so that one of the two cannot be conceived in the mind without the other; as in the case of AlOubuw-apu and Albunuw-apu [i. e. fathership and sonship]. (KT. [See also 3.])

ADAfhu Uilayohi He made it to incline towards it; (Ṣ, M,* O, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) namely, a thing (Ṣ, O) to a thing. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb.) He made it to lean, rest, or stay itself, against it, or upon it. (M, TA.) You say, ADAf Zahorahu UilaI AlHaAYiTi He leaned his back against the wall. (MA.) And ADAf Uilayohi OamorFA ‡ He rested, or stayed, upon him an affair, and desired him to do what would suffice. (TA.)
And He made him to have recourse to it, or to betake himself to it for refuge. (Ṣ, O, Ḳ.)
And He adjoined it to it. (Mṣb.)

And hence AlUiDaAfapu as a conventional term of the grammarians; because the first [of two nouns in the case to which it applies] is adjoined to the second: (Mṣb:) [for] UiDaAfapu AlAisomi UilaI AlAisomi is [The prefixing the noun to the noun so that the former governs the latter in the gen. case] as when you say gulaAmu zayodK; in which instance, glAm is termed muDaAfN↓, and zyd is termed muDaAfN↓ Uilayohi: and this is done for the purpose of particularizing or appropriating, and of making known or definite: therefore the UiDaAfap of a thing to itself [i. e. the prefixing a noun in this manner to one identical therewith in meaning] is not allowable, because a thing does not make known, or definite, itself; (Ṣ;) unless by an ellipsis, as when you say Haq-u Alyaqiyni for Haq-u AlX-aIoCi Alyaqiyni; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves. (Ṣ voce jaAmiEN.) [AlUiDaAfapu is also often used as meaning The state of being prefixed in the manner explained above; or the connection of a noun so prefixed with its complement. The various kinds of UiDaAfap are sufficiently explained in the grammars of De Sacy and others: they are not proper subjects of a lexicon, though much is said respecting them in the O, and more in the Mṣb.]

[Hence also, biAlUiDaAfapi UilaI kacaA meaning In comparison with (lit. to), or in relation to, (like biAln-isobapi UilaI,) such a thing; as though in juxtaposition to it: a phrase of frequent occurrence: see an ex. in Bḍ ii. 6.]

OaDafotuhu (inf. n. UiDaAfapN, Mṣb) and Day-afotuhu↓ (inf. n. taDoyiyfN, O) both signify the same, (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from AlD-iyaAfapu; (O;) i. e. both signify I made him a guest, or lodged him, or gave him refuge or asylum, syn. Oanozalotuhu, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) with me, as a Dayof [or guest], (Ṣ,) and entertained him: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) OaDaAfuwhu and Day-afuwhu↓ both signify Oanozaluwhu: (Mgh:) accord. to Th, OaDafotuhu signifies I lodged him at my abode as a Dayof: and I gave him (i. e. one in fear) protection, or refuge or asylum: (Mṣb:) and Day-afotuhu↓ is also expl. as meaning I fed him: and Dy-fhu↓ as meaning he made him to be in the condition of OaDoyaAf [or guests]. (TA.)
5. intrans.: see 1, first and second sentences.
taDay-ufN signifies also The being collected together. (KL, from the Mj.)
And The being a taAbiE [or follower,, &c.]. (Id.)
As trans.: see 1, latter half, in four places.
6: see 4.

tDAyf as said of a valley, [from DiyfN “a side,”] It became narrow; syn. taDaAyaqa. (Ṣ, M, O.) taDaAyafona Ealayohi, a phrase used by a poet [describing camels following an old camel], They became near to him, (Ṣ, M, O,) by his side. (Ṣ, M.) And you say, tDAyfhu Alqawomu The people, or party, became on both sides of him (biDiyfayohi). (TA.) And taDaAyfuh Als-abuEaAni The two beasts of prey hemmed him in on both sides. (TA.) And taDaAyafati AlkilaAbu AlS-ayoda and taDaAyafato Ealayohi [The dogs hemmed in the object of the chase on both sides, or round about]. (TA.) [In the TA, all these are said to be tropical; but why, I see not.]

entry.sense: [7. AnDAf Uilayohi signifies He, or it, became joined, or adjoined, or added, to him, or it: and he joined himself to him: but is perhaps post-classical.]
10: see 1, last sentence.

You say also AisotaDaAfaniI, meaning He desired me, or asked me, to grant him protection, or refuge. (Mṣb.) And AstDAf fulaAnN UilaI fulaAnK Such a one had recourse, or betook himself, to such a one for protection, or refuge. (IAạr, M.)

DayofN A guest: and guests: (MA:) so called because adjoined to the family and fed with them: (Ḥam p. 124:) it is applied to one, and to a pl. number, (Ṣ, M, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and to a male and to a female, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because it is originally an inf. n.: (MA, Mṣb:) [as a sing.,] i. q. muDay-afN↓, (M,) which is syn. with naziylN: (TA:) and applied to a pl. number, it may be pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of DaAYifN↓, which is syn. with naAzilN; thus being of the class of zawozN and SawomN: (M:) and it is also pluralized, having for its pls. OaDoyaAfN and DiyfaAnN (Ṣ, M, MA, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DuyuwfN (Ṣ, M, MA, O, Ḳ) and DiyaAfN, (MA, TA,) the first of which is properly a pl. of pauc., but is also used as a pl. of mult.: (M:) and a female is termed DayofapN as well as DayofN: (Ṣ, M, O, Mṣb, Ḳ:) El-Ba'eeth says,
laqFI Hamalatohu Oum-uhu wahoIa DayofapN
[A castaway with whom his mother became pregnant while she was a guest]: (Ṣ, M, O:) or, accord. to AHeyth, the meaning here is that which follows. (O.)
DayofapN applied to a woman signifies also Menstruating: (O, Ḳ:) so says AHeyth with reference to the citation above from El-Ba'eeth. (O.)

DiyfN The side (T, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ) of a valley (T, M) and of a mountain (M) [&c.: see 6]: and, as metaphorically used by an anonymous poet, of the cakar: (M:) and maDaAyifu↓ signifies the sides of a valley. (TA.)
And one says, fulaAnN fiI Diyfi fulaAnK, meaning Such a one is in the vicinage, or quarter, of such a one. (M.)

DayofanN One who comes with a guest: (Ṣ, O:) or who so comes intruding without invitation: (Ḳ:) or one who follows a guest: derived from DayofN, accord. to Sb; but said by AZ to belong to art. Dfn: (M:) [accord. to J and Ṣgh] the n is augmentative: the pl. is DayaAfinu. (Ṣ, O.)
DiyaAfapN an inf. n. of Difotuhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter above. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)

[And] a subst. from OaDafotuhu and Day-afotuhu [as such signifying The entertainment of a guest or guests; i. e. the act of entertaining: and an entertainment as meaning a repast, given to a guest or guests; a banquet, or feast]. (Mṣb.) [Hence, daAru AlD-iyaAfapi The house of entertainment of guests.]
DaAYifN A man alighting as a guest; syn. naAzilN: (M, TA:) see DayofN: its [proper] pl. is Duy-afN. (TA.)

The former signifies also ‡ One who is made an adjunct, or adherent, to a people, or party, (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ, TA,) and made to incline to them, (M,) not being of them. (M, TA.) One says, maA huwa Uil-aA muDaAfN ‡ [He is none other than an adjunct, or adherent]. (TA.)

And ‡ One whose origin, or lineage, or parentage, is suspected; or who makes a claim to relationship not having it: (O, Ḳ, TA:) and (Ḳ) whose origin, or relationship, is referred to a people, or party, of whom he is not a member. (O, Ḳ, TA.)

And One who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, (M, O, Ḳ, TA,) to a narrow, or confined, place, and who is burdened with evil: (TA:) El-Bureyk El-Hudhalee says,
wayaHomiI AlmuDaAfa UicaA maA daEaA
[And he protects him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge, when he calls for aid]. (M.) And musotaDaAfN↓ signifies the same as muDaAfN [app. in the last of the senses expl. above]: so says IB; and he cites the saying of Jowwás Ibn-Ḥeiyán El-Azdee,
walaqado Oaqodamu fiI Alr-awN
Ei waOaHomiI AlmusotaDaAfaA
[app. meaning And verily I advance boldly in the case of fear, and I protect him who is constrained to betake himself to a place of refuge]. (TA.) [See also maDuwfN.]

Also One who is beset, hemmed in, or encompassed, in war, or battle: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ: said in the TA to be tropical:) or one falling among the horsemen and men of valour, having in him no strength. (M.) [See, again, maDuwfN.]
And One in a state of fear. (TA.)

maDuwfN Beset by distress of mind: (TA:) [accord. to Freytag, as from the Deewán of the Hudhalees, constrained to seek refuge: (see also muDaAfN:)]
it occurs in the saying of the Hudhalee,
Oanota tujiybu daEowapa AlmaDuwfi
[Thou answerest the prayer, or call, of him who is beset, &c.]; and is formed after the manner of buwEa for biyEa. (M, TA.)

maDiyfN a dial. var. of maSiyfN [q. v.]. (TA.) [ISd says that] maDiyfFA occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb [as some relate it], cited voce karabapN, [where the reading of maSiyfFA is given,] is for DaAYifFA, meaning Turning aside; crooked. (M.)
muDiyfN Fleeing; or turning away and fleeing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O. [See also its verb.])
muDaAfapN Hardship, or difficulty, or distress. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

maDuwfapN, an anomalous word, by rule maDiyfapN, (Kh, Sb, TA in art. Dwf,) Anxiety; and want, or a want; (O and Ḳ in that art.;) and maDiyfapN↓ and muDiyfapN↓ signify the same; (O in that art. and in art. Dyf;) or these two signify anxiety, and grief: (Ḳ in this art.:) or maDuwfapN signifies an affair, or event, that is feared, or of which one is cautious; (Ṣ and M in this art.;) thus accord. to Aṣ; and maDiyfapN↓ and muDaAfapN↓ signify the same. (Ṣ, L, TA.)
maDiyfapN and muDiyfapN: see both in the next preceding paragraph; the former in two places.
maDoyafapN, of the measure mafoEalapN, A place of DiyaAfap [i. e. entertainment of a guest or guests: pl. maDaAyifu]. (TA.)
muDay-afN: see DayfN.
muDay-ifN The master of an abode in which guests are entertained; as also maDaAyifiI-N↓. (TA.)
miDoyaAfN [One who often entertains guests]. (Ḥar p. 579.)
maDaAyifu [pl. of maDoyafapN:]
[and also of a sing. not mentioned]: see DiyfN.
maDaAyifiI-N [from maDaAyifu pl. of maDoyafapN]: see muDay-ifN.

UisomaMCN mutaDaAyifapN Correlative nouns; i. e. nouns significant of the existence of persons, or things, whereof the existence of one necessarily indicates the existence of another; as OabN and AibonN [father and son]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
musotaDaAfN: see muDaAfN.
musotaDiyfN [act. part. n. of 10, q. v.:] Asking, or calling, for aid, or succour. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

1. DaAqa, aor. yaDiyqu, inf. n. DayoqN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and DiyqN, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) It was, or became, narrow, or strait; contr. of Ait-asaEa; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tDy-q↓, [or rather this signifies it was, or became, rendered narrow, or strait, being quasi-pass. of 2,] and tDAyq↓: (Ḳ:) it is said of a thing, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb,) and of a place. (Mṣb.) [See also DayoqN below.] DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu, in the Ḳur ix. 119, means The earth became strait to them. (Bḍ, Jel.) And one says, DaAqato bihi AlOaroDu [meaning, in like manner, The earth, or land, became narrow, or strait, with him]: ʼAmr Ibn-El-Ahtam says,
laEamoruka maA DaAqato bilaAdN biOaholihaA
walekin-a OaxolaAqa Alr-ijaAli taDiyqu
[By thy life, or by thy religion, countries have not become narrow with their inhabitants, but the dispositions of the men become narrow]. (O, TA.) [DAq bihi often signifies, and so does tDAyq↓ bh, It was, or became, choked, surcharged, or overfilled, with it; for instance, a water-course with water, and a place with people.] And tDAyq↓ bihi AlOamoru means DAq Ealayohi ‡ [The affair was, or became, strait to him]. (O, TA. [See an ex. in art. rHb, conj. 6.]) One says also, DAq Ealayohi maEaAXuhu: see 4. [And DAq Alwaqotu † The time became strait, or contracted.] And DAq Sadoruhu † His bosom, or mind, became strait, or contracted: (Mṣb:) and DAq Eanohu Sadoruka † [Thy mind became so contracted as to be incapable of it: or thy mind shrank from it]. (Ḳ.) [And yaDiyqu AlEaqolu Eano taqodiyrihi † The intellect is incapable of determining its limit, or limits, or the like.] And DAq Eani AljawaAbi and biAljawaAbi † [He was straitened, or embarrassed, so as to be unable to reply, or to answer; he was incapable of replying, or answering]: both signify the same. (TA in art. znd.) And DAq bAlOamori caroEFA, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,) meaning † The thing, or affair, was difficult, or distressing, to him, (Mṣb,) originally DAq caroEuhu bihi, (Ṣ,* O,* Mṣb,) i. e. his ability [was straitened by it, or was inadequate to it]; and his power: (Mṣb:) or his art, or artifice, or cunning: or his way, course, mode, or manner, of acting (macohabuhu) [was straitened, or rendered difficult, or distressing, by it]. (O. [See more voce caroEN: and see a similar phrase in the Ḳur xi. 79 and xxix. 32.]) And hence, app., the saying DAq AlmaAlu Eani Ald-uyuwni ‡ The property was inadequate to the debts. (Mṣb.) And you say, DAq Eanoka AlX-aIoCu [meaning lamo yasaEoka † The thing was not allowable to thee]: one says, laA yasaEuniI XaIoCN wayaDiyqa Eanoka, (Ṣ, O,* TA, [in the O, erroneously, lA ystgnI,]) i. e. waOano yaDiyqa Eanoka † [A thing will not be allowable to me conjointly with its being disallowable to thee, waOano yaDiyqN meaning maEa Dayoqihi]: balo mataI wasiEaniI XaIoCN wasiEaka [but when a thing is allowable to me, it is allowable to thee]. (Ṣ in art. wsE.) And DAq, (aor. yaDiyqu, Ḳ, inf. n. DiyqN, TA,) ‡ He was or became, niggardly, or avaricious. (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)

2. Dy-qhu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taDoyiyqN, (Mṣb, TA,) He made it strait, or narrow; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a place [&c.]; (Mṣb;) as also ADAqhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UiDaAqapN. (TA.) You say, Day-aqotu Ealayohi AlmakaAna, (Ṣ,) or AlX-aIoCa, i. e. I straitened, or made narrow, to him [the place, or the thing; or I scanted it, or made it scanty]; contr. of was-aEotuhu Ealayohi. (O.) And Day-aqotu Ealayohi [alone, used elliptically, I straitened him, properly speaking; and also, † his circumstances, &c.]. (Mṣb.) And Duy-iqa EalaI fulaAnK † [Such a one was straitened]. (TA.) lituDay-iquwA Ealayohin-a, in the Ḳur [lxv. 6, † In order that ye may straiten them], implies relation to expenses and to the bosom. (TA.) [See 3. Alt-aDoyiyqu bayona XayoYayoni, occurring in the Ṣ and Ḳ in art. HwS, means The making a coarctation between two things.]

3. DAyqhu He straitened him: (MA:) [see also 2: or, properly, he straitened him, being in like manner straitened by him: see 1 in art. zHm: and] ‡ he treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, or harshness; (O,* Ḳ,* TA;) fiI kacaA [in, or in respect of, such a thing]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. ADAq ‡ His means of living became strait (DaAqa↓ Ealayohi maEaAXuhu); (TA;) his property went away; (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and he became poor. (TA.)
See also 2.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, first sentence.

6: see 1, in three places. tDAyqwA They straitened one another; pushed, or pressed, one against another; or crowded one another; in a place of assembly; syn. zaHama baEoDuhumo baEoDFA: (Mṣb in art. zHm:) or they became straitened in a place, or † in disposition. (Ṣ, O.)
10. AstDAqt bidurojapK [She endeavoured to constrict her vagina by means of a pessary], (O, Ḳ, TA,) or biAlOadowiyapi [by means of medicaments]; (A, TA;) said of a woman. (A, O, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: DayoqN an inf. n. of 1, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also DiyqN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.: (Mṣb:) [both, used as simple substs., signify Narrowness, or straitness:] accord. to Fr, [both seem to signify thus; but the latter, properly; and the former, tropically; for he says that] AlD-ayoqu is in that which does not [really] become wide, like the mind (AlS-ador): (O:) or it is maA DaAqa Eanohu Sadoruka [that of which the mind by its being contracted is incapable, or from which the mind shrinks; an explanation not given in the Ḳ as on the authority of Fr, and deviating from his words as given in the O; whence it appears that, for maA, we should perhaps read fiymaA]: (Ḳ:) but AlD-iyqu↓ is in that which may be [really] wide, like the house and the garment: (O, Ḳ:) and the former [is also used as an epithet, being a contraction of Day-iqN in this case, and as such] has a dual and a plural and a feminine; but the latter has not: (O:) or ↓both are alike [in signification]: (Ḳ:) and DayoqapN↓ is syn. with DiyqN. (Ṣ.)

Also, and DayaqN↓, accord. to AA, (O, [the latter there expressly said to be biAlt-aHoriyki,]) or the former and DiyqN↓, (Ḳ, [said in the TA to be a mistake for DayaqN, but see what follows,]) Doubt (AA, O, Ḳ) in the heart: (Ḳ)
the first is more common than the second, in this sense; and occurs in the Ḳur in xvi. last verse and xxvii. 72: (O:) [but] Ibn-Ketheer read, in both of these instances, Diyq↓; and this and Dayoq are dial. vars. signifying straitness of mind. (Bḍ.)
See also Day-iqN, in two places:
and DayoqapN, second sentence, in two places.

entry.sense: DiyqN: see the next preceding paragraph, in five places.
DayaqN: see DayoqN, latter part.
DayoqapN: see DayoqN, latter part.

Also (Ṣ) ‡ Poverty; and an evil state or condition; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA;) and so DiyqapN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) of the former (Fr, Ṣ, TA) is DayoqN↓: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA: [in the CK, erroneously, DiyqN:]) Fr says, when you see AlD-ayoq↓ to have occurred in the place of AlD-iyq, it is in [one of] two cases; either it is the pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of AlD-ayoqapu; or it means the narrow, or strait, thing, DayoqN being a contraction of Day-iqN. (TA.)

And AlD-ayoqapu, (O,) or Dayoqapu [without the article], (JK, O, TA,) or AlD-iyqapu↓, (Ḳ, [app. a mistake, for in the O, in every case, whether as a proper name or not, AlDyqp is written AlD-ayoqapu,]) is the name of A certain mansion of the moon, (JK, O, Ḳ, TA,) [not one of the Twentyeight Mansions,] close by Alv-uray-aA [or the Pleiades]: (JK, O, TA:) or, as IḲt says, on the authority of Ibn-Ziyád El-Kilábee, sometimes the moon falls short of Ald-abaraAn and alights in AlDyqp, i. e. two small stars, near together, between Alv-uray-aA and Ald-aAbaraAn: (TA:) it is asserted by the Arabs to be an inauspicious place. (O,* TA.) Hence the saying of El-Akhtal,
fahal-aA zajarota AlT-ayora layolapa jiYotahaA
biDayoqapa bayona Aln-ajomi waAld-abaraAni
[And wherefore didst not thou draw an omen from the flight of birds on the night when thou camest to her, when the moon was in Deykah, between the Pleiades and Ed-Debarán?]: he notifies that the moon, in the night of their coming together, was making its abode [in the neighbourhood of] AldbrAn, which is inauspicious: (O, TA:) or [the latter hemistich, as J relates it, app. on the authority of AʼObeyd, is thus,]
biDayoqapi bayona Aln-ajomi waAld-abaraAni
from AlD-ayoqapu as syn. with AlD-ayoqu; (Ṣ;) and as AA relates the verse, it is [thus] with kesr to the p in bDyqp; the word not being made the [proper] name of a place, but the meaning being bDyqp maA bayona Alnjm wAldbrAn [i. e. in the narrow space between the Pleiades and Ed-Debarán]. (TA.)
DayoqapN is also the fem. of DayoqN the contracted form of Day-iqN. (Ṣ, O, TA.)
DiyqapN: see the next preceding paragraph, former half, in two places.

DuwqaI and DiyqaI are fems. of OaDoyaqu↓; (Ṣ, O, Ḳ;) the former [as well as the latter] is [originally] of the measure fuEolaI, (TA,) [each being originally DuyoqaI,] the I being changed in the former into w because quiescent and preceded by ḍammeh: (Ṣ, O, TA:) the former occurs in the saying of a woman to her fellowwife, contending with her for superiority,
maA Oanoti biAlxuwraI walaA AlD-uwqaI HirFA
[Thou art not the better nor the narrower, &c.; xuwraI being in like manner fem. of Oaxoyaru]. (TA.) Accord. to Kr, the former is pl. of Day-iqapN↓; (TA;) and he says the same of DiyqaI also; (TA voce kay-isN;) but ISd says, I know not how this may be, for fuEolaI is not of the measures of pls. except of the kind of pl. which differs not from its sing. otherwise than in the latter's having p [as an affix], like buhomaApN and buhomaI [q. v.]. (TA in the present art.)
DiyaAqN: see miDoyaAqN.
DaAYiqN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

Day-iqN and DayoqN↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Ṣ,) the two being like hay-inN and hayonN [&c.], (O,) and DaAYiqN↓, (Ḳ,) Narrow, or strait: (Ṣ,* O,* Ḳ:) or Day-iqN is an epithet used in this sense when permanence [of the attribute] is meant [and so therefore is its contracted form]; and DaAYiqN↓ as meaning [being, or becoming, narrow or strait; or] temporarily narrow or strait: (Mṣb:) the fem. [of the first {Day-iqapN} (TA) and of the second {DayoqapN} (Ṣ, O, TA) as well as of the third {DaAYiqapN}] is with p: (Ṣ, O, TA:) see also DuwqaI: [the pls. of the first and second, applied to rational beings, is Day-iquwna and Dayoquwna, like may-ituwna and mayotuwna: and] the pl. of DaAYiqN↓ is DaAqapF. (TA.) You say XaIoCN Day-iqN (O, Mṣb) and DayoqN↓ (O) A narrow, or strait, thing. (O,* Mṣb.) And SadorN Day-iqN † A strait, or contracted, mind; (Mṣb;) and nafosN Day-iqapN [meaning the same]. (TA.) And waDaAYqN↓ bihi Sadoruka, in the Ḳur [xi. 15], means † And thy mind is temporarily strait or contracted thereby. (Mṣb.) Day-iqN signifies also † Niggardly, or avaricious. (KL.) [And Day-iqu Alxuluqi † Narrow, or illiberal, in disposition.]
OaDoyaqu [More, and most, narrow or strait or contracted]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) see its fems. DuwqaI and DiyqaI, above. [See also three exs. voce AisotN, in art. sth.]

maDiyqN A narrow, or strait, place: (Ḳ:) [a pass: a place of narrowness or straitness] of land; and of the vulva; and † [a place, or state, of straitness] of life, or of the means of subsistence: (Ḳ in art. Azm:) and ‡ a narrow, or strait, affair or case: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. maDaAyiqu. (TA.)
OamorN muDay-aqN † [An affair rendered strait]. (TA.)

miDoyaAqN, (JK, and O on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád, and TA,) or DiyaAqN↓, like kitaAbN [in measure], thus in all the copies of the Ḳ, (TA,) [but probably, I think, taken from a mistranscription,] A pessary (durojapN) of rag and perfume, with which a woman endeavours to constrict her vagina (tasotaDiyqu bihaA). (JK, Ibn-ʼAbbád, O, Ḳ.)

4. OaDoyalati AlOaroDu and OaDaAlat The land had in it [trees of the species called] DaAl: (Fr, Ṣ, O:) or ADAl AlmakaAnu and OaDoyala the place gave growth to DAl: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) or had in it many DAl. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)

DaAlN The wild [species of lote-tree called] sidor [q. v.]: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or such of the sidor as are watered only by the rain; (M, Ḳ:) the sidor of the mountains, which is thinner in its wood than that of the rivers: AḤn says, it grows in the plain, or soft, tracts, and in the rugged; and the bow that is made of it, when it is pared, is pared so as to be thick, in order that it may be stronger, because of the lightness of its wood: (M:) n. un. with p {DaAlapN}. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.) [See also EuboriI-N, and EumoriI-N.]

Also Another species of tree; (M, Ḳ;) AḤn says, it is a tree of the shrub-kind, found in the borders of El-Yemen, rising to the height of a cubit, in its manner of growth like the cypress, and having a yellow [fruit of the sort called a] baramap, of a very pungent odour, so that its odour comes to you before you reach it: it is not of the sidor thus called. (M.)
DaAlapN n. un. of DaAlN [q. v.]. (Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ.)

Also Arrows, (M, O, TA,) and bows, (TA,) made of the [species of lote-tree called] DaAl: (M, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) or arrows, (IB, Ḳ,) because they are made thereof: (IB:) or it signifies, (Ḳ,) or signifies also, (O,) all kinds of weapons. (O, Ḳ.) One says, raOayotuhu yaromiI biAlD-aAlapi [I saw him shooting arrows]. (TA.) And xaraja wafiI yadihi DaAlapN i. e. [He went forth having in his hand] a bow. (TA.) And Uin-ahu lakaAmilu AlD-aAlapi Verily he is complete in respect of weapons. (O.) And xaraja fulaAnN biDaAlatihi Such a one went forth with his weapons. (O.)

1. DaAmahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yaDiymuhu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. DayomN, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) [as also DaAmahu, aor. yaDuwmuhu, inf. n. DawomN, (see art. Dwm,)] He wronged him; treated him wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (Ṣ:) he harmed, injured, hurt, or damaged, him: (Mṣb:) and AstDAmhu↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ.) And DaAmahu Haq-ahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (M,) He defrauded him of his right, or due, partially or wholly; (M, Ḳ;) as also AstDAmhu↓. (Ḳ.)

And Dumotu I was wronged,, &c.: of which there are three dial. vars.; one says of a man Diyma; and Duyoma, with [the pronunciation termed] UiXomaAm; and Duwma; like as we have said respecting biyEa. (Ṣ.) One says, maA Dimotu OaHadF wamaA Dumotu [I have not wronged any one, and I have not been wronged]; i. e. no one has wronged me. (TA.) It is said in a trad., as some relate it, laA tuDaAmuwna fiI ruWoyatihi [or tuDaAm-uwna↓ or taDaAm-uwna↓ Ye will not be wronged in the seeing Him]. (M. [For other readings and explanations of this trad., see 3 in art. Dr.])
3: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
6: see the preceding paragraph {1}.
10: see 1, in two places.
DayomN Wrong; i. e. wrongdoing; or wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an inf. n. which is pluralized; its pl. being DuyuwmN. (M, Ḳ.)
DiymN The side of a mountain, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of an [eminence such as is termed] Oakamap. (M.)

DaAYimN Wronging, or a wrongdoer: pl. DaAmapN: the latter occurring in the prov., taOotiI bika AlD-aAmapu Eir-iysa AlOasadi [The wrongdoers bring thee, or cause thee to come, to the covert of the lion]; meaning, the wrong of the wrongdoers requires thee to cast thyself into destruction: applied in offering an excuse for venturing upon that which is perilous: or, as some relate it, AlD-aAm-apu, from AlD-am-u; meaning “want, or the object of want, that brings thee and causes thee to have recourse [to a thing].” (Meyd.)
maDiymN Wronged; treated wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: as also musotaDaAmN↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA.)
musotaDaAmN: see what next precedes.
